revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = Noreascon 3, the 47th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Sheraton-Boston Hotel, Hilton Hotel, [[Boston Park Plaza Hotel & Towers|Park Plaza Hotel]], and the [[Hynes Convention Center]] | location = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | country = United States | first = August 31–September 4, 1989 | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 6,837 | website = }} The '''47th World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]), also known as '''Noreascon 3''' (or "... '''Three'''", or "... '''III'''"), was held August 31–September 4, 1989, at the Sheraton-Boston Hotel, Hilton Hotel, [[Boston Park Plaza Hotel & Towers|Park Plaza Hotel]], and the [[Hynes Convention Center]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], United States. The chairman was [[Mark L. Olson]]. The Guests of Honor were [[Andre Norton]], [[Ian Ballantine|Ian]] & [[Betty Ballantine]] (pro), and [[The Stranger Club]] (fan). Seven surviving members of the latter group—the first known science fiction club in the Boston area, and responsible for organizing [[Boskone|Boskone I]], New England's first science fiction convention, in 1941—attended, including [[Hal Clement|Harry Stubbs]] (Hal Clement). Total attendance was 6,837, of 7,795 paid memberships. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== The 1989 Hugo Award base honored the 50th anniversary of both the [[1939 New York World's Fair]] and the [[1st World Science Fiction Convention|first Worldcon]]. The Fair's iconic [[Trylon and Perisphere]] were represented with the Hugo Award rocket taking the place of the {{convert|610|ft|m|sp=us}} tall Trylon spire. * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Cyteen]]'' by [[C. J. Cherryh]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[The Last of the Winnebagos]]" by [[Connie Willis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Schrödinger's Kitten]]" by [[George Alec Effinger]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Kirinyaga (story)|Kirinyaga]]" by [[Mike Resnick]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Non-Fiction Book|Best Non-Fiction Book]]: ''[[The Motion of Light in Water]]'' by [[Samuel R. Delany]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Gardner Dozois]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Michael Whelan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Semiprozine|Best Semiprozine]]: ''[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]'', edited by [[Charles N. Brown]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[File 770]]'', edited by [[Mike Glyer]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Dave Langford]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: ** [[Brad Foster]] and ** [[Diana G. Gallagher|Diana Gallagher Wu]] (tie) ===Other awards=== * [[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: ''[[SF-Lovers Digest]]'' for pioneering the use of [[computer bulletin board]]s in fandom * Special Award: [[Alex Schomburg]] for lifetime achievement in science fiction art * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[Michaela Roessner]] ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |first=Andrew L. |last=Yarrow |work=The New York Times |title=Sci-Fi Fans Meet to Ponder Genre's Present |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/04/arts/sci-fi-fans-meet-to-ponder-genre-s-present.html |date=September 4, 1989 |accessdate=March 30, 2010}} {{cite web|work=The Hugo Awards |title=1989 Hugo Awards |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1989-hugo-awards/ |accessdate=March 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612033831/http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1989-hugo-awards/ |archivedate=June 12, 2010 }} {{cite news |first=Mike |last=Glyer |authorlink=Mike Glyer |work=[[File 770]] |title=How Tall Is The Hugo? |url=http://file770.com/?p=378 |date=August 1, 2008 |accessdate=August 28, 2012}} }} == External links == * [http://www.noreascon.org/ Noreascon website] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1989 NESFA.org: 1989 convention notes] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[46th World Science Fiction Convention]]
Nolacon II in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], United States (1988) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''47th World Science Fiction Convention'''
Noreascon 3 in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], United States (1989) | after = [[48th World Science Fiction Convention]]
ConFiction in [[The Hague]], Netherlands (1990) }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 047}} [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:1989 in the United States]] [[Category:Culture of Boston]] [[Category:1989 in Massachusetts]] [[Category:1989 conferences]]

revision.text:
{{UDP|date=August 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=September 2016}} {{POV|date=September 2016}} }}
[[File:Dr. Alison Thompson heart flag.jpg|thumb|Alison Thompson holding her heart flag]] '''Alison Thompson''' has worked for the past 16 years as a full-time humanitarian volunteer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/meimeifox/2016/06/07/leading-by-being-in-the-right-place-at-the-wrong-time/#70fd46bf5983|title=Leading By Being 'In The Right Place At The Wrong Time'|last=Fox|first=MeiMei|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/opinion/op-ed/article58883703.html|title=Saving lives amid world’s worst humanitarian crisis|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/18/world/syrian-refugees-lesbos-volunteer/index.html|title=The woman who never shies away from disaster|last=CNN|first=Sara Sidner, Gul Tuysuz and Mary Rogers|website=CNN|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=World Race Films|title=Just Do Something - Alison Thompson from the Beaches of Lesvos|date=2016-03-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=asHs0mVuHM4|accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref> [[File:Dr. Alison Thompson Greece.jpg|alt=Alison Thompson is dressed in yellow emergency gear and a love cap. She is carrying a Syrian refugee baby to safety.|thumb|Alison Thompson helping Syrian refugees off a boat.]]
== Biography ==
===Greece and Syria=== Since 2015, Thompson has been working on the island of Lesvos, Greece in the epicenter of the Syrian refugee Crisis where millions have fled the war zones of Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan. In Greece, she volunteers as a paramedic rescuing refugees along the Aegean sea including resuscitating children to healing bullet and torture wounds to those fleeing ISIS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1282752|title=Refugee Crisis Lesbos, Greece|website=CNN iReport|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Chris Morrow|title=Syrian Refugees land in Lesbos Greece - crisis|date=2015-11-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sVSbjbHf7-M&feature=youtu.be&list=PLBZ3oQ4gi6NuowSRampnucc-HciT_irFB|accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref> Thompson is also bringing innovative Solar lights to give to the Syrian women and children in the dark refugee camps.<ref>{{Citation|last=Operation Blessing International|title=Illuminating Greece: Solar Lights For Refugees|date=2016-05-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DZiOqlVkrw|accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref>
The Origami 'fold up in your pocket' Solar Puff lights are important for the refugees living in the dark. Thompson has personally distributed the solar lights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/gregory-weinkauf/let-there-be-light-invent_1_b_10823542.html|title=Let There Be Light! Inventor Alice Chun and Dr. Alison Thompson Bring Solight's SolarPuff to the World|last=Poet|first=Gregory Weinkauf|last2=pundit|date=2016-07-11|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-08-31|last3=Writer|first3=Award-Winning}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Chris Morrow|title=Giving Light to the Syrian Refugees - Lesbos Greece|date=2015-11-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rv3yOwG1Zco|accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://miami.cbslocal.com/2016/01/21/south-florida-woman-helps-light-the-way-for-syrian-refugees/|title=South Florida Woman Helps Light The Way For Syrian Refugees|last=Pastrana|first=Lauren|access-date=2016-08-31}}</ref>
==Honours== In 2015 she was honored at [[Loyola University Chicago|Loyola Chicago University]] with an Honorary ‘Doctorate of Letters’,<ref name="ArtsAndCultureTv">{{Citation|last=ArtsAndCultureTv|title=Alison Thompson Loyola Doctoral Ceremony|date=2015-06-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZtcpTbHUuA|accessdate=2016-08-31}}</ref> in the ‘Humanities’, where she also gave the commencement speech.<ref name="ArtsAndCultureTv"/>
== Media == Her documentary [[The Third Wave (2007 film)|The Third Wave]] chronicles her volunteer experience in Sri Lanka after the 2004 tsunami and was screened at the 2008 [[Cannes Film Festival]] in a Presidential Jury Screening presented by Sean Penn and Bono. She followed up with a book published by Random House called The Third Wave: A Volunteer Story.
== Awards == * 2009 honored by US Army Two- Star General Simeon Trombitas and the [[82nd Airborne Division]] with the US Commanders 'Medal of Excellence' Award * 2010 [[Order of Australia]] * 2010 The [[Paul P. Harris|Paul Harris]] award from [[Rotary International]] * 2005 Humanitarian award from the President of Sri Lanka * 2012 InStyle award for Charity and Community * 2015 Loyola Chicago University Honorary ‘Doctorate of Letters’,‘Humanities’ <ref name="ArtsAndCultureTv"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thompson, Alison}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American emergency physicians]] [[Category:American humanitarians]] [[Category:American traumatologists]] [[Category:Disaster medicine]] [[Category:Emergency medical responders]] [[Category:International responses to disasters]]

{{one source|date=May 2012}}
'''Anna Gyllander''' (born 1633 – [[floruit]] 1659) was a Swedish [[imposter]], who during the reign of King [[Charles X of Sweden]], presented herself to be the abdicated queen [[Christina of Sweden]].<ref>Stålberg: Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor</ref>
==The fraud== In 1659, rumors reached King Charles X that there was a woman travelling about the country who claimed to be the former regent queen Christina, who abdicated and was living in Rome. The alleged "Queen Christina" had traveled about the country for at least a year, toasting "her brother the king" and firing gunshots to his honour. When asked if she was "''Cristina Regina''", she reportedly replied: ''"Ni säger så"'' (In English: "I hear you say that," or: "So you say"),<ref>Stålberg: Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor</ref> and said that her parents were King [[Gustav II Adolf of Sweden]] and [[Maria Eleonora of Brandenburg|queen Maria Eleonora]]. She never said straight out that she was Queen Christina, but gave the impression this was the case, and never denied it when others claimed she was.
The impostor was apprehended and identified as Anna Gyllander, daughter of Anders Gyllander from [[Norrköping]] and married to a cavalry captain from [[Courland]] in the division of Kruuse.<ref>Stålberg: Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor</ref>
She defended herself by claiming that she had no idea how serious the whole thing would be considered and pleaded for mercy. The king sentenced her to one month imprisonment on [[bread and water]], followed by banishment and exile from the kingdom and its provinces.<ref>Stålberg: Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor</ref>
== See also == * [[Helga de la Brache]] * [[Anna Ekelöf]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * Stålberg, Wilhelmina: ''[http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0183.html Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor]''
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Avalanche''' was a [[criminal]] syndicate involved in [[phishing]] attacks, [[online bank fraud]], and [[ransomware]]. The name also refers to the network of owned, rented, and compromised systems used to carry out that activity. Avalanche only infected computers running the Microsoft Windows operating system.
In November 2016, the Avalanche botnet was destroyed after a four-year project by an international consortium of law enforcement, commercial, academic, and private organizations.
==History==
Avalanche was discovered in December 2008, and may have been a replacement for a phishing group known as Rock Phish which stopped operating in 2008.<ref name="greene1">{{cite news|last=Greene|first=Tim|title=Worst Phishing Pest May be Revving Up|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/196304/worst_phishing_pest_may_be_revving_up.html|accessdate=2010-05-17|newspaper=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100520022702/http://www.pcworld.com/article/196304/worst_phishing_pest_may_be_revving_up.html| archivedate= 20 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It was run from [[Eastern Europe]] and was given its name by security researchers because of the high volume of its attacks.<ref name="mcmillan1">{{cite news|last=McMillan |first=Robert |title=Report blames 'Avalanche' group for most phishing |url=http://www.networkworld.com/news/2010/051310-report-blames-avalanche-group-for.html?hpg1=bn |accessdate=2010-05-17 |newspaper=[[Network World]] |date=2010-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613121028/http://www.networkworld.com/news/2010/051310-report-blames-avalanche-group-for.html?hpg1=bn |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }}</ref><ref name="mcmillan2">{{cite news|last=McMillan |first=Robert |title=Report blames 'Avalanche' group for most phishing |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9176661/Report_blames_Avalanche_group_for_most_phishing |accessdate=2010-05-17 |newspaper=[[Computerworld]] |date=2010-05-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516031426/http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9176661/Report_blames_Avalanche_group_for_most_phishing |archivedate=16 May 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Avalanche launched 24% of phishing attacks in the first half of 2009; in the second half of 2009, the [[Anti-Phishing Working Group]] (APWG) recorded 84,250 attacks by Avalanche, constituting 66% of all phishing attacks. The number of total phishing attacks more than doubled, an increase which the APWG directly attributes to Avalanche.<ref name="aaron1">{{cite journal|last=Aaron|first=Greg|year=2010|title=Global Phishing Survey: Trends and Domain Name Use 2H2009|url=http://www.antiphishing.org/reports/APWG_GlobalPhishingSurvey_2H2009.pdf|journal=APWG Industry Advisory|author2=Rod Rasmussen|accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref>
Avalanche used [[E-mail spam|spam email]] purporting to come from trusted organisations such as financial institutions or employment websites. Victims were deceived into entering personal information on websites made to appear as though they belong to these organisations. They were sometimes tricked into installing software attached to the emails or at a website. The [[malware]] [[Keystroke logging|logged keystrokes]], stole passwords and credit card information, and allowed unauthorised [[remote desktop software|remote access]] to the infected computer.
[[Internet Identity]]'s Phishing Trends report for the second quarter of 2009 said that Avalanche "have detailed knowledge of commercial banking platforms, particularly treasury management systems and the [[Automated Clearing House]] (ACH) system. They are also performing successful real-time [[man-in-the-middle attack]]s that defeat two-factor security tokens."<ref name="iid1">{{cite web|title=Phishing Trends Report: Analysis of Online Financial Fraud Threats Second Quarter, 2009 |url=http://www.internetidentity.com/images/stories/docs/phishing_trends_report_q2-2009_by_internet_identity.pdf |publisher=[[Internet Identity]] |accessdate=2010-05-17 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Avalanche had many similarities to the previous group [[Rock Phish]] - the first phishing group which used automated techniques - but with greater in scale and volume.<ref name="kaplan1">{{cite news|last=Kaplan |first=Dan |title="Avalanche" phishing slowing, but was all the 2009 rage |url=http://www.scmagazineus.com/avalanche-phishing-slowing-but-was-all-the-rage-last-year/article/170052/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130201222945/http://www.scmagazineus.com/avalanche-phishing-slowing-but-was-all-the-rage-last-year/article/170052/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-01 |accessdate=2010-05-17 |newspaper=SC Magazine |date=2010-05-12 }}</ref> Avalanche hosted its domains on compromised computers (a [[botnet]]). There was no single [[Internet hosting service|hosting provider]], making difficult to take down the domain and requiring the involvement of the responsible [[domain registrar]].
In addition, Avalanche used [[fast-flux]] [[Domain name system|DNS]], causing the compromised machines to change constantly. Avalanche attacks also spread the [[Zeus (malware)|Zeus]] [[Trojan horse (computing)|Trojan horse]] enabling further criminal activity. The majority of domains which Avalanche used belonged to national [[domain name registrar]]s in Europe and Asia. This differs from other phishing attacks, where the majority of domains use [[United States of America|U.S.]] registrars. It appears that Avalanche chose registrars based on their security procedures, returning repeatedly to registrars which do not detect domains being used for fraud, or which were slow to suspend abusive domains.<ref name="iid1" /><ref name="mohan1">{{cite news|last=Mohan|first=Ram|title=The State of Phishing - A Breakdown of The APWG Phishing Survey & Avalanche Phishing Gang|url=http://www.securityweek.com/content/state-phishing-breakdown-apwg-phishing-survey-avalanche-phishing-gang|accessdate=2010-05-17|newspaper=Security Week|date=2010-05-13}}</ref>
Avalanche frequently registered domains with multiple registrars, while testing others to check whether their distinctive domains were being detected and blocked. They targeted a small number financial institutions at a time, but rotated these regularly. A domain which not suspended by a registrar was re-used in later attacks. The group created a phishing "kit", which came pre-prepared for use against many victim institutions.<ref name="iid1" /><ref name="naraine1">{{cite web|last=Naraine |first=Ryan |title='Avalanche' Crimeware Kit Fuels Phishing Attacks |url=http://threatpost.com/en_us/blogs/avalanche-crimeware-kit-fuels-phishing-attacks-102309 |work=ThreatPost |publisher=[[Kaspersky Lab]] |accessdate=2010-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802000726/http://threatpost.com/en_us/blogs/avalanche-crimeware-kit-fuels-phishing-attacks-102309 |archivedate=2010-08-02 |df= }}</ref>
Avalanche attracted significant attention from security organisations; as a result, the [[uptime]] of the [[domain name]]s it used was half that of other phishing domains.<ref name="aaron1" />
In October 2009, [[ICANN]], the organisation which manages the assignment of domain names, issued a Situation Awareness Note encouraging registrars to be pro-active in dealing with Avalanche attacks.<ref name="icann1">{{cite web|last=Ito|first=Yurie|title=High volume criminal phishing attack known as Avalanche the delivery method for the Zeus botnet infector|url=http://www.icann.org/en/security/sa-2009-0002.htm|work=ICANN Situation Awareness Note 2009-10-06|publisher=[[ICANN]]|accessdate=2010-05-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100402223820/http://www.icann.org/en/security/sa-2009-0002.htm| archivedate= 2 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The UK registry, [[Nominet]] has changed its procedures to make it easier to suspend domains, because of attacks by Avalanche.<ref name="aaron1" /> Interdomain, a Spanish registrar, began requiring a confirmation code delivered by [[mobile phone]] in April 2009 which successfully forced Avalanche to stop registering fraudulent domains with them.<ref name="iid1" />
In 2010, the APWG reported that Avalanche had been responsible for two-thirds of all phishing attacks in the second half of 2009, describing it as "one of the most sophisticated and damaging on the Internet" and "the world's most prolific phishing gang".<ref name="aaron1" />
==Takedown==
In November 2009, security companies managed to shut down the Avalanche botnet for a short time; after this Avalanche reduced the scale of its activities and altered its ''[[modus operandi]]''. By April 2010, attacks by Avalanche had decreased to just 59 from a high of more than 26,000 in October 2009, but the decrease was temporary.<ref name="greene1" /><ref name="aaron1" />
On November 30, 2016, the Avalanche botnet was destroyed at the end of a four-year project by [[Interpol|INTERPOL]], [[Europol]], the Shadowserver Foundation,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shadowserver.org/wiki/pmwiki.php/Shadowserver/Mission|title=Shadowserver Foundation - Shadowserver - Mission|publisher=}}</ref> [[Eurojust]], the [[Lüneburg|Luneberg]] (Germany) police, The [[Federal Office for Information Security|German Federal Office for Information Security]] (BSI), the Fraunhofer FKIE, several antivirus companies organized by [[Symantec]], [[ICANN]], [[United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team|CERT]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], and some of the domain registries that had been used by the group.
Symantec [[Reverse engineering|reverse-engineered]] the client malware and the consortium analyzed 130 [[Terabyte|TB]] of data captured during those years. This allowed it to defeat the [[fast-flux]] distributed [[Domain name system|DNS]] obfuscation, map the command/control structure<ref>https://www.europol.europa.eu/sites/default/files/images/editor/avalanche_-_double_flux-_details.png</ref> of the botnet, and identify its numerous physical servers.
37 premises were searched, 39 servers were seized, 221 rented servers were removed from the network when their unwitting owners were notified, 500,000 [[Zombie (computer science)|zombie computers]] were freed from remote control, 17 families of malware were deprived of c/c, and the five people who ran the botnet were arrested.
The law enforcement [[DNS sinkhole|sinkhole server]], described in 2016 as the "largest ever", with 800,000 domains served, collects the IP addresses of infected computers that request instructions from the botnet so that the ISPs owning them can inform users that their machines are infected and provide removal software.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.darkreading.com/threat-intelligence/avalanche-botnet-comes-tumbling-down-in-largest-ever-sinkholing-operation/d/d-id/1327618?_mc=NL_DR_EDT_DR_daily_20161203&cid=NL_DR_EDT_DR_daily_20161203&elqTrackId=07a363846c414e28a454dada70e0dd31&elq=eb2866eb5fba46899765800b077fc473&elqaid=75229&elqat=1&elqCampaignId=24598|title=Avalanche Botnet Comes Tumbling Down In Largest-Ever Sinkholing Operation|last=Peters|first=Sarah|date=December 1, 2016|website=darkreading.com|publisher=|access-date=December 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/avalanche-malware-network-hit-law-enforcement-takedown|title=Avalanche malware network hit with law enforcement takedown|last=Symantec Security Response|first=|date=December 1, 2016|website=Symantec Connect|publisher=Symantec|access-date=December 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.europol.europa.eu/newsroom/news/%E2%80%98avalanche%E2%80%99-network-dismantled-in-international-cyber-operation|title=‘Avalanche’ network dismantled in international cyber operation|last=Europol|first=|date=December 1, 2016|website=europol.europa.eu|publisher=Europol|access-date=December 3, 2016}}</ref>
==Malware deprived of infrastructure==
The following malware families were hosted on Avalanche: * Windows-encryption Trojan horse (WVT) (a.k.a. Matsnu, Injector,Rannoh,Ransomlock.P) * URLzone (a.k.a. Bebloh) * Citadel * VM-ZeuS (a.k.a. KINS) * Bugat (a.k.a. Feodo, Geodo, Cridex, Dridex, [[Emotet]]) * newGOZ (a.k.a. GameOverZeuS) * Tinba (a.k.a. TinyBanker) * Nymaim/GozNym * Vawtrak (a.k.a. Neverquest) * Marcher * Pandabanker * Ranbyus * Smart App * TeslaCrypt * Trusteer App * Xswkit
The Avalanche network also provided the c/c communications for these other botnets: * TeslaCrypt * Nymaim * Corebot * GetTiny * Matsnu * Rovnix * Urlzone * QakBot (a.k.a. Qbot, PinkSlip Bot)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/alerts/TA16-336A|title=Alert TA16-336A|last=US-CERT|first=|date=November 30, 2016|website=us-cert.gov|publisher=CERT|access-date=December 3, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/joint-cyber-operation-takes-down-avalanche-criminal-network Joint Cyber Operation Takes Down Avalanche Criminal Network] ([[FBI]])

[[Milt Franklyn]] (unc.) |distributor=[[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] |release_date={{start date|1946|8|3}} (USA premiere) |color_process=[[Black and White]] (only seen on the theater screen)
'''In:'''
[[Technicolor]] |runtime= }} '''''Bacall to Arms''''' is a 1946 [[Warner Bros.]] cartoon in the [[Merrie Melodies]] series, co-planned by Bob Clampett, in his second-to-last cartoon at Warner Bros. (''[[The Big Snooze]]'' would be the last) and [[Tex Avery]], finished by [[Arthur Davis (animator)|Arthur Davis]] and supervised by [[Friz Freleng]]. Neither Clampett (he was left uncredited because he had left the studio before the cartoon was released) nor voice characterizations are credited. [[Mel Blanc]]'s voice is recognizable as a fat theater patron, a husband in a newsreel, and the wolf's vocal effects. Impressionist [[Dave Barry (actor)|Dave Barry]] portrays the voice of [[Humphrey Bogart]] while [[June Foray]] voices Lauren Bacall. The title refers both to Hemingway's ''[[A Farewell to Arms]]'' and actress [[Lauren Bacall]], whose acclaimed film debut was in ''[[To Have and Have Not (film)|To Have and Have Not]]'', based on another Hemingway novel, as well as a play on the term "A Call to Arms". ==Background== [[Bob Clampett]] started his directing career with [[black-and-white]] animated shorts for the [[Looney Tunes]] series, this phase of his career lasting from 1937 to 1941. In 1941, fellow director [[Tex Avery]] departed the [[Warner Bros. Cartoons]] studio. Clampett replaced Avery as the head of a unit producing [[Color motion picture film|films]] for the [[Merrie Melodies]] series, while [[Norman McCabe]] took over Clampett's former unit.Barrier (1999), unnumbered pages The chief animator of Clampett's new unit was [[Robert McKimson]]. ==Plot== The cartoon is set in a [[movie theater]]. Various random gags occur before the film, such as one patron moving to another seat another patron taking the vacated seat, and so on, accelerating into a free-for-all. A [[wolf]] makes a pass at a sexy movie [[Usher (occupation)|usher]]ette, gets slapped in the face, then settles down for the show. While the theater is in color, the films-within-the film are black-and-white. A short "[[newsreel]]" is narrated by Robert C. Bruce. The main feature is a film called ''To Have- To Have- To Have- ...'', a parody of ''[[To Have and Have Not]]''. It includes images of [[Humphrey Bogart]] and [[Lauren Bacall]], who are credited as "Bogey Gocart and Laurie Becool". In addition to recreating a few well-known scenes from that film (the kissing scene; the "put your lips together and blow" scene), the players sometimes lapse into slapstick (Bacall lighting her cigarette with a [[blowtorch]] à la [[Harpo Marx]]; or letting loose with a loud, shrill whistle after her famous sultry comment) and interact with the theater audience. Although the theater was initially full, it is eventually seen to be empty except for one patron: a literal [[lone wolf (trait)|lone wolf]] in a [[zoot suit]] who goes ga-ga over Bacall. The final gag has the wolf grabbing a [[cigarette]] that was dropped in the film and jumps off the screen, and Bogie shoots him. He hands it to Bogie and it explodes, covering him with "[[blackface]]". Bogie suddenly adopts a "[[Eddie Anderson (comedian)|Eddie 'Rochester' Anderson]]" voice, and says, "Mah, oh mah! I can work fo' Mr. [[Jack Benny|Benny]] nah!" ==Analysis== The film reuses animation from an earlier short, ''[[She Was an Acrobat's Daughter]]'' (1937) by [[Friz Freleng]]. Like its 1930s predecessor, the film depicts a noisy movie audience member which disrupts the screening. In this case the noisy audience is represented by the [[wolf-whistling]] and [[Gray wolf#Howling|howling]] of a wolf in the audience.Sartin (1998), p. 78-79 The film uses [[caricature]]s of [[Humphrey Bogart]] and [[Lauren Bacall]], who attempt to act out the scene from ''[[To Have and Have Not (film)|To Have and Have Not]]'' (1944) in which they first kiss, and her character's advice on how to whistle. Bogart eventually shoots the disruptive wolf from the movie screen, though the [[Story within a story#Film within a film|film within a film]] never properly ends.Crafton (1998), p. 107 The short is one of two memorable parodies of Bogart from the [[Warner Bros. Cartoons]] studio. The other was ''[[Slick Hare]]'' (1947), where restaurant customer Bogart demands "fried rabbit" from [[Elmer Fudd]]. Setting up a plot where both Fudd and Bogart chase after [[Bugs Bunny]].Kanfer (2011), p. 147 The film functions as a tribute to Bacall and her [[Sexual attraction|sexual attractiveness]]. It was probably produced to promote the release of an upcoming feature film, ''[[The Big Sleep (1946 film)|The Big Sleep]]'' (1946).Worland (2011), p. 91 The film [[Conflation|conflates]] two scenes from ''To Have and Have Not'', the scene where the [[protagonist]] are introduced to each other and the whistle scene.Worland (2011), p. 91 In the original film, Bogart cleans a [[fishing reel]]. In the parody, he cleans a [[List of .45 caliber handguns|.45 caliber handgun]].Worland (2011), p. 91 In a reference to Bacall's "hotness", when her caricature crosses the floor, she leaves a trail of flames behind her. While the film within a film is [[black-and-white]], making it the last [[Warner Bros.]] cartoon in [[black-and-white]], the flames are red and yellow.Worland (2011), p. 91 When she asks for a light, the Bogart caricature offers her a [[blow torch]]. She easily catches it and uses the torch to light her [[cigarette]].Worland (2011), p. 91 The distinctive voice of [[Eddie "Rochester" Anderson]] is used here to accompany a [[blackface]]-related [[visual gag]]. Christopher Lehman notes that it was typical for blackface gags in animated films to make references to well-known [[African American]] actors. References to both Anderson and [[Stepin Fetchit]] were frequently used. He notes, however, that the creators of [[Warner Bros. Cartoons]] found comedic use for Anderson's voice and [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]]. But never for the intelligence or [[wit]] of his character, Rochester. Which he finds rather telling.Lehman (2009), p. 116 Author Don Peri points that in the 1930s, [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Productions]] was the industry leader in [[character animation]]. But as this studio's focus shifted from animated shorts to [[List of animated feature films|animated feature films]], other studios started making their own advances in the field. At times depicting emotions that were absent from Disney films. Peri cites ''Bacall to Arms'' as a memorable depiction of [[lust]] in animation.Peri (2011), p. 94 The wolf himself seems similar to "[[Red Hot Riding Hood|Wolfie]]" by [[Tex Avery]].Shull, Wilt (2004), p. 77-79 [[World War II]] ended in August 1945, but several animated shorts released later in that year and into 1946 still contained war-related references. In ''Bacall to Arms'' there is a [[newsreel]] featuring ''"wartime inventions put to peacetime use"''. The example depicted is that of a married man who uses a [[radar]] to receive early warnings for the unannounced visits of his mother-in-law. Norman Klein cites the film as an example of animated films referencing [[film noir]] and figures associated with the genre, such as Bogart. He argues that [[screwball comedy film]], the chase-themed animated films, the [[crime film]], and film noir were genres which shared certain elements. In his view, all were reactions to the [[melodrama]] films of the 1930s and all rejected the moralizing tendecies of these melodramas. They reacted by embracing depictions of outrageous behavior and [[amorality]]. Common themes among them were the depiction of [[poetic justice]] as [[malum in se]], of faked sentiment as a tool of [[deception]], and [[sardonicism]] as the primary form of [[Humour|humor]].Klein (1996), p. 181-182 ==Availability== *''Bacall to Arms'' is available, uncensored and uncut, on ''[[Looney Tunes Golden Collection: Volume 5]]'', Disc 3. *Also available as bonus feature on the DVD issue of ''To Have and Have Not'' (Region 1 and 4) *It is also available on "The Golden Age Of Looney Tunes Volume 2" laserdisc. ==Sources== * {{citation | last=Barrier | first=Michael| title=''Hollywood Cartoons: American Animation in Its Golden Age'' | chapter =Warner Bros.,1941-1945| year=1999 | publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]| isbn=978-0199839223| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=xt5k08yuAXIC&pg=PT445 }} * {{citation | last=Crafton | first=Donald| editor1-last=Sandler| editor1-first=Kevin S.| title=''Reading the Rabbit: Explorations in Warner Bros. Animation'' | chapter =The View from Termite Terrace: Caricature and Parody in Warner Bros. Animation| year=1998 | publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]| isbn=978-0813525389| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=zd_WTZZjvqkC&pg=PA116 }} * {{citation | last=Kanfer | first=Stefan| title=''Tough Without a Gun: The Extraordinary Life of Humphrey Bogart'' | chapter =Cut the Gab and Bring Me an Order of Fried Rabbit| year=2011 | publisher=[[Faber and Faber]]| isbn=978-0571260744| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=O0SNDP5sIxkC&pg=PA147 }} * {{citation | last=Klein | first=Norman M.| title=''Seven Minutes: The Life and Death of the American Animated Cartoon'' | chapter =Citizen Kane, the Cartoon: Screwball Noir, 1941-46| year=1996 | publisher=[[Verso Books]]| isbn=978-1859841501| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=zNAC05_w-W8C&pg=PA182 }} * {{citation | last=Lehman | first=Christopher P.| title=''The Colored Cartoon: Black Representation in American Animated Short Films, 1907-1954'' | chapter =United Productions and the End of Animated Black Representation| year=2009| publisher=[[University of Massachusetts Press]]| isbn=978-1558497795| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=m2tZuHaupNgC&pg=PA116 }} * {{citation | last=Peri | first=Don| title=''Working with Disney: Interviews with Animators, Producers, and Artists'' | chapter =Xavier (X.) Atencio| year=2011 | publisher=[[University Press of Mississippi]]| isbn=978-1604739404| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=oQMG71o2T5IC&pg=PA94 }} * {{citation | last=Sartin | first=Hank| editor1-last=Sandler| editor1-first=Kevin S.| title=''Reading the Rabbit: Explorations in Warner Bros. Animation'' | chapter =From Vaudeville to Hollywood, from Silence to Sound: Warner Bros. Cartoons of the Early Sound Era| year=1998 | publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]| isbn=978-0813525389| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=zd_WTZZjvqkC&pg=PA116 }} * {{citation | last1=Shull | first1=Michael S.| last2=Wilt | first2=David E.| title=''Doing Their Bit: Wartime American Animated Short Films, 1939-1945'' | chapter= Slow Fade on the Home Front: 1944-1945| year=2004 | publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]| isbn=978-0786481699| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=hKrmuvh4PQkC&pg=PA78 }} * {{citation | last=Worland | first=Rick| editor1-last=Griffin| editor1-first=| title=''What Dreams Were Made of: Movie Stars of the 1940s'' | chapter =Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall: Tough Guy and Cool Dame| year=2011 | publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]| isbn=978-0813549637| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=aVK9c-msK1wC&pg=PA91 }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|38318}} *{{bcdb title|4313}} {{Ernest Hemingway}} [[Category:1946 films]] [[Category:1946 animated films]] [[Category:1940s American animated films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:1940s animated short films]] [[Category:Merrie Melodies shorts]] [[Category:Warner Bros. {{Infobox Film festival | name = Biarritz Film Festival | image = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Biarritz]], [[France]] | founded = 1991 | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = | number = | date = | language = | website = http://www.festivaldebiarritz.com/ }}
The '''Biarritz Festival Latin America''' ({{lang-fr|Festival Biarritz Amérique Latine}}) is an international [[film festival]] held annually in the [[France|French]] city of [[Biarritz]], since 1991 to promote the Latin American cinema and culture with the French people and offer opportunities to distribution or coproductions to Latin American films.
==Description== The Biarritz Festival of Latin American Cinema offer competitions of unreleased films in long films, short films and documentaries (in partnership with Latin Union).
Furthermore, the films in competicion each year, festival presents annually homages and retrospectives around different themes.
The festival also offer discover the Latin American culture in other forms with literary meetings, expositions of fotographies and academic conferences.
The famous Village festival of conviviality and exchange located oceanfront, allows to attend exhibitions, lectures and evening concerts for free.
==Awards==
* HUG for Best Feature * Jury Award for Best Feature * Best Actress * Best Actor * Feature Film Audience Award in collaboration with Air France * Prize of the French Union of Film Critics * HUG for Documentary, Latin Union Festival of Biarritz * Audience Award for Best Documentary Film * HUG for Best Short film * Special Mentions of the Short Film Jury * Prizes Shorts TV Numéricâble
== See also == *[[Cinema of Latin America]]
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.festivaldebiarritz.com}} *[https://www.facebook.com/festival.biarritz.amerique.latine/info Official Facebook Page]

'''Business Consulting International''' was a [[London]]-based investment company that collapsed after being exposed by a [[City of London Police]] investigation in 2008 as the [[United Kingdom]]'s biggest [[ponzi scheme]], estimated at £115M.<ref name=BBC17290356/> The business was set up and run by Kautilya Nandan Pruthi, a London-based Indian businessman, in partnership with Kenneth Peacock and John Anderson, who both lived in [[Sunningdale]], [[Surrey]].<ref name=DMail1202079/>
Based from rented offices at 1 Relton Mews, [[Knightsbridge]], the proposal of BCI was that clients lent it money, so that BCI in turn could lend that money at very high rates of interest to "distressed" businesses that found themselves unable to borrow from banks for short periods of time. Pruthi through BCI offered investors a return of between 4% and 20% a month on short-term fixed deposits of between four weeks and a year,<ref name=FSAAPPruthi/> while Anderson and Peacock through their own consulting companies promised slightly lower rates, passing on their deposits directly to Pruthi.<ref name=DMail1202079/>
In the last three years of operation (2005–November 2008), the partners each attracted:<ref name=DMail1202079/> *Anderson: 130 clients, investing in total between £8.4M and £10.1M *Peacock: 175 clients, investing in total between £9M and £10M *Pruthi: 290 clients, investing in total £49.5M
Peacock, a member of [[Surrey County Cricket Club]], lured in many sports personalities to the scheme. The three partners would also meet regularly at Lord’s and the [[Oval cricket ground]], where they would also meet potential investors. Pruthi additionally bought Apex Motorsports, in which he invested the funds, and to which he invited investment clients to participate in various UK and global motorsports events.<ref name=DMail1202079/>
Celebrity clients included the former cricketer [[Darren Gough]], and the actor [[Jerome Flynn]], who invested with fellow members of the [[Ratu Bagus]] religious sect.<ref name=DMail1202079>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1202079/The-pop-singer-Strictly-Come-Dancing-star-vibrating-mystics--DID-fall-85m-scam.html|title=The pop singer, the Strictly Come Dancing star, the vibrating mystics... why DID so many fall for £85m 'scam'?|author=Steve Boggan and Stephen Wright|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=25 July 2009|accessdate=2012-03-08}}</ref>
==Investigation== In November 2008, BCI and the partners' assets were frozen to allow an investigation to be undertaken by the [[City of London Police]]. Lodging papers at the [[High Court]], the [[Financial Services Authority]] accused BCI and its partners of illegally accepting deposits for a collective investment scheme in contravention of the [[Financial Services and Markets Act 2000]], as they were not authorised to operate such an enterprise.<ref name=DMail1202079/>
Despite working in the same offices, Pruthi immediately claimed that Anderson and Peacock operated independently of him and so there was no such organised "scheme". The three also counter-argued that the monies were never pooled to be "collectively" invested, and so they could not have breached the Act.<ref name=DMail1202079/>
The FSA started a search for the invested monies, which globally extended to [[Dubai]], the [[Cayman Islands]], [[Thailand]] and [[Bermuda]]. In the UK they seized: £1 million in jewellery; £250,000 in cash; and 16 cars, including [[Bentley]]s, two [[Ferrari]]s, and a [[Lamborghini]]. Pruthi was the sole shareholder of Relton Mews Air Ltd, a Bermuda-based company that owned a twin-engine [[Cessna Citation I]] jet aircraft, registered as VP-BGE. [[2008 Farnborough Cessna Citation crash|This aircraft crashed]] near [[Biggin Hill Airport]], [[Kent]], on 30 March 2008, killing five people, including: [[David Leslie (racing driver)|David Leslie]], a touring car driver; [[Richard Lloyd (racing driver)|Richard Lloyd]], a racing driver and APEX team co-owner; and Chris Allarton, a data engineer.<ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30100-1311171,00.html Farnborough Air Crash: Cessna Aircraft Goes Down In Kent |Sky News|UK News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They were travelling to the [[Circuit Paul Armagnac|Nogaro Circuit]] in France to test for Apex Motorsport in preparation for the [[FIA GT3 European Championship]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.planetlemans.com/2008/03/30/david-leslie-and-richard-lloyd-killed-in-plane-accident/ | title = David Leslie and Richard Lloyd killed in plane accident | publisher = Planetlemans | date = 30 March 2008 | accessdate = 2008-03-30}}</ref> Any monies from a $1 million (£610,000) insurance claim for the aircraft will now be deposited with the FSA.<ref name=DMail1202079/>
==Trial== On 25 March 2010, the High Court ruled that Pruthi, Anderson and Peacock, trading as Business Consulting International, John Anderson Consulting and Kenneth Peacock Consulting, were unlawfully accepting deposits from UK consumers.<ref name=FSAAPPruthi/>
On 29 June 2010, the High Court declared that the three must pay the FSA £115M within a defined period, split: Pruthi £89.8M; Anderson £13.2M; Peacock £11.6M.<ref name=FSAAPPruthi>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsa.gov.uk/pages/consumerinformation/firmnews/2010/anderson_peacock_pruthi.shtml|title=Anderson, Peacock and Pruthi to pay £115m after unlawfully accepting deposits|publisher=[[Financial Services Authority]]|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=2102-03-08}}</ref> But on failing to do so, the High Court declared each of them [[bankrupt]], to allow the FSA to recover the maximum amount of client funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsa.gov.uk/consumerinformation/firmnews/2011/anderson_peacock_pruthi.shtml|title=Call to clients of Anderson, Peacock and Pruthi|publisher=[[Financial Services Authority]]|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=2102-03-08}}</ref>
On 30 July 2010, Pruthi was charged with 30 fraud offences including running a bogus business, money laundering and obtaining money by deception, later released on [[bail]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-10821820|title=Businessman facing 30 charges over alleged £115m fraud|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=30 July 2010|accessdate=2102-03-08}}</ref> The main trial was scheduled for early 2012 at [[Southwark Crown Court]], in front of Judge Michael Gledhill QC, to allow time for the FSA to recover funds.
On 30 January 2012, before the trial began, Pruthi pleaded guilty in a pre-trial hearing to: four specimen counts of obtaining money transfers by deception; one count of participating in a fraudulent business; one count of unauthorised regulated activity; and one count of converting and removing criminal property.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16801635|title=Man admits 'biggest Ponzi fraud in the UK'|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2012|accessdate=2102-03-08}}</ref> On 5 March, Anderson and Peacock were convicted of unauthorised regulated activity, in a scheme masterminded by Pruthi. On 7 March, Anderson and Peacock were found not guilty of recklessly making a misleading, false or deceptive promise. Jurors also cleared them of one count each of fraud.<ref name=BBC17290356>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-17290356|title=Ponzi scheme pair not guilty of deception|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=7 March 2012|accessdate=2102-03-08}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
