page.title: List of expenses claims in the United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} [[File:Palace.of.westminster.arp.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]]]] This article lists the published allegations of expenses abuse made against specific [[Members of Parliament|members of the British Parliament]] in the course of the [[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal]]. While the majority of these were first made public by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' on or after 8 May 2009, a few cases had already come to public attention before that date. On 18 June 2009 the details of all MP's claims for the period 2004 to 2008 were published on the official Parliament website{{cite web|url=http://mpsallowances.parliament.uk/mpslordsandoffices/hocallowances/allowances-by-mp/ |title=UK Parliament - Allowances by MP |publisher=Mpsallowances.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2 May 2010}} together with details of voluntary repayments amounting to approximately £500,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/parliamentary_committees/mec/repayments.cfm |title=UK Parliament - Repayments of Allowances |publisher=Parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621212800/http://www.parliament.uk/parliamentary_committees/mec/repayments.cfm |archivedate=21 June 2009 }} ==Items that became public before 8 May 2009== ===The John Lewis List=== The [[John Lewis List]] is the name given to a list used by House of Commons Clerks to ascertain whether or not claims by MPs under the Additional Costs Allowance (ACA) are a realistic representation of the price of items. The list details items that are considered acceptable to be claimed on the ACA, along with the price such items would cost in the [[John Lewis (department store)|John Lewis]] department store chain.{{cite news|last=Griffiths |first=Emma |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7234982.stm |title='John Lewis' list kept from MPs |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Prior to 2008 the list was never published in case MPs saw the maximum permitted claim for each item and such a price "became the going rate", a rule House of Commons' resources chief Andrew Walker upheld in February 2008 despite campaigners wanting it released to the [[Information Tribunal]] considering the release of MPs' expenses claims. However, a freedom of information request by the [[Press Association]] just a month later, in March 2008, saw the list released into the public domain anyway,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7295066.stm |title=MPs' £10,000 kitchens on expenses |publisher=BBC News |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} revealing that MPs were able to claim for, among other things, dishwashers, television sets and tumble dryers.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7295066.stm |title=In full: MPs' 'John Lewis list' |publisher=BBC News |date=13 March 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} ===Derek Conway=== [[Derek Conway]], the MP for [[Old Bexley and Sidcup (UK Parliament constituency)|Old Bexley and Sidcup]] then under the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] whip, was found to have employed his son, Frederick, as a part-time research assistant in his parliamentary office between 2004 and 2007, with an annual salary of £10,000, despite Frederick being a full-time undergraduate student at [[Newcastle University]].{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmstnprv/280/280.pdf |format=PDF |title=House of Commons Standards and Privileges Report: Conduct of Mr Derek Conway (2008) |publisher=[[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] |location=[[Westminster]] |date=25 January 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} This arrangement was revealed by ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' on 27 May 2007, in an article which prompted a complaint to the [[Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards]], who in turn referred the matter to the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] [[Standards and Privileges Committee]]. The committee launched an investigation into the matter as a whole, and reported to the House on 28 January 2008. On the same day, Conway apologised on the floor of the Commons, stating that he accepted the report's criticisms "in full".{{cite web|author=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Commons, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmhansrd/cm080128/debtext/80128-0004.htm#0801285000004 |title=Hansard – 28 January 2008 |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date=28 January 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} The report's main finding was that there was "no record" of Frederick ever doing any substantive work for Conway, and that the salary he was paid was too high. The committee ordered Conway to repay £13,000 of the money Frederick had been paid, and recommended that Conway should be suspended from the Commons for ten sitting days. These recommendations were approved, in their entirety, by the House of Commons on 31 January 2008.{{cite web|author=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Commons, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmhansrd/cm080131/debtext/80131-0005.htm#08013153000005 |title=Hansard – 31 January 2008 |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date=31 January 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} At the time of Conway's suspension, the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] MP [[John Mann (British politician)|John Mann]] announced that he would be making a complaint to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards over Conway's employment of his other son, [[Henry Conway (socialite)|Henry]], in a similar capacity to Frederick.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7214573.stm |title=Tory whip withdrawn from Conway |publisher=BBC News |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Shortly after Conway's suspension and the second allegation being made, the Conservative leader, [[David Cameron]], withdrew the party [[whip (politics)|whip]] from Conway, effectively leaving him sitting as an [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] MP. Conway subsequently announced that he would not be standing for re-election at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|next general election]].{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/1576993/Derek-Conway-to-stand-down-at-election.html |title=Daily Telegraph – Derek Conway to stand down at election |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=31 January 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} In January 2009, a year after the first report, the Committee on Standards and Privileges published a further report, specifically in relation to Conway's employment of his son Henry. The committee found that Henry had been employed immediately prior to Frederick and, similarly, had been studying as a full-time undergraduate at the time of his employment.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200809/cmselect/cmstnprv/207/207.pdf |format=PDF |title=House of Commons Standards and Privileges Report: Conduct of Mr Derek Conway (2009) |publisher=House of Commons |location=Westminster |date=27 January 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} The committee reported that, like the previous case, there was no "hard evidence" of Henry's employment, but also stated that
it would be unfair to conclude that Henry Conway did not undertake sufficient work to fulfil the terms of his contract of employment
The committee ordered Conway to repay £3,758 in over payments to his son, and to also write a letter of apology to the committee's chairman, [[Sir George Young, 6th Baronet|Sir George Young]]. Once again, Conway apologised "without qualification" to the Commons.{{cite web|author=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Commons, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200809/cmhansrd/cm090202/debtext/90202-0017.htm |title=Hansard – 2 February 2009 |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date=2 February 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7866267.stm |title=MP Conway apologises for payments |publisher=BBC News |date=3 February 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} ===Caroline Spelman=== [[Caroline Spelman]], the then [[Chairman of the Conservative Party]], became embroiled in the "nannygate" saga on 6 June 2008 when the [[BBC]]'s ''[[Newsnight]]'' programme suggested she had paid for her nanny out of parliamentary expenses during her early years in Parliament, between 1997 and 1998.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7441360.stm |title=Tory MP paid nanny from expenses |publisher=BBC News |date=6 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Spelman issued a statement to ''Newsnight'' that the nanny in question, Tina Haynes, was also her constituency secretary. The [[Conservative Central Office]] agreed with her claim. Immediately after the revelations were made public, the nanny told ''Newsnight'' that she only took the odd phone message or posted documents when needed. In the following days, however, Haynes stated that her work had, in fact, been on a more formal basis, providing constituency secretarial work when Spelman's children were at school.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7442053.stm |title=MPs’ nanny 'did secretarial work' |publisher=BBC News |date=7 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} In an attempt to resolve the situation and clear her name, Spelman asked John Lyons, the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards, to investigate the payments to Haynes. However, the commissioner himself suggested that an investigation dating back seven years would be exceptional, especially on a self-referral.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7442622.stm |title=Watchdog 'considering' nanny case |publisher=BBC News |date=9 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Despite this, the commissioner announced on 17 June that he would launch a formal investigation into the saga.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7459528.stm |title=Spelman facing expenses inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=17 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} During the commissioner's investigation, ''Newsnight'' revealed that nine years earlier, Spelman's parliamentary secretary, Sally Hammond, had raised concerns over the "nannygate" payments with the leadership of the Conservative party. In 1998, Hammond informed [[Peter Ainsworth]], a member of the [[Shadow Cabinet (UK)|Shadow Cabinet]], who in turn referred the matter to the then [[Opposition Chief Whip]], [[James Arbuthnot]], who investigated and told Spelman to stop paying Haynes out of parliamentary expenses immediately.{{cite news|last=Crick |first=Michael |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7476527.stm |title=MPs call for Spelman to be sacked |publisher=BBC News |date=26 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} In March 2009, the Committee for Standards and Privileges published their final report into the matter, which ruled that Spelman had inadvertently "misapplied part of [her] parliamentary allowances". However, both the Committee and the Commissioner noted that Spelman was, at the time, one of many new members who had taken their seats following the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], and was therefore not fully aware of the rules governing the use or purpose of parliamentary allowances. The committee recommended that Spelman repay £9,600.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200809/cmselect/cmstnprv/316/9780215528964.pdf|format=PDF|title=Committee on Standards and Privileges Report: Mrs Caroline Spelman|date=3 March 2009|accessdate=20 May 2009|publisher=House of Commons|location=Westminster}} ===Ed Balls and Yvette Cooper=== In September 2007, the married couple and Labour [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]] ministers, [[Ed Balls]], the [[Secretary of State for Children, Schools and Families]], and [[Yvette Cooper]], then the [[Minister of State for Housing and Planning|Housing Minister]], were accused of exploiting the Commons' allowances system in order to pay for a £655,000 house in [[Stoke Newington]], [[North London]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-483406/Cabinet-husband-wife-cash-homes-loophole.html |title=Cabinet husband and wife cash in on two homes loophole |work=Daily Mail |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |author=Jonathon Oliver |date=23 September 2007 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} The couple subsequently declared this to be their second home, despite spending most of their time in London in order to fulfil their ministerial responsibilities and their children attending London schools. The declaration of the Stoke Newington property as their second home meant that they became eligible for a reported Additional Costs Allowance (ACA) of £44,000 a year to cover the property's £438,000 mortgage.{{cite news|last=Hope |first=Christopher |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1564016/Ed-Balls-claims-27000-subsidy-for-2nd-home.html |title=Daily Telegraph – Ed Balls claims £27,000 subsidy for 2nd home |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=25 September 2007 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} The Conservative MP [[Malcolm Moss]] made a complaint to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards, who agreed to launch an investigation into the matter.{{cite news|author=Ian Drury |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1029410/Ed-Balls-Yvette-Cooper-face-sleaze-watchdog-probe-using-expenses-pay-mortgage.html |title=Ed Balls and Yvette Cooper face sleaze watchdog probe over using expenses to pay their mortgage |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |work=Daily Mail |date=25 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} The commissioner ultimately found that the couple had acted in accordance with parliamentary rules and as such dismissed the complaint against them.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmstnprv/1044/1044.pdf|format=PDF|title=Committee on Standards and Privileges Report: Mr Ed Balls & Mrs Yvette Cooper|date=8 October 2008|accessdate=19 May 2009|publisher=House of Commons|location=Westminster}} The Committee on Standards and Privileges agreed with the Commissioner's dismissal of the complaint. ===Sir Nicholas and Ann Winterton=== [[Sir Nicholas Winterton|Sir Nicholas]] and [[Ann Winterton|Lady Winterton]], the married backbench Conservative MPs, were accused of claiming back mortgage interest through the Additional Cost Allowance (ACA) on a flat they owned in London, despite having completed payment of the mortgage itself. It was further alleged that the pair had subsequently transferred the ownership of the flat to a [[trustee|trust]] and then claimed £21,600 a year in rent for the flat.{{cite news|last=Porter |first=Andrew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/2151611/Conservative-MPs-Sir-Nicholas-and-Ann-Winterton-broke-Commons-expenses-rules.html |title=Daily Telegraph – Conservative MPs Sir Nicholas and Ann Winterton broke Commons expenses rules |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=18 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} A complaint was made about this arrangement by two members of the public to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards, who in turn launched an investigation. The commissioner found that a change in the allowances rules in 2003 appeared to complicate matters as it may have placed the Wintertons' arrangement outside of the rules, and ruled it was "unfortunate" that the couple never reassessed their situation following the change in rules.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmstnprv/744/744.pdf|format=PDF|title=Committee on Standards and Privileges: Sir Nicholas and Lady Winterton|publisher=House of Commons|date=17 June 2008|accessdate=19 May 2009|location=Westminster}} The commissioner also ruled that a further change to allowance rules in 2006 meant that there was a clear breach of the rules, but noted that the Wintertons would not have received any additional public funds for their arrangement than they would have if they had resided in a different property under more acceptable arrangements. It was also noted that the Wintertons had never attempted to conceal the arrangement. The Committee on Standards and Privileges agreed with the Commissioner's report and ruled that the payment of the Additional Costs Allowance to the Wintertons should be stopped. Notably however, they did not order the Wintertons to repay any money they had previously claimed.{{cite news|author=Ian Drury |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1027407/Tory-couple-broke-expenses-rules-KEEP-cash.html |title=Tory couple who broke expenses rules KEEP cash |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |work=Daily Mail |date=18 June 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} In a separate debate, the Wintertons are two of only six Conservative MPs who have refused to disclose their full expenses claims, despite orders to do so by party leader, [[David Cameron]].{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/2455511/Tory-MP-Nicholas-Winterton-accuses-David-Camerons-mafia-of-trying-to-force-him-out.html |title=Daily Telegraph – Tory MP Nicholas Winterton accuses David Cameron's mafia of trying to force him out |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=25 July 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} ===Jacqui Smith=== [[File:Smith, Jacqui (crop).jpg|thumb|right|Jacqui Smith, then Home Secretary]] In February 2009, the ''[[Mail on Sunday]]'' reported that the [[Home Secretary]], [[Jacqui Smith]], had listed her constituency home in [[Redditch]], [[Worcestershire]] as her second home, whilst designating a house she shared with her sister in [[London]] as her main home, despite sometimes spending as little as two nights there, allowing her to claim £116,000 in Additional Cost Allowance over several years.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7877422.stm |title=Smith denies expenses wrongdoing |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} A key aspect in the debate was the fact that Smith, as Home Secretary, was eligible for a "[[grace and favour]]" home in Westminster, and therefore did not need to claim expenses to live with her sister. The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that, despite several MPs complaining to him about the affair, the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards would not be launching an investigation into Smith's expenses because there was "not sufficient evidence for an inquiry".{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1138782/Fury-stitch-Jacqui-Smith-escapes-sleaze-investigation-116-000-second-home-claim.html |title=Fury over 'stitch-up' as Jacqui Smith escapes sleaze investigation into £116,000 second home claim|publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |work=Daily Mail |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} However, after the residents of the house next-door to Smith's sister complained to him, stating that Smith may only stay there for three nights a week, he requested that Smith explain her arrangements.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7896783.stm |title=Smith asked to explain expenses |publisher=BBC News |date=18 February 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} A month after allegations were made against Smith's second home arrangements, the ''[[Sunday Express]]'' revealed that Smith had claimed as parliamentary expenses for two Pay-TV [[pornographic films]] her husband, [[Richard Timney]], had watched while she was away.{{cite news|author1=Christopher Leake |author2=Brendan Carlin |lastauthoramp=yes|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1165611/Blue-movies-expenses-Jacqui-Smiths-husband-apologises-watching-porn--paid-taxpayer.html |title=Blue movies expenses |work=Daily Mail |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Smith and her husband both apologised for the error, and Smith said she would pay back the claim.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7970492.stm |title=Smith 'sorry' for expenses claim |publisher=BBC News |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} This, coupled with the previous allegation, led to mounting pressure of Smith to resign, but the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]], [[Gordon Brown]], gave her his full support, before proposing alterations to the existing expenses system.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7973075.stm |title=Scrap second home allowance - PM |publisher=BBC News |date=30 March 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}}{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/labour/5072701/Jacqui-Smith-under-pressure-over-husbands-adult-film-expense-claims.html |title=Daily Telegraph – Jacqui Smith under pressure over husband's adult film expense claims |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=31 March 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} In April 2009, Smith came under increasing pressure after yet further questions were raised about her expenses by the ''Mail on Sunday''. The newspaper suggested that Smith had claimed for several items that were supposed to allow her to "perform her duties as an MP", including a toothbrush, a patio heater, a barbecue, a flat-screen TV and a bath plug costing 89p.{{cite news|author=James Chapman |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1167576/Dont-forget-toothbrush-Jacqui-After-porn-films-furnished-home-taxpayer.html |title=Don't forget your toothbrush |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. |work=Daily Mail |date=4 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} On 2 June 2009, she announced she would stand down at the Cabinet reshuffle on 5 June 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article6415037.ece|title=Jacqui Smith to resign as Home Secretary at reshuffle|date=2 June 2009|work=The Times|accessdate=2 June 2009 | location=London | first1=Philippe | last1=Naughton | first2=Philip | last2=Webster}} ===Tony McNulty=== In March 2009, Labour minister [[Tony McNulty]] (then [[Minister for London]], [[Minister for Employment]] and MP for [[Harrow East (UK Parliament constituency)|Harrow East]]) admitted claiming expenses on a second home, occupied by his parents, which was eight miles away from his primary residence, after details appeared in the ''Mail on Sunday''. He asserted that the claim was appropriate, but ceased claiming the allowances. In an article headlined "Tony McNulty, Benefit Cheat", ''[[The Spectator]]'' on 26 March 2009 contrasted the statements made by McNulty regarding benefit cheats with his own claims for expenses.{{cite news|title=Tony McNulty, Benefit Cheat|author=Alex Massie|work=The Spectator|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=19 May 2009|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/alex-massie/2009/03/tony-mcnulty-benefit-cheat/}} He resigned during the Cabinet reshuffle of 5 June 2009.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/5454342/Tony-McNulty-resigns-following-expenses-shame.html |title=Tony McNulty resigns following expenses shame |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |work=Telegraph.co.uk |date=5 June 2009 |accessdate=5 June 2009 | location=London}} ===Eric Pickles=== On 26 March 2009, Conservative MP [[Eric Pickles]] ([[Brentwood and Ongar (UK Parliament constituency)|Brentwood and Ongar]]) appeared on the political debate programme ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]''. While discussing the controversy over Tony McNulty, Pickles admitted he claimed a second home allowance even though his constituency home was only 37 miles from Westminster. Pickles justified himself by saying ”the House of Commons works on clockwork. You have to be there. If you're on a committee, you have to be there precisely." Host [[David Dimbleby]] responded "Like a job, in other words?" reflecting the reality that many of Pickles' own constituents commute to London each day.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.uat.telegraph.co.uk/news/iainmartin/9308917/Pickles_Part_II_the_Question_Time_tapes/ |title=Pickles Part II the Question Time tapes |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=27 March 2009|accessdate=21 May 2009 | location=London}} ==Items made public on or after 8 May 2009== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right; width:20em; text-align:center; margin-left:1em" |+ Amounts to be paid back ! Name!!To Be Paid back (£) |- | {{sortname|Phil|Hope}} || {{padleft:41709|6|0}}41,709{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5317104/Phil-Hope-agrees-to-return-41000-as-MPs-retreat-on-expenses-claims.html |title=Phil Hope agrees to return £41,000 as MPs retreat on expenses claims |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009 | location=London | first=Matthew | last=Moore}} |- |
