|| {{padleft:680|6|0}}680 |- | {{sortname|George|Osborne}} || {{padleft:440|6|0}}440 |- | {{sortname|Gordon|Brown}} || {{padleft:150|6|0}}150 |- | {{sortname|Chris|Huhne}} || {{padleft:119|6|0}}119 |- | {{sortname|David|Willetts}} || {{padleft:115|6|0}}115 |- | {{sortname|Nick|Clegg}} || {{padleft:82|6|0}}82{{cite news |title=How Nick Clegg pushed expenses claims to the limit: MPs' expenses |work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314418/How-Nick-Clegg-pushed-expenses-claims-to-the-limit-MPs-expenses.html |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009 | location=London | first=Rosa | last=Prince}} |- | {{sortname|Lembit|Opik}} || {{padleft:40|6|0}}40 |- | {{sortname|Cheryl|Gillan}} || {{padleft:4|6|0}}4 |} The following details are sorted by party in descending order of parliamentary size of the party at the time of the scandal. ===Labour Party=== The ''Telegraph'' devoted the first two days of coverage to the expenses of the governing [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], beginning with the [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]] on day one, before turning to junior ministers and Labour backbenchers on the second day, Saturday 9 May. Further allegations were made on Thursday, 14 May. The main allegations the newspaper made, alongside any responses to them from the various MPs are shown below. *'''[[Gordon Brown]]''' ([[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]/[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]], [[Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy & Cowdenbeath]]) – allegedly paid his brother in excess of £6,000 for cleaning services and claimed for the same plumbing repair bill twice. [[Downing Street]] responded by saying that Brown paid his brother, who in turn paid the cleaner as the cleaner worked for them both but preferred to be paid by a single person for [[National Insurance]] reasons. The cleaner was hired by the Prime Minister's sister-in-law to clean his brother's flat but then expanded her duties to include cleaning the Prime Minister's London flat.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/may/10/gordon-brown-cleaner-mps-expenses |title=MPs' expenses: the true story of Gordon Brown, the cleaner and my husband | Politics |publisher=Guardian Media Group |work=The Guardian |date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} Meanwhile, the Commons Fees Office stated that the double payment for a repair bill was a mistake on their part and that Brown had repaid it in full.{{cite news |last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293446/MPs-expenses-Gordon-Browns-house-swap-that-let-him-claim-thousands.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Gordon Brown |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8039273.stm |title=MPs' expenses claims – key details |publisher=BBC News |date=19 June 2009 (running) |accessdate=22 June 2009}} *'''[[Tony Blair]]''', former Prime Minister – claimed £6,990 for roof repairs to his constituency home in [[Sedgefield]]. He had submitted the invoice dated 8 June 2007 on 25 June – two days before he was replaced as Prime Minister. He had announced his decision to stand down as Prime Minister on 10 May 2007.{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5567079/Tony-Blair-claimed-7000-for-new-roof-two-days-before-leaving-No.10.html |title=Tony Blair claimed £7,000 for new roof two days before leaving No.10 |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=18 June 2009 |accessdate=18 June 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Hazel Blears]]''' ([[Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government]]/Labour, [[Salford (UK Parliament constituency)|Salford]]) – claimed for three different London properties in one year and claimed nearly £5,000 for furniture in three months. It is also alleged that she switched her second home designation from her constituency house in Salford to a flat in South London, for which she claimed £800 a month second-home allowance for the mortgage. She is then said to have sold the flat for a £45,000 profit, on which she did not pay [[capital gains tax]], because she advised [[HM Revenue and Customs]] that it was in fact her main residence. Blears responded by saying that all her claims were within the rules and that her furniture bill was "reasonable", although she did admit not paying capital gains tax on the property she sold.{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293585/MPs-expenses-Hazel-Blears-claims-for-three-different-properties-in-a-year.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Hazel Blears |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} On 10 May 2009, it was reported that [[HM Revenue and Customs]] are to investigate cases of possible capital gains tax evasion by MPs such as Blears.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/may/10/mps-expenses-capital-gains-tax |title=MPs' expenses: Tax officials to investigate capital gains evasion, guardian.co.uk|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London | first=Toby | last=Helm}} A spokesman for Blears said that there was "no liability" for capital gains tax from the sale. Blears said that the system was "wrong", though she had not broken the rules. She recommended that members of the public meet with an independent body to come to a resolution.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8042261.stm|title=Expenses system 'wrong' - Blears|publisher=BBC News|date=10 May 2009|accessdate=10 May 2009}} On 12 May 2009, Blears told [[Sky News]] that she would send a cheque to HM Revenue and Customs for £13,332, the amount of capital gains tax she would have paid had she admitted liability. *'''[[Alistair Darling]]''' ([[Chancellor of the Exchequer]]/Labour, [[Edinburgh South West]]) – changed the designation of his second home four times in four years, allowing him to claim for the costs of his family home in Edinburgh, and to buy and furnish a flat in London including the cost of [[stamp duty]] and other legal fees. Darling said that "the claims were made within House of Commons rules".{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293500/Alistair-Darlings-stamp-duty-paid-by-public-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Alistair Darling |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} On 1 June 2009 the Telegraph published further allegations suggesting that the Chancellor claimed parliamentary expenses for two properties at the same time{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5418493/MPs-expenses-Alistair-Darling-billed-us-for-two-homes-at-the-same-time.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Alistair Darling billed us for two homes at the same time |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=1 June 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009 | location=London}} a claim that a spokeswoman later said was "wrong".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8076405.stm |title=Darling to repay service charges |publisher=BBC News |date=1 June 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009}} *'''[[Peter Mandelson|Lord Mandelson]]''' ([[Secretary of State for Business, Enterprise and Regulatory Reform]]/[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]], at the time MP for [[Hartlepool (UK Parliament constituency)|Hartlepool]]) billed taxpayers for work carried out on his constituency home after he announced his decision to stand down as an MP in July 2004. His final expenses claim, including £3,235 work on his house, was submitted in December 2004.{{citation|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293035/MPs-expenses-Questions-over-timing-of-Peter-Mandelsons-house-claim.html|title=Daily Telegraph: Peter Mandelson |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=14 May 2009 | location=London | first=Rosa | last=Prince}} *'''[[John Prescott]]''' (Former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]]/Labour, [[Hull East]]) – reported to have claimed £312 for fitting mock Tudor beams to his constituency home, and for two new toilet seats in as many years. Prescott has not responded to any of the claims.{{cite news|last=Beckford |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293199/MPs-expenses-Two-lavatory-seats-in-two-years-for-John-Prescott.html |title=Daily Telegraph: John Prescott |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[David Miliband]]''' ([[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]]/Labour, [[South Shields (UK Parliament constituency)|South Shields]]) – allegedly claimed for gardening expenses and nearly £30,000 in repairs, decorations, and furnishings his family home in South Shields. Miliband has made no comment.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293729/David-Miliband-challenged-by-gardener-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: David Miliband |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Jack Straw]]''' ([[Secretary of State for Justice]]/Labour, [[Blackburn (UK Parliament constituency)|Blackburn]]) – admitted using expenses to claim full council tax bill despite only paying a 50% rate. Straw said he had acted in good faith and had repaid the erroneous claims once he was aware that MPs' expenses were to be made public.{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293369/Jack-Straw-apologises-for-bungling-claim-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Jack Straw |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Phil Woolas]]''' ([[Minister of State for Borders and Immigration|Immigration Minister]]/Labour, [[Oldham East and Saddleworth]]) – reportedly claimed for ladies' clothing, comics and nappies (diapers) on expenses. Woolas said the items were on a receipt he submitted under food claims, but were not claimed themselves, and threatened the newspaper with legal action.{{cite news|last=Beckford |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5298364/Immigration-Minister-claimed-for-womens-clothing-and-panty-liners.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Phil Woolas |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Barbara Follett (politician)|Barbara Follett]]''' (Tourism Minister/Labour, [[Stevenage (UK Parliament constituency)|Stevenage]]) – reportedly claimed £25,000 in expenses for security patrols at her Soho house over a four-year period after being mugged. Follett responded by saying the claims were within the rules.{{cite news|last=Beckford |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5297818/Barbara-Follett-Millionaire-MPs-25000-expenses-on-security-over-safety-fears.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Barbara Follett |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Keith Vaz]]''' ([[Home Affairs Select Committee]] Chairman/Labour, [[Leicester East]]) – allegedly claimed £75,000 for a second home in Westminster despite living in [[Stanmore]], west [[London]], just 12 miles away. Vaz responded by claiming he made no claim in relation to his home in Stanmore which he acquired when he got married.{{cite news|last=Swaine |first=Jon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5298267/Keith-Vaz-75000-for-a-flat-12-miles-from-home.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Keith Vaz |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Margaret Moran]]''' ([[Backbencher]]/Labour, [[Luton South (UK Parliament constituency)|Luton South]]) – claimed £22,500 for treating dry rot in her coastal property in [[Southampton]], 100 miles from her constituency and a two-hour drive from Westminster, just days after making it her designated second home. Moran responded by saying she had done nothing outside of the rules and needed the Southampton property to maintain her family life. Moran also stated that there were "inaccuracies" in the ''Telegraph'' reports that were "probably actionable".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5298395/Margaret-Moran-Second-home-flip-paid-22500-dry-rot-bill.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Margaret Moran |author=Rosa Prince |author2=Holly Watt |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=15 May 2009 |accessdate=23 May 2009 | location=London}} Appearing on the [[Politics Show]] on 10 May 2009, Moran was asked: "why should the taxpayer pay for your home in Southampton when clearly you are not using it for work?". Moran said that such arrangements were necessary in order to allow MPs to have "a proper family life".{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8044998.stm|title=MPs 'claimed for swimming pools'|publisher=BBC News|date=12 May 2009|accessdate=12 May 2009}} She insisted that there was nothing wrong with her three homes arrangement and she argued that MPs should have third homes away from London or their constituency where they can relax with their partners, and that this would make them more able MPs. In the days after her expenses were exposed, Moran agreed to pay back the £22,500, saying that she understood constituents' anger. *'''[[Paul Murphy (UK politician)|Paul Murphy]]''' ([[Secretary of State for Wales]]/Labour, [[Torfaen]]) – Murphy was the only Welsh MP criticised for "claiming" expenses. Murphy claimed for a new boiler, because the one he had was deemed "unsafe", in which the water was too hot. ''The Telegraph'' identified that he had claimed £1,799 in stamp duty, £35 for a lavatory holder, £537 for an oven, £1,674 for a carpet, £605 for a new television set, £449 for a sound system, £1.98 for light bulbs, £6 for vacuum cleaner dust bags, and £6 for a tin opener.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5293490/Paul-Murphys-plumbing-bill-because-water-was-too-hot-MPs-expenses.html |title=Paul Murphy's plumbing bill because water was too hot: MPs' expenses |publisher=Telegraph |date=8 May 2009 |accessdate=2 May 2010 | location=London}} *'''[[Elliot Morley]]''' (a former [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|agriculture minister]]/Labour, [[Scunthorpe (UK Parliament constituency)|Scunthorpe]]) – continued claiming mortgage interest on his constituency home, totalling £16,000 over 18 months, after the loan had been repaid. Morley said in response that "I have made a mistake, I apologise for that and I take full responsibility". In November 2007, Morley “flipped” his designated second home from Scunthorpe to a London property he was renting out to another MP [[Ian Cawsey]]. For four months Morley claimed full mortgage interest on the London house and Cawsey, who had designated the house as his second home, continued to claim £1,000 a month as rent paid to Morley. The fees office discovered that the two MPs were both claiming for the same property in March 2008 but the arrangements were not reported or independently investigated.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5320852/Elliot-Morley-claimed-16000-for-mortgage-that-did-not-exist-MPs-expenses.html|title=Daily Telegraph: Elliot Morley |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=14 May 2009 |accessdate=14 May 2009 | location=London | first1=Robert | last1=Winnett | first2=Holly | last2=Watt}} In the hours following these allegations being made, it was announced that Morley had been suspended from the [[Parliamentary Labour Party]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8049096.stm|title=Morley suspended by Labour party |publisher=BBC News |date=14 May 2009 |accessdate=14 May 2009}} The ''Telegraph'' also alleged that Morley rented out a [[London]] flat designated as his main residence to another Labour MP, [[Ian Cawsey]], a close friend and former special adviser. Cawsey named the property as his second home, allowing him to also claim £1,000 a month in expenses to cover the rent which he was charged by Morley. In November 2007, the newspaper claims Morley "flipped" his designated second home from his Scunthorpe property to his London flat, and for four months the two men claimed expenses on the same property. Morley told BBC News that he had repaid the money two weeks prior to the ''Telegraph'' story breaking upon realising he had mistakenly continued claiming for his mortgage payments after the mortgage had been paid off in 2006. On 14 May 2009 he was suspended from the Parliamentary Labour Party because of this scandal.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8049096.stm|title=Brown suspends mortgage claim MP |publisher=BBC News|date=14 May 2009|accessdate=14 May 2009}} Morley has referred himself to Parliamentary Standards Commissioner John Lyon, in an effort to clear his name. On 29 May 2009 he announced that he would not stand for re-election at the next general election.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8074908.stm|title=Morley resignation: statement in full |publisher=BBC News|date=29 May 2009|accessdate=30 May 2009}} *'''[[Shahid Malik]]''' ([[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Justice minister]]/Labour, [[Dewsbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Dewsbury]]) – Shahid Malik (Justice minister/Labour, Dewsbury) – It was falsely alleged that Malik was paying a discounted rent on his main home in his constituency, and as such in breach of the ministerial code. Within weeks he had been cleared of any wrongdoing following an independent inquiry by Sir Philip Mawer. He was also accused of improper use of a second office in his constituency but after a ten-month inquiry Malik was cleared of abusing his expenses early in April 2010. Malik said the ruling was the end of a "12-month nightmare." He added "I have now been cleared of breaching the ministerial code of conduct by the ministerial standards adviser Sir Philip Mawer, cleared of any abuse of expenses by a parliamentary review conducted by the Department of Resources, and now finally cleared of abusing office expenses by the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards John Lyon."{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8601902.stm|title=Shahid Malik cleared of abusing office expenses|date=3 April 2010|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2 June 2010}} *'''[[David Chaytor]]''' admitted that he had claimed almost £13,000 in interest payments for a mortgage that he had already repaid. On 15 May 2009, the ''Telegraph'' reported that between September 2005 and August 2006, Chaytor claimed £1,175 a month for mortgage interest on a Westminster flat. However, Land Registry records show that the mortgage on the flat had already been paid off in January 2004.{{cite news|author=Robert Winnett|author2=Jon Swaine|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5332053/David-Chaytor-and-the-phantom-13000-mortgage-claim-MPs-expenses.html|title=David Chaytor and the phantom £13,000 mortgage claim|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=15 May 2009|accessdate=20 May 2009 | location=London}} Chaytor was suspended by the Parliamentary Labour Party following publication of the expenses he had claimed. He said "In respect of mortgage interest payments, there has been an unforgivable error in my accounting procedures for which I apologise unreservedly. I will act immediately to ensure repayment is made to the Fees Office".{{cite news|author=Andrew Alderson|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5334280/David-Chaytor-Labour-MP-suspended-by-his-party-over-expenses-disclosures.html |title=David Chaytor: Labour MP suspended by his party over expenses disclosures |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|work=Telegraph.co.uk|date=18 May 2009 |accessdate=21 May 2009 | location=London}} On 3 December 2010 he pleaded guilty to charges of false accounting in relation to parliamentary expenses claims and he was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment on 7 January 2011. *'''[[David Clelland]]''' “bought out” his partner's share of a joint mortgage on a flat in London in a deal which cost the taxpayer thousands of pounds plus legal fees. After the deal, which was approved by the Commons fees office, his taxpayer-funded mortgage interest payments increased by almost £200 a month. Mr Clelland, who cited the “increasingly bureaucratic” nature of the expenses system and fears of “press intrusion” as reasons for ending the joint mortgage, also submitted a claim including 36p for fuses. *'''[[Gerald Kaufman]]''' submitted a claim for three months’ expenses totalling £14,301.60, which included £8,865 for a Bang & Olufsen Beovision 40-inch LCD television in June 2006. The maximum amount MPs are allowed to claim for TVs is £750 as no luxury item allowed. Most of the expenses of Kaufman were spent on repairs of his second flat in Regents Park, London which he depicts as a "decrepit" and "old flat" with "out of date" facilities that had “not carried out any repairs/maintenance for 32 years”.{{cite news|author=Gordon Rayner |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5330816/Sir-Gerald-Kaufmans-1800-rug-and-an-8865-claim-for-a-television-MPs-expenses.html |title=Sir Gerald Kaufman's £1,800 rug and an £8,865 claim for a television: MPs' expenses |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=16 May 2009 |accessdate=17 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Ben Chapman (politician)|Ben Chapman]]''' admitted that he was allowed to continue claiming for interest payments on his entire mortgage after repaying £295,000 of the loan in 2002. Over 10 months the arrangement allowed Mr Chapman to receive £15,000 for the part of the home loan which had been paid off. Following publication of the claims Chapman said he would not give back the money. Permission to claim “phantom” mortgage payments is understood to have been offered to several MPs before 2004. It was stopped after Commons officials admitted it should never have been allowed.{{cite news |author=Robert Winnett |author2=Jon Swaine|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5340293/MPs-expenses-Officials-colluded-over-mortgage-claims.html |title=MPs' expenses: officials colluded over mortgage claims|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|date=17 May 2009|accessdate=19 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Ian Gibson (politician)|Dr Ian Gibson]]''' claimed mortgage payments on a London flat while, according to claims by the ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'' newspaper, his daughter and her partner lived there full-time without paying rent. He subsequently sold the property to his daughter at an undervalue. *'''[[Quentin Davies]]''' claimed £10,000 of taxpayers' money for repairs to window frames at his "second home", an 18th-century mansion, while staying at his "main home", a flat near Westminster.{{cite news |title=Defence Minister and ex-Tory MP Quentin Davies claimed £10k for window repairs |work=[[Sunday Mirror]] |publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]] |location=London, UK |date=24 May 2009 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2009/05/24/defence-minister-and-ex-tory-mp-quentin-davies-claimed-10k-for-window-repairs-115875-21384260/ |accessdate=24 May 2009 |quote=Defence Minister and ex-Tory MP Quentin Davies claimed £10,000 of taxpayers' money for repairs to window frames at his "second home" - an 18th-century mansion. He claimed for the listed building while staying at his "main home", a flat near Westminster. Mr Davies, who defected to Labour when Gordon Brown became PM in 2007, spent close to the maximum additional cost allowance in each year from 2004 to 2008. "Window frame works", costing £10,033, appeared in a claim in 2005. Mr Davies said he believes all his claims were entirely legitimate.}} It is notable{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} that this allegation against a Labour MP appeared in the ''[[Sunday Mirror]]'', a newspaper known to support the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]. ===Conservative Party=== Although focusing on Labour MPs on days one and two, on the evening of 10 May, the ''Telegraph'' website reported that the newspaper was preparing to publish the expenses claims of [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MPs in the next day's edition. It also began publishing the stories online that evening.{{cite news|last=Porter |first=Andrew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5304821/MPs-expenses-Telegraph-investigation-shifts-to-Conservatives.html |title=Daily Telegraph – MPs' expenses: Telegraph investigation shifts to Conservatives|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} The day after these particular revelations began, the Leader of the Opposition, David Cameron, announced that all questionable claims by the Shadow Cabinet would be repaid, including those made by Michael Gove, Oliver Letwin, Francis Maude and Chris Grayling.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8044998.stm |title='Appalled' Cameron orders payback|publisher=BBC News |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} Cameron himself repaid a £680 repair bill that included the clearing of wisteria from his chimney.{{cite news|last=Rayner|first=Gordon|title=David Cameron repays £680 bill for wisteria removal : MPs' expenses|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5315163/David-Cameron-repays-680-bill-for-wisteria-removal-MPs-expenses.html|accessdate=26 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|date=13 May 2009}} On the evening of 11 May, the ''Daily Telegraph'' announced it was turning its attention on the claims of backbench Conservative MPs whom the newspaper dubbed "the [[grandee]]s" of the party.{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5310200/MPs-expenses-Paying-bills-for-Tory-grandees.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Paying bills for Tory grandees|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} Those claims and further revelations are listed below: *'''[[Michael Ancram]]/The Marquess of Lothian''' (Conservative, [[Devizes (UK Parliament constituency)|Devizes]]) – said to have claimed on expenses for servicing of his swimming pool's boiler, as well as gardening, cleaning and a housekeeper at his constituency home. Ancram replied by agreeing to repay the £98 boiler servicing claim, but maintained that “none of the other items were extravagant or luxurious”.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5309953/MPs-expenses-Taxpayer-charged-for-Michael-Ancrams-pool.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Michael Ancram|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[James Arbuthnot]]''' (Conservative, [[North East Hampshire (UK Parliament constituency)|North East Hampshire]]) – reported to have claimed for maintenance on the swimming pool at his constituency home, a claim that he accepted was "an error of judgment" and one which he would repay.{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5309732/MPs-expenses-I-made-an-error-and-will-repay-pool-money-says-James-Arbuthnot.html |title=Daily Telegraph: James Arbuthnot |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Gregory Barker]]''' ([[Official Opposition|Shadow]] Energy & Climate Change Minister/Conservative, [[Bexhill and Battle (UK Parliament constituency)|Bexhill & Battle]]) – sold a London flat which he had purchased using expenses for a profit of £327,000. Barker responded by saying the newspaper had failed to take into account the fact that he had invested a "significant amount" of his own money.{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5298307/Greg-Barker-The-320000-profit-on-flat-bought-with-taxpayer-help.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Greg Barker |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Bill Cash]]''' (Conservative, [[Stone (UK Parliament constituency)|Stone]]) – it was reported on 28 May 2009 that Cash had claimed £15,000 which he then paid to his daughter, a prospective Conservative candidate, as rent for a Notting Hill flat, when he had a flat of his own a few miles away and closer to Westminster. Cash defended these expenses by claiming that it was done within the rules and that "It was only for a year".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8073531.stm |title=MP Cash 'not intending to quit' |publisher=BBC News |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=29 May 2009}} *'''[[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]]''' (Former Shadow Home Secretary/Conservative, [[Haltemprice & Howden]]) – reportedly claimed in excess of £10,000 over four years for home improvements, including £5,700 for a [[portico]] at his Yorkshire house. Davis responded that his previous portico had sustained severe water damage, necessitating the building of a new one.{{cite news|last=Hope |first=Christopher |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5309646/MPs-expenses-David-Davies-the-council-estate-lad-who-claimed-5700-for-a-portico.html |title=Daily Telegraph: David Davis|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Jonathan Djanogly]]''' ([[Official Opposition (UK)|Shadow]] Business Minister & Shadow Solicitor General/Conservative, [[Huntingdon (UK Parliament constituency)|Huntingdon]]) - claimed £5,000 for security gates on his constituency home as well as £13,962 for cleaning expenses and a further £12,951 for gardening costs. Djanogly commented that "The automatic gates are integrated with a CCTV system which I installed with police advice after I had security threats following from my representation of constituents' interests at Huntingdon Life Sciences."{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8064794.stm |title=Tory MP claims £5,000 for gates |publisher=BBC News |date=23 May 2009 |accessdate=23 May 2009}} *'''[[Alan Duncan]]''' ([[Official Opposition (UK)|Shadow]] Leader of the House/Conservative, [[Rutland and Melton]]) – claimed more than £4,000 over a three-year period in expenses for gardening costs until he agreed with the Commons Fees Office that such claims "could be considered excessive" and stopped. Duncan quickly responded by suggesting that the reports in the ''Telegraph'' were "misleading", and that all his claims were "legitimate and approved by the fees office".{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5304976/Alan-Duncan-claimed-thousands-for-gardening-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Alan Duncan|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Cheryl Gillan]]''' (Shadow Welsh Secretary/Conservative, [[Chesham and Amersham]]) – claimed on expenses for £4.47 worth of pet food. Gillan confirmed that dog food had been mistakenly included in a claim, and that she would pay the relevant amount back to the Commons.{{cite news|last=Beckford |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305101/Cheryl-Gillan-claimed-for-dog-food-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Cheryl Gillan|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|date=11 May 2009|accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Michael Gove]]''' (Shadow Children, Schools & Families Secretary/Conservative, [[Surrey Heath]]) – claimed £7,000 for furnishing a London property before "flipping" his designated second home to a house in his constituency, a property for which he claimed around £13,000 to cover stamp duty. It is also alleged that Gove claimed for a cot mattress, despite children's items being banned under the Commons rule. Gove said he would repay the claim for the cot mattress, but maintained that his other claims were "below the acceptable threshold costs for furniture".{{cite news|last=Hope |first=Christopher |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305434/Michael-Gove-flipped-homes-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Michael Gove|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Chris Grayling]]''' (Shadow Home Secretary/Conservative, [[Epsom and Ewell (UK Parliament constituency)|Epsom & Ewell]]) – reportedly claimed to renovate a flat in London, despite already owning three properties inside the [[M25 motorway|M25]]. Grayling is also said to have continued to claim for works on the property for up to a year after they had finished. Grayling defended his claims, saying he needed to have two homes in order to serve both his constituents and fulfil his duties in the Shadow Cabinet.{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305242/Chris-Grayling-claimed-for-London-flat-despite-nearby-constituency-home-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Chris Grayling |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009}} *'''[[John Gummer]]''' (Former Cabinet Minister/Conservative, [[Suffolk Coastal (UK Parliament constituency)|Suffolk Coastal]]) – claimed more than £9,000 for gardening. Gummer has yet to respond. *'''[[David Heathcoat-Amory]]''' (Conservative, [[Wells (UK Parliament constituency)|Wells]]) – allegedly claimed for more than £380 of horse manure for his garden. Heathcoat-Amory responded only to confirm that such claims had indeed been made.{{cite news|last=Allen |first=Nick |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5310147/MPs-expenses-David-Heathcoat-Amory-dumps-550-sacks-of-manure-on-taxpayer.html |title=Daily Telegraph: David Heathcoat-Amory|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Douglas Hogg]]/Viscount Hailsham'''{{Anchor|Douglas Hogg|Sleaford and North Hykeham}} (Conservative, [[Sleaford and North Hykeham]]) – allegedly claimed £2,115 to have the moat at his country estate cleaned, as well as claiming for piano tuning and a gardener. Hogg emphatically denied the claims, saying: "I have never claimed for the moat, or for the piano tuning - the allegation that I did is incorrect. I never claimed for these and I never received any money."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5330641/Best-quotes-on-the-Telegraphs-MPs-expenses-investigation.html?image=5 |title=Best quotes about the Telegraph's MPs' expenses investigation |work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009|accessdate=22 May 2009 | location=London}} Later, he responded to the newspaper's claims by saying he had agreed all claims with the fees office, and therefore hoped and believed that they would comply with the rules and the meaning of the rules.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5310069/MPs-expenses-Clearing-the-moat-at-Douglas-Hoggs-manor.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Douglas Hogg|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Stewart Jackson]]''' (Shadow Communities Minister/Conservative, [[Peterborough (UK Parliament constituency)|Peterborough]]) – reported to have claimed £11,000 in 'professional fees' and over £300 for maintaining the swimming pool at his home. When questioned, Jackson admitted that the swimming pool claim could be "construed as excessive" and as such would repay the money.{{cite news|last=Swaine |first=Jon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5310312/MPs-expenses-Stewart-Jackson-admits-claim-for-pool-work-was-excessive.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Stewart Jackson|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Bernard Jenkin]]''' (Conservative, [[Bracknell (UK Parliament constituency)|North Essex]]) - was reported to have used £50,000 in expenses in order to pay his sister-in-law rent on the property he uses as his constituency home. Jenkin claimed that he was paying "an honest and reasonable rent" for the property.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8064828.stm |title=UK | Stop MP humiliation - archbishop |publisher=BBC News |date=23 May 2009 |accessdate=2 May 2010}} *'''[[Julie Kirkbride]]''' (Conservative, [[Bromsgrove (UK Parliament constituency)|Bromsgrove]]) - was reported to have claimed, amongst other costs, over £1,000 per month in mortgage payments on an apartment in her constituency. She has stated that these claims are "a total distortion".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8065511.stm |title=Expenses row MP faces more claims |date=24 May 2009 |accessdate=24 May 2009 |publisher=BBC News}} Kirkbride is reported to have claimed, jointly with her husband, MP [[Andrew MacKay|Andrew Mackay]], that the couple's two homes were both second homes, which were subsidised by taxpayers.{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25488415-28737,00.html |title=MPs' rorts infuriate the British |author=Peter Wilson |date=16 May 2009 |accessdate=28 May 2009 |work=[[The Australian]] |publisher=News Limited}} *'''[[Andrew Lansley]]''' (Shadow Health Secretary/Conservative, [[South Cambridgeshire (UK Parliament constituency)|South Cambridgeshire]]) – also accused of 'flipping' second homes after claiming in order to renovate a rural cottage prior to selling it. It is claimed that after he 'flipped' his second home designation to a London flat, he claimed thousands of pounds for furniture. Lansley responded to the claims by stating that his claims were "within the rules".{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305406/Andrew-Lansley-sold-home-after-expenses-renovations.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Andrew Lansley|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Oliver Letwin]]''' (Chairman of the Conservative Research Department & Policy Review/Conservative, [[West Dorset (UK Parliament constituency)|West Dorset]]) – reportedly claimed over £2,000 to replace a leaking pipe on the tennis courts at his constituency home. Letwin responded by saying that the work had to be carried out because he had been served with a statutory notice by the water company.{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305385/Oliver-Letwins-tennis-court-repairs-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Oliver Letwin|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Andrew MacKay]]''' (Conservative, [[Bracknell (UK Parliament constituency)|Bracknell]]) - resigned as parliamentary aide to [[David Cameron]] over what he described as "unacceptable" expenses claims made by him and his wife, [[Julie Kirkbride]], a fellow MP.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8049614.stm |title=Tory MP quits post over expenses |publisher=BBC News |date=14 May 2009 |accessdate=14 May 2009}} *'''[[David Maclean]]''' (Conservative, [[Penrith and The Border (UK Parliament constituency)|Penrith and The Border]]) - who introduced the 2007 Bill, spent more than £20,000 improving his farmhouse under the Additional Costs Allowance (ACA) before selling it for £750,000. He claimed the money by designating the property as his “second home” with the Commons authorities, yet Maclean did not pay capital gains tax on the sale because the taxman accepted it was his main home.{{cite news|author=Patrick Hennessy |author2=Melissa Kite |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5336230/MPs-expenses-cash-secrets-of-MPs-who-tried-to-stop-you-seeing-their-expenses.html |title=MPs' expenses: cash secrets of MPs who tried to stop you seeing their expenses |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=17 May 2009 |accessdate=17 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Francis Maude]]''' (Shadow Minister for the Cabinet Office/Conservative, [[Horsham (UK Parliament constituency)|Horsham]]) – allegedly had a claim for mortgage interest rejected by the Fees Office. It is also suggested that Maude purchased a flat in London, close to a house he already owned, before claiming on the flat and renting out the house.{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5305293/David-Camerons-shadow-cabinet-drawn-into-expenses-scandal-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph – David Cameron's shadow cabinet drawn into expenses scandal|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Malcolm Rifkind|Sir Malcolm Rifkind]]''' {{small|[[Order of St Michael and St George|KCMG]]}} (Former Foreign Secretary/Conservative, [[Kensington and Chelsea (UK Parliament constituency)|Kensington and Chelsea]]) - in 2008 he claimed £3,066 for flights to his home in Scotland despite representing Kensington and Chelsea which is only three tube stops away from the Houses of Parliament.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=a43L_nXgklbw&refer=uk |title=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=a43L_nXgklbw&refer=uk |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |work=Bloomberg.com |date=21 May 2009 |accessdate=1 June 2009 |author=Robert Hutton |author2=Kitty Donaldson}} *'''[[Michael Spicer, Baron Spicer|Sir Michael Spicer]]''' (Chairman of the [[1922 Committee]]/Conservative, [[West Worcestershire (UK Parliament constituency)|West Worcestershire]]) – said to have claimed for the costs of hanging a chandelier in his main manor house and £5,650 in nine months for his garden to be maintained, which included the cutting of a hedge into a helipad. Spicer responded by saying the helipad was a "family joke". *'''[[Anthony Steen]]''' (Conservative, [[Totnes (UK Parliament constituency)|Totnes]]) - claimed more than £87,000 over four years for maintenance and upkeep of his country home. Since the revelation in the Daily Telegraph, Steen has announced that he will not be standing at the next General Election. He also claimed on the BBC's [[The World at One]] radio programme that people were "jealous" because he has a "very, very large house".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8062205.stm |title=Steen: 'People are jealous of my house' |publisher=BBC News |date=21 May 2009 |accessdate=24 May 2009}} [[File:Skogaholm Manor.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Skansen|Skogaholm Manor]]. Peter Viggers claimed compensation for a replica of the manor to be used as a duck house.]] *'''[[Peter Viggers|Sir Peter Viggers]]''' (Conservative, [[Gosport (UK Parliament constituency)|Gosport]]) - said to have claimed £20,000 on gardening expenses and £1,645 for a 5 ft [[duck]] house,{{cite news|title=MP made claim for 'non-mortgage' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8060563.stm|publisher=BBC News |date=20 May 2009|accessdate=20 May 2009|quote=Another Tory MP, Sir Peter Viggers, will step down at the next election after claiming £20,000 on gardening.…[The Daily Telegraph] also said that Sir Peter, MP for Gosport, claimed £2,000 for a duck island.}} made as a replica of [[Skansen|Skogaholm Manor]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]].{{cite web|url=http://di.se/Avdelningar/Artikel.aspx?stat=0&ArticleID=2009%5c05%5c22%5c338404&SectionId=Ettan&menusection=Startsidan;Huvudnyheter&o=sp4 |title=Stockholm - Ett ankhus för mycket |publisher=di.se|date=22 May 2009|accessdate=22 May 2009}} Mystery surrounds the whereabouts of the £1,645 duck house after aerial photographs revealed it was no longer in its pond, but Viggers had sold the property and the new owners may have removed the house for reasons related to this story.{{cite news|author=Nick Allen |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5364831/MPs-expenses-Sir-Peter-Viggers-in-duck-house-mystery.html |title=MPs' expenses: Sir Peter Viggers in duck house mystery], |work=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=21 May 2009|accessdate=21 May 2009 | location=London}} The duck house later resurfaced and was auctioned for charity, going on display at a business centre in Wolverhampton{{cite news|author=Peter Henley |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/peterhenley/2010/09/should_the_duck_house_be_sold.html |title=Should the duck house be sold |work=BBC News |date=7 September 2010 |accessdate=1 December 2010}} *'''[[Bill Wiggin]]''' (Conservative, [[Leominster (UK Parliament constituency)|Leominster]]) - said to have claimed mortgage interest on his constituency home even though the house had never had a mortgage on it. *'''[[David Willetts]]''' (Shadow Innovation, Universities and Skills Secretary/Conservative, [[Havant (UK Parliament constituency)|Havant]]) – allegedly claimed £100 for workmen to replace 25 light bulbs in his second home. Willetts said that a workman was required to replace the light bulbs because there was a fault in the system that "needed the attention of an electrician".{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5304988/David-Willetts-skills-minister-who-cant-change-a-light-bulb--MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: David Willetts|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=11 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Brian Binley]]''' (Conservative, [[Northampton South]]) - claimed £57,000 over 3 years in rent in respect of a flat owned by a company of which he was chairman. Initially, the arrangement may have been permissible within the expenses rules. In April 2006 the rules were tightened specifically to bar MPs from paying rent to their own companies. The House of Commons fees office contacted Mr Binley to inform him that his arrangement was outside the rules but payments continued until early 2009.{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5553901/MPs-expenses-Tory-claims-57000-to-rent-flat-from-own-company.html |title=Tory claims £57,000 to rent flat from own company|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=17 June 2009 |accessdate=17 June 2009 | location=London}} ===Liberal Democrats=== The [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] became the focus of the ''Daily Telegraph'''s revelations on day 6 of the publications.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314507/Telegraph-discloses-Liberal-Democrat-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Telegraph discloses Liberal Democrats MPs' expenses |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} The allegations made alongside responses from the MPs are listed below. *'''[[Nick Clegg]]''' (Liberal Democrat Leader/Liberal Democrat, [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]]) – allegedly claimed the full amount permissible under the Additional Cost Allowance, including claims for food, gardening and redecorating. The ''Telegraph'' also said Clegg claimed £80 for international call charges, a claim he said he would repay.{{cite news|last=Prince |first=Rosa |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314418/How-Nick-Clegg-pushed-expenses-claims-to-the-limit-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Nick Clegg|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 December 2005 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Chris Huhne]]''' (Home Affairs Spokesman/Liberal Democrat [[Eastleigh (UK Parliament constituency)|Eastleigh]]) – is said to have claimed for various items including groceries, fluffy dusters and a trouser press. Huhne said he would repay the cost of the trouser press in order "to avoid controversy".{{cite news|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314093/Chris-Huhne-a-multi-millionaire-but-you-buy-his-chocolate-HobNobs-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Chris Huhne|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Sir Menzies Campbell]]''' (Former Liberal Democrat leader/Liberal Democrat, [[North East Fife (UK Parliament constituency)|North East Fife]]) – reportedly claimed £10,000 to redesign his flat in London, which included the purchasing of a king-sized bed, scatter cushions and a plasma television. Campbell said he believed that the claims were "within the spirit and letter of the rules" as the flat had not been renovated for 20 years.{{cite news|last=Hope |first=Christopher |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314759/Sir-Menzies-Campbell-hired-top-designer-for-10000-overhaul-of-flat-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Sir Menzies Campbell|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Lembit Öpik]]''' (Liberal Democrat, [[Montgomeryshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Montgomeryshire]]) – is said to have claimed £40 to pay a [[court summons]] he received for non-payment of [[council tax]]. Öpik responded by agreeing to repay the amount in question. It was also revealed that Öpik had been refused payment for a £2,500 plasma television for his constituency home because he had purchased it after the [[dissolution of Parliament]] for the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]].{{cite news|last=Swaine |first=Jon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5314613/Lembit-Opik-forced-to-pay-for-own-2500-plasma-TV-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Lembit Öpik|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Andrew George (politician)|Andrew George]]''' (Liberal Democrat, [[St Ives (UK Parliament constituency)|St Ives]]) – allegedly claims nearly £850 a month for mortgage interest payments on a [[London Docklands|Docklands]] flat, the home insurance policy for which is in his daughter's name. George said that whilst his daughter did use the flat as a "bolt-hole", she did not spend more time there than he did.{{cite news|last=Beckford |first=Martin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5315055/MPs-expenses-Liberal-Democrat-claims-for-308000-flat-used-by-daughter-as-bolt-hole.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Andrew George|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Julia Goldsworthy]]''' (Liberal Democrat, [[Falmouth and Camborne (UK Parliament constituency)|Falmouth and Camborne]]) – reportedly claimed thousands of pounds on furniture in the days immediately prior to the end of the financial year, the deadline for expenses claims. Goldsworthy said she had claimed "only reasonable costs for furnishings".{{cite news|last=Winnett |first=Robert |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5315041/Julia-Goldsworthys-home-spree-as-deadline-loomed-MPs-expenses.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Julia Goldsworthy|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news|publisher=Northcliffe Media|work=West Briton (Falmouth & Penryn edition)|date=14 May 2009|title=Goldsworthy: 'I did not set up a spending spree'|page=1}} ===Sinn Féin=== On 10 May 2009, ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'' reported that the five [[Sinn Féin]] MPs together claimed nearly £500,000 in second home allowances, despite never taking up their seats at Westminster due to the party's [[abstentionist]] policy.{{cite web |title=Sinn Féin press release |url=http://www.sinnfein.org/releases/01/pr011812d.html |publisher=Sinn Féin |date=18 December 2001 |accessdate=11 May 2009}}{{cite news|last=Alderson |first=Andrew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5301510/MPs-expenses-Sinn-Fein-claimed-500000-for-second-homes.html |title=MPs' expenses: Sinn Féin claimed £500,000 for second homes |work=The Sunday Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} In its defence, Sinn Féin stated that its members often have to travel to London on parliamentary business. *'''[[Gerry Adams]]''' (Sinn Féin (President), [[Belfast West (UK Parliament constituency)|Belfast West]]) and '''[[Martin McGuinness]]''' (Sinn Féin,McGuiness was [[First Minister and deputy First Minister|deputy First Minister]] of [[Northern Ireland]]. Gildernew and Murphy was also ministers in the [[Northern Ireland Executive]] [[Mid Ulster (UK Parliament constituency)|Mid Ulster]]) – reportedly jointly claimed £3,600 a month for a shared flat in London, for which a local estate agent claims a fair rent would be £1,400.{{cite news|last=Alderson |first=Andrew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5301510/MPs-expenses-Sinn-Fein-claimed-500000-for-second-homes.html |title=Daily Telegraph: Sinn Féin MPs |work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} *'''[[Michelle Gildernew]]''' (Sinn Féin, [[Fermanagh and South Tyrone (UK Parliament constituency)|Fermanagh & South Tyrone]]), '''[[Pat Doherty]]''' (Sinn Féin, [[West Tyrone (UK Parliament constituency)|West Tyrone]]) and '''[[Conor Murphy]]''' (Sinn Féin, [[Newry and Armagh (UK Parliament constituency)|Newry & Armagh]]) – jointly reported to have claimed £5,400 per month as rent for a shared [[townhouse]] which an estate agent estimated at costing £1,800 a month. ===The House of Lords=== *'''[[Glenys Thornton, Baroness Thornton]]''' has also been implicated in this controversy, having been reported{{cite news|author=Rajeev Syal |author2=Toby Helm |author3=Gabby Hinsliff |author4=David Batty |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/may/10/mps-expenses-capital-gains-tax |title=MPs' expenses: Tax officials to investigate capital gains evasion |publisher=Guardian Media Group |work=The Guardian |date=10 May 2009 |accessdate=13 May 2009 | location=London}} to be claiming £22,000 a year in expenses by saying that her mother's bungalow in Yorkshire is her main home, amounting to around £130,000 since 2002. She was later cleared of any wrongdoing by [[Michael Pownall]], the [[Clerk of the Parliaments|Clerk of Parliaments]], after it was determined that she spent much of her time there while caring for her mother.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article7021155.ece|title=Nine peers cleared over expenses claims|publisher=The Times|date=10 February 2010|accessdate=6 May 2010 | location=London | first=Roland | last=Watson}} ===Couples=== *'''[[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter]] and [[Iris Robinson]]''' ([[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]], [[Belfast East (UK Parliament constituency)|Belfast East]] and [[Strangford (UK Parliament constituency)|Strangford]]). The couple were found to have been claiming nearly the maximum amount for food, totalling £30,000 over four years.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8051277.stm |title=Robinsons in £30,000 food claims |publisher=BBC News |date=15 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009}} Both Robinsons were also members of the Northern Ireland Assembly, with Mr Robinson serving as [[First Minister of Northern Ireland|First Minister]], and both had voted in less than 40% of divisions in the period.{{cite web|url=http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/mp.php?mpn=Peter_Robinson&mpc=Belfast_East |title=Voting Record — Peter Robinson MP, Belfast East |publisher=Public Whip |date= |accessdate=15 May 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/mp.php?mpn=Iris_Robinson&mpc=Strangford |title=Voting Record — Iris Robinson MP, Strangford |publisher=The Public Whip |date= |accessdate=15 May 2009}} Peter Robinson responded, "I think if MPs slept on a park bench and starved themselves that would still be too much for some people."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8051277.stm |title=Robinsons in £30,000 food claims |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=15 May 2009 |date=15 May 2009}} *'''[[Alan Keen|Alan]] and [[Ann Keen]]''' (Labour, [[Feltham and Heston (UK Parliament constituency)|Feltham & Heston]]/Labour, [[Brentford and Isleworth (UK Parliament constituency)|Brentford & Isleworth]] and junior [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Health minister]]) – allegedly claiming interest on a £520,000 mortgage for a £500,000 flat designated as their second home, despite their constituencies being 30 minutes away from Parliament. Alan Keen responded to the allegations by stating that the fees office had agreed the claims. Both MPs claimed more than £30,000 each for the previous four consecutive years toward the property. The remaining £20,000 from the £520,000 mortgage was spent on "fixtures and fittings" on the property.{{cite news|last=Watt |first=Holly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/5324707/Ann-and-Alan-Keen-buy-flat-10-miles-from-home-MPs-expenses.html |title=Ann and Alan Keen buy flat 10 miles from home: MPs' expenses|work=Telegraph.co.uk |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |date=15 May 2009 |accessdate=15 May 2009 | location=London}} The Parliamentary Standards Commissioner is investigating the Keens' housing claims.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8144906.stm|title=MP couple win squatter court bid |date=10 July 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=13 July 2009}} On 26 June 2009 a group of squatters moved into the Keens main home in protest over the Keens expense claims, amid claims that their main home was derelict and had not been lived in for a year. The Keens are facing having their main home seized as an abandoned dwelling by [[Hounslow Council]] under recent legislation.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1198919/Mr-Mrs-Expenses-granted-court-order-kick-squatters-main-home.html|title='Mr and Mrs Expenses' granted court order to kick out squatters from their 'main' home |last=Allen|first=Vanessa|date=10 July 2009|work=The Daily Mail|publisher=Metro Media Group |accessdate=13 July 2009}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Speaker of the British House of Commons election, 2009}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Expenses Claims In The United Kingdom Parliamentary Expenses Scandal}} [[Category:2009 controversies|United Kingdom Parliamentary Expenses Scandal List Of Expenses Claims]] [[Category:Political scandals in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2009 in British politics]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Maria | logo = | logo_size = <!-- default is 180px --> | image_file = <!-- cover.jpg (omit the "file:" prefix) --> | image_size = <!-- default is 180px --> | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[Women's magazine]] | frequency = Weekly | format = | publisher = Impala Sociedade Editorial SA | circulation = 177,770 (Sept.-Oct. 2013) | founder = | founded ={{Start date and age|1978}} | firstdate = | finaldate = | finalnumber = | company = Impala | country = [[Portugal]] | based = [[Queluz, Portugal|Queluz]], [[Lisbon]] | language = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | website = | issn = | oclc = }}
'''''Maria''''' is a Portuguese language weekly women's magazine published in [[Queluz, Portugal|Queluz]], [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]]. It is one of the most popular weeklies in the country.
==History and profile== ''Maria'' was established in 1978.<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview of the Sector|url=http://www.gmcs.pt/en/overview-of-the-sector-20140314-164712|work=GMCS|accessdate=17 May 2015|date=19 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Rui Alexandre Novais|author2=Hugo Ferro|title=Media Stratups in a Creative Destructive Scenario|url=http://www.cmdconf.net/2013/makale/PDF/29.pdf|work=II. International Conference on Communication, Media, Technology and Design|accessdate=3 May 2015|date=2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Fernando Correia|title=Media landscapes. Portugal|url=http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/portugal|work=European Journalism Centre|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> Its headquarters is in Queluz, Lisbon.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Europa World Year: Kazakhstan - Zimbabwe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C&pg=PA3489|accessdate=3 May 2015|year=2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-85743-255-8|page=3488}}</ref> The magazine is part of the Impala Group, which also owns ''[[Nova Gente]]'', a celebrity magazine.<ref name=bpi>{{cite web|title=Portuguese Media|url=https://www.bpiequity.bpi.pt/others/PDF.aspx?id=49681|work=BPI Equity|accessdate=3 May 2015|date=5 March 2014}}</ref> ''Maria'' is published by Impala Sociedade Editorial SA on a weekly basis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maria - Portugal|url=http://www.magazineexpress.com/548467026maria-portugal.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518094253/http://www.magazineexpress.com/548467026maria-portugal.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=18 May 2015|publisher=Magazine Express|accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Portugal and Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IT2dAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA44|accessdate=3 May 2015|date=1 June 2013|publisher=Britanncia Educational Publishing|isbn=978-1-61530-993-1|page=44}}</ref>
In 2007 the circulation of ''Maria'' was 243,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anne Austin |title=Western Europe Market and Media Fact |url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |work=Zenith Optimedia |accessdate=11 April 2015 |date=2008 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205131709/http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20%26%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |archivedate=5 February 2015 |df= }}</ref> In 2010 the magazine had a circulation of 203,817 copies.<ref name=ifa>{{cite web|title=Top 50 Magazines|url=http://ifabc.org/site/assets/media/Top-50-magazines-30042014.xlsx|work=IFABC|accessdate=3 May 2015|date=30 April 2014}}</ref> It fell to 201,063 copies in 2011 and to 190,826 copies in 2012.<ref name=ifa/> Between September and October 2013 its circulation was 177,770 copies.<ref name=bpi/>
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Portugal]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maria}} [[Category:1978 establishments in Portugal]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1978]] [[Category:Media in Lisbon]] [[Category:Portuguese magazines]] [[Category:Portuguese-language magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Women's magazines]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[File:Michael Hill International Violin Competition logo.jpg|thumb|The logo for the competition|alt=Thin silver letters spelling out 'Michael Hill International Violin Competition']] The '''Michael Hill International Violin Competition''' is a [[:wikt:biennial|biennial]] music competition for [[violin]]ists aged between 18 and 28.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianz.org.nz/our-work/arts-community/-limelight/violin-comp|title=An Asian flavour at the Michael Hill International Violin Competition 2009|work=Asia New Zealand Foundation|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> It was founded by [[Michael Hill (entrepreneur)|Michael Hill]] in 2001<ref name=mhivcmhs>{{Cite web| title = Michael Hill International Violin Competition – The Michael Hill Story| url=http://www.michaelhillinternationalviolincompetition.com/index.php/pi_pageid/106| accessdate = 25 May 2010 }}</ref> as the Michael Hill World Violin Competition.<ref name=wfimc>{{Cite web| title = World Federation of International Music Competitions| publisher = World Federation of International Music Competitions| url = http://www.fmcim.org/comp/city.php?type=org-jv&org_id=281&lang=en&menu=1| accessdate = 25 May 2010}}</ref> Hill remains a major sponsor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/547685|title=Giving back more important than rich list: Hill|work=The Southland Times|publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|date=24 July 2008|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> claiming that "It is my dream that New Zealand will one day become a much more balanced society with not just wonderful sport – but also wonderful classical music."<ref name="mhivc pr">{{cite press release|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0906/S00137.htm|title=Josef Spacek Wins Michael Hill Violin Competition|publisher=Michael Hill International Violin Competition|date=12 June 2010|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> In 2004, the event became a member of the [[World Federation of International Music Competitions]].<ref name=wfimc /><ref name="mhivc pr" />
The event is held in [[New Zealand]], with the first two semi-final rounds of competition conducted in [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]] and the third and final rounds held in [[Auckland]].<ref name=mhivcgi>{{Cite web| title = Michael Hill International Violin Competition - 2011 Competition - General Information| url=http://www.michaelhillinternationalviolincompetition.com/index.php/pi_pageid/152| accessdate = 25 May 2010 }}</ref> There is a total prize pool of [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]100,000, with the winner receiving $40,000. In 2009, the events gained about $500,000 worth of sponsorship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/czech-violinist-wins-michael-hill-competition-103656|title=Czech violinist wins Michael Hill competition|work=[[National Business Review]]|first=John|last=Daly-Peoples|date=12 June 2009|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref>
Special guests at the competition have included [[Prime Minister of New Zealand]] [[Helen Clark]],<ref name="FengNing">{{cite web|url=http://www.tourdates.co.uk/news/5960-feng-ning-wins-michael-hill-international-violin-competition|title=Feng Ning wins Michael Hill International Violin Competition|work=tourdates|date=14 June 2005|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> and [[Ministry for Culture and Heritage|Minister for Arts, Culture and Heritage]] [[Chris Finlayson|Christopher Finlayson]].<ref name="mhivc pr" />
==Laureates== '''2001''' # [[Joseph Lin]], USA # Tatiana Samouil, Russia # Alexandra Osborne, Australia
'''2003''' # Natalia Lomeiko, Russia<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0306/S00033.htm|title=Russia Born NZ-Citizen Wins Violin Competition|publisher=Auckland Philharmonia|date=9 June 2003|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> # Kristian Winther, Australia # Korbinian Altenberger, Germany
'''2005''' # Feng Ning, China<ref name="FengNing" /> # Yvonne Lam, USA # [[Bartosz Woroch]], Poland
'''2007''' # Bella Hristova, Bulgaria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/auckland-philharmonia/news/article.cfm?o_id=500473&objectid=10444722&ref=bebo|title=Michael Hill International Violin Competition Final Round at Auckland Town Hall|first=William|last=Dart|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=11 June 2007|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> # Yuuki Wong, Dominica # Stefan Hempel, Germany
'''2009''' # [[Josef Špaček (violinist)|Josef Špaček]], Czech Republic<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lakesleisure.co.nz/events/E113-Michael-Hill-International-Violin-Competition.html|title=Michael Hill International Violin Competition|work=Lakes Leisure|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10578116 |title=''Review:'' Michael Hill International Violin Competition|first=William|last=Dart|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=19 June 2009|accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref> # Yoo Jin Jang, South Korea # Danbi Um, South Korea # Tessa Lark, USA # David McCarroll, USA # Dami Kim, South Korea
'''2011''' # [[Sergey Malov (musician)|Sergey Malov]], Russia # Richard Lin, Taiwan # Xiang Yu, China # [[Nadir Khashimov]], Uzbekistan # Eric Silberger, USA # Stefani Collins, USA
'''2013''' # Nikki Chooi, Canada # Sarah Christian, Germany # Boson Mo, Canada # Wonyoung Jung, South Korea # Ioana Cristina Goicea, Romania # Natalie Lin, New Zealand
'''2017''' # Ioana Cristina Goicea, Romania # Luke Hsu, USA # Benjamin Baker, New Zealand # Olga Šroubková, Czech Republic # Sumina Studer, Switzerland # Kunwha Lee, South Korea
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.michaelhillinternationalviolincompetition.com Michael Hill International Violin Competition]

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = RADARSAT Constellation | names_list = <!--list of previous names if the spacecraft has been renamed. Include the dates applicable if possible, and separate each name with a linebreak. Omit if the spacecraft has only ever been known by one name. Do not include Harvard, COSPAR/NSSDC or SATCAT/NORAD/NASA designations as alternative names-->
<!--image of the spacecraft/mission--> | image = <!--omit the "file" prefix--> | image_caption = <!--image caption--> | image_alt = <!--image alt text--> | image_size = <!--include px/em; defaults to 220px-->
<!--Basic details--> | mission_type = [[Earth observation satellite]]s | operator = [[Canadian Space Agency]] | COSPAR_ID = <!--spacecraft launched since 1963 only (aka NSSDC ID; eg. 1998-067A)--> | SATCAT = <!--satellite catalogue number, omit leading zeroes (e.g. 25544)--> | website = {{url|http://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/radarsat/default.asp}} | mission_duration = 7 years (each satellite))<ref name='specs'/>
<!--Spacecraft properties--> | spacecraft = <!--Spacecraft name/serial number (eg. Space Shuttle ''Discovery'', Apollo CM-118), etc--> | spacecraft_type = <!--eg. GPS Block II, Kobalt-M, US-K, etc--> | spacecraft_bus = Canadian SmallSat Bus<ref name='specs'/> | manufacturer = [[MacDonald Dettwiler]] | launch_mass = 1,400 kg (total mass of the 3 satellites)<ref name='specs'>[http://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/radarsat/radarsat-tableau.asp Satellite characteristics]. RADARSAT Mission. Canadian Space Agency.</ref> | BOL_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit at beginning of operational life, after LEOP phase--> | dry_mass = <!--spacecraft mass in orbit without fuel--> | payload_mass = <!--Mass of cargo carried by spacecraft (eg. for Space Shuttle), or total mass of instrumentation/equipment/experiments for mission--> | dimensions = <!--body dimensions and solar array span--> | power = <!--end-of-life power, in watts--> <!--Launch details--> | launch_date = 18 February 2019<ref name='RCM launch'/> <!--{{start-date|DATE, TIME}} [[UTC]]--> | launch_rocket = [[Falcon 9]] | launch_site = <!--Where the rocket launched from, including complex and pad; do not include the full address or country--> | launch_contractor = [[SpaceX]]
<!--orbit parameters--> <!--as science-related articles, SI units should be the principal units of measurement, however we usually use {{convert}} to display imperial units in parentheses after the initial values--> | orbit_reference = <!--geocentric, selenocentric, etc - please link (e.g. [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]])--> | orbit_regime = [[sun-synchronous orbit]] <!--high, low, medium, molniya, GSO - please link (e.g. [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] - please don't use acronyms--> | orbit_longitude = <!--geosynchronous satellites only--> | orbit_slot = <!--Designation of orbital position or slot, if not longitude (e.g plane and position of a GPS satellite)--> | orbit_semimajor = <!--semimajor axis--> | orbit_eccentricity = <!--orbital eccentricity--> | orbit_altitude = 586-615 km | orbit_periapsis = <!--periapsis altitude--> | orbit_apoapsis = <!--apoapsis altitude--> | orbit_inclination = 97.74° <ref name='specs'/> | orbit_period = 96.4 min | orbit_RAAN = <!--right ascension of the ascending node--> | orbit_arg_periapsis = <!--argument of perigee/periapsis--> | orbit_mean_anomaly = <!--mean anomaly at epoch, only use in conjunction with an epoch value--> | orbit_mean_motion = <!--mean motion of the satellite, usually measured in orbits per day--> | orbit_repeat = <!--repeat interval/revisit time--> | orbit_velocity = <!--speed at which the spacecraft was travelling at epoch - only use for spacecraft with low orbital eccentricity--> | orbit_epoch = <!--the date at which the orbit parameters were correct--> | orbit_rev_number = <!--revolution number--> | apsis = <!--planet specific apsis term (eg. gee/helion/selene/etc - defaults to generic "apsis")-->
<!--transponder parameters--> | trans_band = [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] | trans_frequency = 5.405 GHz | trans_bandwidth = 100 MHz | trans_capacity = <!--capacity of the transponders--> | trans_coverage = <!--area covered--> | trans_TWTA = <!--TWTA output power--> | trans_EIRP = <!--equivalent isotropic power--> | trans_HPBW = <!--half-power beam width-->
<!--Only use where a spacecraft/mission is part of a clear programme of sequential missions. If in doubt, leave it out--> | programme = | previous_mission = | next_mission =
<!--mission insignia or patch--> | insignia = <!--omit the "file" prefix--> | insignia_caption = <!--image caption--> | insignia_alt = <!--image alt text--> | insignia_size = <!--include px/em; defaults to 180px--> }} {{about|the upcoming satellite mission|the older satellite program|RADARSAT}} The '''RADARSAT Constellation Mission''' ('''RCM''') is a three-spacecraft fleet of [[Earth observation satellite]]s by the [[Canadian Space Agency]]. With satellites smaller than [[RADARSAT-2]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdacorporation.com/news/pr/pr2006031301.html|title=MDA Starts Work on Next Generation Satellite Constellation|accessdate=2006-09-03}}</ref> the RCM will provide new applications—made possible through the [[Fractionated spacecraft|constellation approach]]—as well as continuing to provide [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[radar]] data to [[RADARSAT-2]] users.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sm.mdacorporation.com/what_we_do/radarsat_con.html|title=MDA Space Missions - What We Do - Satellite Missions - RADARDAT Constellation Mission|accessdate=2006-09-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222132444/http://sm.mdacorporation.com/what_we_do/radarsat_con.html|archivedate=2007-02-22|df=}}</ref> Improvements include more frequent area coverage of [[Canada]] and reduced risk of a service interruption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aero-news.net/index.cfm?printable=1&ContentBlockID=6907f502-a7d5-48c0-acfa-535c21ee801d&|title=Canada To Build, Launch Three More Satellites|accessdate=2006-09-03}}</ref>
The launch of the three satellites that will form the constellation is scheduled for February 18, 2019.<ref name='RCM launch'>{{cite web |url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/blog/2018/10/16/radarsat-constellation-a-major-milestone-reached.asp |title=RADARSAT Constellation: A major milestone reached |date=October 16, 2018 |access-date=October 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=pietrobon>{{cite web |title=United States Commercial ELV Launch Manifest |url=http://www.sworld.com.au/steven/space/uscom-man.txt |first=Steven |last=Pietrobon |date=August 23, 2018 |access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref> Manufacturer [[MacDonald, Dettwiler and Associates|MDA]] contracted the launch to [[SpaceX]] with a [[Falcon 9]] rocket.<ref>{{cite web|title=SpaceX Awarded Launch Reservation Contract for Largest Canadian Space Program|url=http://www.spacex.com/press/2013/07/30/spacex-awarded-launch-reservation-contract-largest-canadian-space-program|accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>
==Overview==
The RADSARAT Constellation Mission (RCM) includes three identical Earth observation satellites. The prime contractor on the project is [[MacDonald Dettwiler|MacDonald Dettwiler and Associates]] and it was designed for three main uses:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=19340|title=COM DEV to Participate in Canada's New RADARSAT Constellation Mission|accessdate=2006-09-03}}</ref><ref>[http://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/radarsat/what-is-rcm.asp RADARSAT - Main applications]. Canadian Space Agency. </ref> *Maritime surveillance (ice, surface wind, oil pollution and ship monitoring) *Disaster management (mitigation, warning, response and recovery) *Ecosystem monitoring (agriculture, wetlands, forestry and coastal change monitoring)
Its [[synthetic aperture radar]]s (SAR) have a mass of 400 kg each, and a resolution of 1 × 3 m.<ref name='specs'/>
==See also==
* [[RADARSAT]] * [[Technological and industrial history of Canada]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/radarsat/default.asp RADARSAT Constellation Mission - Canadian Space Agency]
{{Canadian Space Agency}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Radarsat Constellation}} [[Category:Earth observation satellites of Canada]] [[Category:Space synthetic aperture radar]] [[Category:2019 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Future SpaceX commercial payloads]]
