revision.text:
[[File:Red Bull BC One Logo.jpg|thumbnail|Red Bull BC One Logo]] '''Red Bull BC One''' is an annual international [[B-boying|B-Boy]] competition organized by the energy drink company [[Red Bull]]. It is an individual B-Boy competition, notable for being the only one of the major [[International B-Boy Championships|international breaking championships]] to not include a crew event. The main event is a [[knockout tournament]] featuring sixteen B-Boys, chosen for exceptional skills in the dance and good character, competing in one-on-one battles decided by a panel of five judges. Regional Finals are held for [[Red Bull BC One North American Finals|North America]], [[Red Bull BC One Eastern European Finals|Eastern Europe]], [[Red Bull BC One Western European Finals|Western Europe]], [[Red Bull BC One Latin American Finals|Latin America]], [[Red Bull BC One Asia Pacific Finals|Asia Pacific]], and [[Red Bull BC One Middle East Africa Finals|Middle East & Africa]]. The winners of each region go on and participate in the World Finals. The inaugural BC One was held in [[Biel]], Switzerland in 2004.
An official Red Bull BC One [[DVD]] was released for the 2004 and 2005 events. The production of the DVDs has been criticized due to musical rights, as the live music played during the competition had to be dubbed over.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Red-Bull-One-Breakdancing-Championship/dp/B000GW8S06 Amazon.com reviews for Red Bull BC One 2005 DVD], Retrieved August 17, 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.bboyworld.com/forum/video-song-lists/42541-red-bull-bc-one-2005-a.html BBoyWorld.com forum song list thread for Red Bull BC One 2005 DVD] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002522/http://www.bboyworld.com/forum/video-song-lists/42541-red-bull-bc-one-2005-a.html |date=2007-09-28 }}, Retrieved August 17, 2007</ref> From 2006 and on, Red Bull stopped releasing DVDs and made the videos available online for free.<ref>[http://redbullbcone.com/blog/we-read-your-comments Red Bull BC One], Retrieved November 19, 2009</ref>
In 2007, Alastair Siddon directed a film about the Red Bull BC One 2007 competition. The film was released in March 2010 under the title, "Turn it Loose."
Since 2014, Red Bull BC One partnered up with the [[World BBoy Series]] and helped create [[World BBoy Series|Undisputed]], an event to crown the solo world bboy champion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://freestylesession.com/blog/?page_id=65 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109203802/http://freestylesession.com/blog/?page_id=65 |archivedate=2013-11-09 |df= }} Retrieved November 9, 2013</ref>

== 2018 == {{main|2018 Red Bull BC One}} In 2004, the first Red Bull BC One Cypher went down at the cultural centre La Coupole in [[Biel]]. Fourteen years later, the world's most prestigious breaking battle goes back to [[Switzerland]]. This time, the [[Hallenstadion]] in northern [[Zurich]] will host the clash of the world's best breakers, on September 29, 2018.

== 2017 == {{main|2017 Red Bull BC One}} 2017 Red Bull BC One was held in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] on November 4, 2017. This time around, BC One hopefuls go head-to-head in over 35 qualifying cyphers and six camps to determine who makes the Amsterdam cut. The three-day camps will be held in Spain, Russia, France, Turkey, Japan, and Netherlands, reflecting the local creative landscape with lectures, workshops, art exhibitions, club nights and battles. All the winners will earn the chance to compete for the last open spot, just days before the hugely anticipated World Final gets broadcast to the world. Ayumi made history as the first B-girl in history to compete in Red Bull BC One.
'''Judges:''' * {{flagicon|USA}} Crazy Legs ([[Rock Steady Crew]]) * {{flagicon|KOR}} Hong 10 (Drifterz / 7 Commandoz) * {{flagicon|NED}} Niek (The Ruggeds) * {{flagicon|UKR}} Intact (Ruffneck Attack) * {{flagicon|FIN}} AT (Flow Mo)

== 2016 == {{main|2016 Red Bull BC One}} In 2016, Red Bull BC One will hold camps around the world that will feature traditional cyphers. It will no longer hold the six regional finals from previous years. Camps will be held in Austria, France, South Africa, Italy, Japan, and Ukraine. The winners of each cypher will compete in a Last Chance Cypher to qualify to the World Finals.<ref>[http://www.redbullbcone.com/en/about/press/big-changes-2016/ Big Changes on the Horizon for 2016] Retrieved January, 2016</ref> The winners of Last Chance Cypher will battle in Nagoya alongside fifteen Wild Card entries, chosen by an international team of B-Boy experts. Red Bull BC One World Finals 2016 will take place in [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], Japan on December 3. This also happened to be the final BC One that would feature Taisuke, as he announced his retirement from this competition. Meanwhile, Issei's victory meant that he would be the first Japanese champion of Red Bull BC One.

== 2015 == {{main|2015 Red Bull BC One}} On November 14, Red Bull BC One World Finals, the most iconic global B-Boy competition, will take place in the Eternal City, in Rome’s Palazzo dei Congressi. Throughout the year, over 70 cyphers took place around the globe. Sixteen of each country’s best B-Boys went head-to-head for the chance to represent at six regional Finals in Georgia, the United States, Peru, South Korea, Spain and Egypt. The winners of these finals will battle in Rome alongside ten Wild Card entries, chosen by an international team of B-Boy experts.<ref>[http://www.redbullbcone.com/en/battles/red-bull-bc-one-world-final-italy-2015] Retrieved November 11, 2015</ref>

After winning Red Bull BC One, the last event of the [[World BBoy Series]], '''Victor''' ({{flagicon|USA}}) earned a triple pass to [[World BBoy Series#World BBoy Series 2015|Undisputed]]. }}
== 2014 == {{main|2014 Red Bull BC One}} Red Bull BC One took place in Paris, France. In 2014, Red Bull BC One utilized a round-by-round judging system used by [[International B-Boy Championships#Undisputed|Undisputed]]. The round-by-round judging format allows bboys to see the judges decision after every round. The battle is set for 3 rounds (Finals is 5) but can end if a bboy beats his opponent in 2.<ref>[http://www.thebboyspot.com/judging-format-at-undisputed-world-bboy-series-events/] Retrieved November, 2014</ref> However, this judging system received a lot of criticism from Red Bull BC One fans throughout social media following the event. Bboys and fans alike, both disagreed heavily with the judges's decisions after many individual battles. Many argued that it was the worst Red Bull BC one competition since its initiation. Due to '''Menno''' ({{flagicon|NED}}) winning Red Bull BC One and Chelles Battle Pro, '''Gravity''' ({{flagicon|USA}}) was awarded the final spot at [[International B-Boy Championships#Undisputed|Undisputed]] at the end of the year following Red Bull BC One.

== 2007 == For 2007, qualifiers were held in May and June in 10 countries: [[Algeria]], France, Japan, Germany, [[Brazil]], [[South Africa]], United States, Sweden, [[Taiwan]], and Russia. The winner from each of these 9 events, along with 4 [[Wild card (sports)|wild card]] entries and the top 3 finishers from last year's 2006 main event, are the final 16 for the 2007 main event. However, two of the breakdancers – '''Baek''' ({{flagicon|KOR}}), a [[Wild card (sports)|wild card]] selection, and '''Niek''' ({{flagicon|NED}}), who won the Germany qualifier – had to withdraw from the competition due to injury.<ref>[http://www.redbullbcone.com/blog/39/2007-09-18 Welcome to South Africa!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921100205/http://www.redbullbcone.com/blog/39/2007-09-18 |date=2007-09-21 }}, [http://www.redbullbcone.com Red Bull BC One Official Site], Retrieved September 18, 2007</ref> They were replaced by B-boys '''Cico''' ({{flagicon|ITA}}) and '''Jed''' ({{flagicon|RSA}}).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.redbullbcone.com/blog/41/2007-09-19 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929080949/http://www.redbullbcone.com/blog/41/2007-09-19 |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}, [http://www.redbullbcone.com Red Bull BC One Official Site], Retrieved September 18, 2007</ref>

==Red Bull BC One All Stars== Red Bull BC One All Stars is a crew of thirteen internationally renowned dancers, representing the best of the best in the scene. Together, they showcase the art of B-Boying in all of its many forms. Each of the 14 B-Boys has competed in the Red Bull BC One, the world’s most important one-on-one B-Boy battle.
They serve as ambassadors of Hip Hop culture, with their main goal of giving back to the community and sharing their wealth of experience and skills with the younger generation of dancers. They travel the world to teach workshops, judge competitions and, of course, battle, continually challenging and pushing the limits of B-Boying.
Each crewmember is an outstanding individual in his community, bringing a certain style, skillset and original movement to the group, from hardcore power moves to intricate footwork. New members are chosen by the existing crewmembers, and one new member is added every year.<ref>http://www.redbullbcone.com/en/b_boys/red-bull-bc-one-all-stars/</ref>
Red Bull BC One All Stars is not a just collected crew, but still as a real crew that battling worldwide. Some notable achievements are as follows: *All in All Battle at IBE 2012 *Winner of 2v2 Battle at [[Outbreak Europe]] 2015 (Roxrite & Menno) *Winner of 3v3 Battle at Renegade Rockers 32nd Anniversary 2015 (Roxrite, Neguin, Menno) *Winner of Crew Battle at [[UK B-Boy Championships]] 2016 *Semi-Finalist of 2v2 Battle De Vaulx 2016 (Hong 10 & Taisuke) *Finalist of 2v2 World Bboy Classic 2016 (Hong 10 & Ronnie) *Finalist of Crew Battle at [[Chelles Battle Pro|Toulouse Battle Pro]] 2017 *Winner of 3v3 Need For Dance 2017 (Lil G, Hong 10, Menno) *Winner of 2v2 Battle De Vaulx 2017 (Menno & Wing) *Winner of 3v3 Battle at Floorlords 36th Anniversary 2017 (Roxrite, Victor, Menno) *Winner of Seven All Star 2 Smoke at [[The Notorious IBE]] 2017 *Finalist of Crew Battle at Bucheon Bboy International Championship (BBIC) 2017 *Winner of 2v2 LCB "Choose Your Destiny" 2017 (Taisuke & Issei) *Winner of 3v3 Undisputed 2018 (Roxrite, Neguin, Victor) *Winner of Crew vs Crew Circle Industry 2018 (Roxrite, Taisuke, Victor, Menno, Junior) *Winner of 3v3 HIP OPsession 2018 (Hong 10, Wing, Ronnie) *Winner of Crew Battle Legits Blast Winter 2018 *Winner of 4v4 SCAPE Radikal Forze Jam 2018 (Victor, Wing, Menno) *Winner of 2v2 Battle De Vaulx 2018 (Victor & Roxrite) *Winner of 2v2 [[Freestyle Session]] 2018 (Hong 10 & Wing)

{{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Rockwave Festival | image = [[File:Rockwave2009.jpg|200px]] | caption = Terra Stage, Rockwave Festival, 2009 | imagesize = 200px | location = [[Terra Vibe Park|TerraVibe Park]], [[Malakasa]], Greece | years_active= 1996–present | dates = June–July | genre = [[Alternative rock]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Heavy metal music|metal]], [[Pop music|pop]] | website = [http://www.rockwavefestival.gr www.rockwavefestival.gr] }} '''Rockwave Festival''' is a [[rock festival]] that takes place in [[Malakasa]], [[Greece]], near [[Athens]]. It is one of the most famous [[music festival]]s in Greece. The festival's history begins in 1996, but its popularity has spread since 2004. Along with the names they introduced the changes in the festival's whole structure. The festival is now divided in two stages, "Terra" stage and "Vibe" stage (that comes by the name of the event park "TerraVibe"). Τhey also abolished the division of the "Terra" concert area into gates PL1 and PL2, lowered the high price of the tickets and retained the special area that is on the side of the field, where there is more comfort, as there are places to sit. {| class="wikitable" | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Terra Stage''' |- !Tuesday 8 July !Wednesday 9 July !Thursday 10 July |- |valign="top" align="center" width=200| '''[[The Offspring]]'''

'''Spring Thing''' is an annual competition to highlight works of text adventure games and other literary works, also known as [[Interactive Fiction]].
[[Adam Cadre]], author of several works of [[Interactive Fiction]], including ''[[Photopia]]'' and ''[[Varicella (computer game)|Varicella]]'', announced the Spring Thing in 2001, both to promote works that would be longer than those entered into the [[Interactive Fiction Competition]], and to encourage authors to submit works to the general public during other times of the year. It was run in 2002 and 2003, but Cadre did not host it the following year. [[Greg Boettcher]] picked up the slack, and hosted the Spring Thing from 2005 until 2013. As of 2014 it was run by [[Aaron A. Reed]].
As with the better-known Interactive Fiction Competition, works submitted to the Spring Thing must be released as [[freeware]] or [[public domain]]. Unlike that competition's limit of two hours per work, judges may spend as much time as necessary with an entry in the Spring Thing.
== List of winners to date == *2002: Tinseltown Blues by [[Chip Hayes]] - the sole entrant in that year *2003: Max Blaster and Doris de Lightning Against the Parrot Creatures of Venus by Dan Shiovitz and [[Emily Short]] *2004: ''No competition'' *2005: Whom the Telling Changed by Aaron A. Reed *2006: De baron / The Baron by Victor Gijsbers *2007: Fate by Victor Gijsbers *2008: Pascal's Wager by Doug Egan *2009: A Flustered Duck by [[Jim Aikin]] *2010: ''No entrants'' *2011: The Lost Islands of Alabaz by Michael Gentry *2012: The Rocket Man from the Sea by Janos Honkonen *2013: Witch's Girl by Mostly Useless *2014: The Price of Freedom: Innocence Lost by Briar Rose *2015: Toby's Nose by Chandler Groover (Audience Choice and Alumni's Choice) *2016: Tangaroa Deep by Astrid Dalmady (Audience Choice), The Xylophoniad by Robin Johnson (Alumni's Choice)
==See also== *[[XYZZY Award]] *[[Interactive Fiction Competition]]
==External links== *[http://www.springthing.net Spring Thing Home Page]
[[Category:Interactive fiction]] [[Category:Video game development competitions]]

revision.text:
{{tone|date=September 2017}} {{Primary sources|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox Website | name =TechCrunch | logo =TechCrunch logo.svg | logo_size =200px | screenshot = | website = {{url|techcrunch.com|TechCrunch.com}} | commercial =Yes | location =[[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]], United States | type =Technology news and analysis | language =English, Chinese, French, Japanese | registration =None | owner =[[AOL]] (2010–2017)
[[Oath Inc.]] (2017–present) | author =[[Michael Arrington]], [[Keith Teare]] | editor = Matthew Panzarino | launch date ={{start date and age|2005|6|10}}{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/techcrunch.com|title=TechCrunch.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools|work=[[WHOIS]]|date= |accessdate=2016-08-23}} | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 668 ({{as of|2017|06|10|alt=June 2017}})[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/techcrunch.com TechCrunch] | current status=Active | revenue=[[United States dollar|US$]]2.4 million (2007 est.){{cite web | url=https://www.wired.com/2007/06/ff-arrington/ | title=TechCrunch Blogger Michael Arrington Can Generate Buzz … and Cash | author=Fred Vogelstein | publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date=June 22, 2007 | quote=Revenue from advertising, job listings, and sponsorships now totals about $200,000 a month}} }} '''TechCrunch''' is an [[United States|American]] online [[publisher]] of technology industry news founded in 2005 by Archimedes Ventures whose partners were [[Michael Arrington]] and [[Keith Teare]].{{cite web|last1=Arrington|first1=Michael|title=The Real History of TechCrunch|url=https://uncrunched.com/2018/02/18/the-real-history-of-techcrunch/|publisher=Michael Arrington|accessdate=19 February 2018}} It reports on the business of tech, tech news, analysis of emerging trends in tech, and profiling of new tech businesses and products. ==History== TechCrunch was founded in June 2005 by Archimedes Ventures - the Partners were [[Michael Arrington]] and [[Keith Teare]]. In 2010, [[AOL]] acquired the company for approximately $25 million.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/29/aol-buys-techcrunch|title=AOL buys TechCrunch|last=Sweney|first=Mark|date=2010-09-29|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-01-26}} ===Controversy=== A scandal erupted over the [[Titstare]] application, created by participants in a [[hackathon]] at Disrupt 2013.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/09/titstare-app-women-tech-sexism|title='Titstare' app at Techcrunch: women in tech deserve better | Amy Gray | Comment is free|date=2013-09-08|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2014-08-10|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/techcrunch-forced-to-apologise-over-sydney-duos-titstare-app-20130909-2tflb.html|title=TechCrunch forced to apologise over Sydney duo's 'Titstare' app|author=Ben Grubb|date=|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=2014-08-10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2013/09/09/_titstare_app_at_techcrunch_disrupt_what_would_a_tech_conference_be_without.html|title=Titstare app at TechCrunch Disrupt: What would a tech conference be without the sexism?|last=Marcotte|first=Amanda|date=2013-09-09|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=2014-08-10}} In 2011, the site came under fire for possible ethics violations. These included claims that Arrington's investments in certain firms which the site had covered created a conflict of interest.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/05/business/media/michael-arringtons-audacious-venture.html|title=Michael Arrington's Audacious Adventure|author=David Carr|date=September 5, 2011|publisher=New York Times}} The controversy that ensued eventually led to Arrington's departure, and other writers, including [[Paul Carr (writer)|Paul Carr]] and [[Sarah Lacy]], followed suit.{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120116/sarah-lacy-debuts-new-tech-site-pandodaily-and-guess-whos-working-for-her-video/|title=Sarah Lacy Debuts New Tech Site, PandoDaily — $2M+ in Funding and Guess Who’s Working for Her?|author=Kara Swisher|date=January 16, 2012|publisher=AllThingsD}}{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/techcruncher-quits-slams-new-editor-techcrunch-134926|title=TechCruncher Quits, Slams New Editor—On TechCrunch|author=Anthony Ha|date=September 16, 2011|publisher=[[AdWeek]]}} ==Products== ===TechCrunch Disrupt=== First held in 2011, TechCrunch Disrupt is an annual tech conference hosted by TechCrunch in [[San Francisco]],{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/events/disrupt-sf-2011/ | title=The first TechCrunch Disrupt San Francisco}} [[New York City]],{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/events/disrupt-ny-2011/ | title=The first TechCrunch Disrupt New York}} and Europe ([[London]] or [[Berlin]]),{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/events/disrupt-eu/ |title=Disrupt Europe |year=2014 |publisher=TechCrunch |accessdate=2017-10-06}} with one 2011 conference held in [[Beijing]].{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/disrupt-beijing-2011/|title=Full coverage of Disrupt Beijing 2011|last=Wood|first=Stephen|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2018-01-05}} TechCrunch Disrupt hosts an event called Startup Battlefield at its conferences where [[startups]] sign up to pitch their business ideas on a stage in front of [[venture capital]] investors, media and other interested parties for prize money and publicity. Past participants include [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]],{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/dropbox/|title=Dropbox|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09}} Beam,{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/11/beam-wins-techcrunch-disrupt-ny-2016/|title=And the winner of TechCrunch Disrupt NY 2016 is… Beam|last=Dillet|first=Romain|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}} [[Snap Inc.|Vurb]],{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/vurb/|title=Vurb|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09}} [[Trello]],{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/trello/|title=Trello|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09}} Mint,{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/11/aaron-patzer-founder-of-mint-has-unfinished-business-with-ai/|title=Aaron Patzer, founder of Mint, has unfinished business with AI|last=Butcher|first=Mike|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}} [[Yammer]],{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/yammer/|title=Yammer|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09}} and [[CrateDB|Crate.io]].{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/startup-battlefield/crate-io/|title=Crate.IO|website=TechCrunch|language=en|access-date=2017-12-09}} ==={{visible anchor|Crunchbase}}=== From 2007 to 2015, TechCrunch operated [[Crunchbase]], a database of the startup ecosystem, consisting of investors, incubators, start-ups, key people, funds, funding rounds and events.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} The company claims to have more than 50,000 active contributors on its platform.{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/03/14/mention-800k-seed/|title=With 50,000 Users & Double-Digit Monthly Revenue Growth, French Real-Time Alerts Startup Mention Raises $800K Flash Seed|last=Lomas|first=Natasha|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}} Subject to registration, members of the public can make submissions to the database; however, all changes are subject to review by a moderator before being accepted.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} In 2013, Crunchbase claimed to have 2 million users accessing its database each month.{{cite web | title=CrunchBase, People+, and the EFF | url=https://about.crunchbase.com/2013/11/crunchbase-people-and-the-eff/ |accessdate=2013-12-07 | publisher=CrunchBase}} AOL is in dispute with start-up Pro Populi over that group's use of the entire Crunchbase dataset in apps that Pro Populi has developed, one of which is known as People+. Pro Populi is being represented by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]].{{cite web | title=AOL Smacks Startup for Using CrunchBase Content It Gave Away | url=https://www.wired.com/2013/11/aol-crunchbase-cc-flap/ | accessdate=2013-12-07 | publisher=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] | date=November 5, 2013}} In 2015, Crunchbase spun out of AOL/Verizon/TechCrunch to become a private entity, and is no longer a part of TechCrunch.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/22/aolverizon-completes-spinout-of-crunchbase-funded-by-emergence-capital/ |title=AOL/Verizon Completes Spinout Of CrunchBase Funded By Emergence Capital |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2015-09-22 |accessdate=2017-12-16}} ===Crunchies=== In 2008, TechCrunch started The [[Crunchies]] award ceremony, which celebrates the "most compelling startups, internet and technology innovations of the year".{{cite web |title=Crunchies 2014 |url= https://techcrunch.com/events/7th-annual-crunchies-awards-2/event-info/ |publisher=TechCrunch |access-date=5 April 2017}} Techcrunch often creates a list of the top startups and the funding they received. Twelve categories have been awarded in 2016, including "Best New Startup", "Best Overall Startup", and "Best Mobile App".{{cite web |title=9th Annual Crunchies Awards |url=https://techcrunch.com/event-info/9th-annual-crunchies-awards/ |publisher=TechCrunch |access-date=5 April 2017}} 2016 was also the first year awarding the Diversity Award.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/02/05/meet-the-people-vying-for-the-first-ever-diversity-crunchie-award/|title=Meet The People Vying For The First-Ever Diversity Crunchie Award {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Dickey|first=Megan Rose|access-date=2017-05-25}} ==Public personal== TechCrunch has more than 10.07 million followers on [[Twitter]],{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/techcrunch|title=TechCrunch (@TechCrunch)|work=[[Twitter]]}} and more than 2.8 million likes on [[Facebook]] as of February 2018.{{cite web | url=https://www.facebook.com/techcrunch | title=TechCrunch | work=Facebook}} In 2014, TechCrunch Disrupt was featured in an arc of the [[HBO]] series ''[[Silicon Valley (TV series)|Silicon Valley]]''.{{cite news|url=http://observer.com/2014/06/silicon-valley-fact-check-hbo-nails-techcrunch-disrupt-all-the-way-down-to-the-nametags/|title=‘Silicon Valley’ Fact Check: HBO Nails TechCrunch Disrupt All the Way Down to the Nametags|website=Observer.com|author=Jack Smith IV|date=June 2, 2014}} The characters' startup "Pied Piper" participates on a startup battle at TechCrunch Disrupt. ==Available languages== TechCrunch is currently available in [[English language|English]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]] (managed by TechNode),{{cite web | author=Ned Desmond | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/05/techcrunch-returns-to-china-for-keeps/ | title=TechCrunch Returns To China, For Keeps, COO of TechCrunch and CrunchBase and General Manager of AOL Tech}} and [[Japanese language|Japanese]].{{cite web | author=Iwamoto Yutaira | url=https://japan.cnet.com/article/35024508/ | title=TechCrunch Tokyo 2012, CNet Editor}} It had a French edition, which was folded into{{clarify|date=November 2016}} TechCrunch.com.{{cite web | author=Mike Butcher | url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/31/techcrunch-france-integrates-with-techcrunch-com/ | title=TechCrunch France Integrates With TechCrunch.com}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website}} * [https://techcrunch.com/events/ TechCrunch Events] * [http://www.crunchbase.com Crunchbase] * [https://techcrunch.com/tag/deadpool/ DEADPOOL] {{Oath Inc.}} [[Category:AOL]] [[Category:Blogs]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2005]] [[Category:American news websites]] [[Category:Technology blogs]] [[Category:Technology conferences]] [[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:Webby Award winners]] [[Category:Internet companies]] [[Category:Web-related conferences]] [[Category:2005 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:2010 mergers and acquisitions]]
