revision.text:
{{short description|American neo-Nazi, white supremacist, and Holocaust denial commentary and message board website}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Good article}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox website | name = '''''The Daily Stormer''''' | logo = Daily_Stormer.png | logo_size = 234px | logo_caption = logo | logo_alt = The Daily Stormer logo | screenshot = | screenshot_size = <!-- default 300px --> | caption = | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | url = {{URL|https://dailystormer.name}} {{as of|2018|2|3|df=US}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Andrew Anglin|url=https://hatreon.net/Anglin/|website=Hatreon|accessdate=February 3, 2018|language=en}}</ref> | commercial = No | type = [[Alt-right]], [[Neo-Nazism|Neo-Nazi]] news, commentary, message board | registration = Required to comment | language = [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Greek language|Greek]] | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = Andrew Anglin | launch_date = {{start date and age|2013|7|4|df=no}} | revenue = | alexa = {{increase}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/dailystormer.name 17,252] (Global October 2018) | ip = | current_status = | footnotes = | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | programming_language = }} {{Antisemitism}} {{Neo-fascism}}
'''''The Daily Stormer''''' is an American [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]], [[White supremacy|white supremacist]], and [[Holocaust Denial|Holocaust denial]] commentary and message board website that advocates for the [[genocide]] of [[Jews]].<ref name=mill>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/06/us/white-supremacists-extend-their-reach-through-websites.html|title=White Supremacists Extend Their Reach Through Websites|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Wines, Michael|date=July 5, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name="lat" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/neo-nazi-holocaust-denial-legal-defense_us_5a612a5ce4b0125fd6354368|title=American Neo-Nazi Is Using Holocaust Denial As A Legal Defense|last=O'Brien|first=Luke|date=January 19, 2018|work=[[HuffPost]]|access-date=April 25, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/12/the-making-of-an-american-nazi/544119/|title=The Making of an American Nazi|last=O'Brein|first=Luke|date=December 2017|website=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=April 4, 2018|quote=(As Anglin would later write, the official policy of his site was: “Jews should be exterminated.”)}}</ref> It considers itself a part of the [[alt-right]] movement.<ref name=voice>{{cite news|last1=Gallo|first1=William|title=What is the 'Alt-Right'?|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/hillary-clinton-attacks-donald-trump-alt-right-ties/3481117.html|accessdate=September 18, 2016|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=August 25, 2016}}</ref> Its editor, Andrew Anglin, founded it on July 4, 2013, as a faster-paced replacement for his previous website ''Total Fascism''.
The site is known for its use of [[Internet meme]]s, which have been likened to the imageboard [[4chan]] and cited as attractions for a younger and more ideologically diverse audience.<ref name=beast/> While some [[white nationalism|white nationalist]] authors have praised ''The Daily Stormer''{{'}}s reach, others have taken issue with its content and tone, accusing Anglin of being an [[agent provocateur]], used to discredit true white nationalism.<ref name="salon">{{cite news|last1=Hankes|first1=Keegan|title=White nationalism’s exploding civil war|url=http://www.salon.com/2014/10/23/white_nationalisms_exploding_civil_war_partner/|accessdate=March 4, 2015|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=October 23, 2014}}</ref>
''The Daily Stormer'' orchestrates what it calls the "Troll Army", which is involved in [[Internet troll]]ing of figures with whom Anglin disagrees politically. In August 2017, after causing outrage by insulting the victim of [[Charlottesville car attack|a car-ramming homicide]] at the far-right [[Unite the Right rally]], the website was rejected by several [[domain name registrar|domain registrar]]s.
== Management == ===Andrew Anglin===
Andrew Anglin was born on July 27, 1984, and grew up near [[Columbus, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anglin|first1=Andrew|title=I was Born in 1984|url=https://andrewanglinblog.wordpress.com/2017/08/25/i-was-born-in-1984/|accessdate=August 25, 2017|publisher=Andrew Anglin Blog|date=August 25, 2017}}</ref><ref name="o'brien"/> According to both Anglin and his childhood classmates, he was [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] as a youth.<ref name="o'brien"/><ref name=vocativ/> He attended the [[Linworth Alternative Program]] and the [[Worthington Christian High School]] from 1999 to 2003, where he was remembered as a dreadlocked [[vegan]].<ref name=alive>{{cite news|last1=Oliphint|first1=Joel|last2=Downing|first2=Andy|title=The White Nationalist from Worthington|url=http://www.columbusalive.com/entertainment/20170208/white-nationalist-from-worthington|accessdate=February 23, 2017|publisher=Columbus Alive|date=February 8, 2017}}</ref> His friends in high school report that his behavior changed during his sophomore year at Linworth, where he exhibited [[self-harm]]ing behavior, and began promoting conspiracy theories.<ref name="o'brien"/> After high school, Anglin took classes at [[Columbus State Community College]] in 2003, and studied English at [[Ohio State University]] for one semester in 2004.<ref name="o'brien"/><ref name=alive/>
In 2006 Anglin launched a [[conspiracy theory]] website, ''Outlaw Journalism'', which was modeled after the works of [[Alex Jones]] and [[Hunter S. Thompson]], whom Anglin admired.<ref name="o'brien">{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=Luke|title=The Making of an American Nazi|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/12/the-making-of-an-american-nazi/544119/|accessdate=November 20, 2017|work=The Atlantic|date=December 2017}}</ref>
In 2008, after posting on ''Outlaw Journalism'' that the only way for humanity to survive was to return to a hunter-gatherer lifestyle, Anglin began traveling around [[Southeast Asia]], eventually ending up in [[Davao City]], in the [[Philippines]]. In 2011, he spent several weeks with a [[Tboli people|Tboli]] village in southern [[Mindanao]], where he initially intended to stay permanently, selling some of his possessions to raise money for a dowry to marry two local Muslim women.<ref name="o'brien"/> In 2012, Anglin wrote that he found the locals to be "a civilized, non-aggressive and industrious people" but he eventually came to consider them too "primitive", became lonely and only wanted to associate with members of his own [[Race (human categorization)|race]], and "By the Grace of God, I found Adolf Hitler".<ref name=alive/>
In 2012, Anglin launched another website, Adventure Quest 2012, which discussed conspiracy theories such as the existence of [[Reptilian humanoid|reptilian humanoids]]. He described the aim of the site as seeking to "mend the wounds produced by modern society ... and [help] the reader transcend these physical bonds and reach total ascendancy. To mend these wounds, the world must learn to embrace diversity and color."<ref name=alive/> In 2014, he stated that although he agreed with the central tenets of [[Nazism]], he had reservations over reintroducing all aspects of Hitler's regime.<ref name=vocativ/> A self-proclaimed "troll", Anglin stated that he was introduced to Nazism on [[4chan]].<ref name=eye>{{cite news|last1=Hankes|first1=Keegan|title=Eye of the Stormer|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2017/eye-stormer|accessdate=October 12, 2017|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=February 9, 2017|quote="I had always been into 4chan as I am at heart a troll...This is about the time /new/ [a particular 4chan board] was going full Nazi, and so I got into Hitler..."}}</ref> Later in 2012, he launched his first neo-Nazi website, ''Total Fascism''.<ref name=vocativ /> Feeling that ''Total Fascism'' was not appealing to a younger demographic and had articles that were too long, Anglin launched ''The Daily Stormer'' on July 4, 2013, with shorter articles and a more provocative style.<ref name=vocativ>{{cite news|last1=Dixon Kavanaugh|first1=Shane|title=The Man Bringing Back the Nazi Movement in America|url=http://www.vocativ.com/usa/race/man-bringing-back-nazi-movement-america/|publisher=[[Vocativ]]|date=March 20, 2014}}</ref> Anglin said in March 2014 he spends 70 hours a week writing for the website.<ref name=vocativ/>
Anglin's location is not known. An investigative article by ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' in November 2016 analyzed his social media and FBI sources, and concluded that he was living in Germany. Rumors have also claimed that he is residing in Russia.<ref name=alive/> In July 2017, Anglin told [[CNN]] he was residing in [[Lagos]], Nigeria.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Simon|first1=Mallory|last2=Sidner|first2=Sara|title=This mom became the target of a neo-Nazi troll storm|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/07/10/us/avalanche-of-hate-daily-stormer-lawsuit/index.html|accessdate=August 6, 2017|work=CNN|date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC) lists the site as being headquartered in [[Worthington, Ohio]], with activity in several other states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hate Map|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hate-map|website=Southern Poverty Law Center|accessdate=November 21, 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.press-citizen.com/story/news/local/amana-clear-creek/2017/08/28/splc-removes-amana-hate-group-map/610471001/|title=SPLC removes Amana from hate group map|author=Brian Rathjen|date=August 28, 2017|publisher=Iowa City Press-Citizen (USA Today Group)}}</ref> The website is registered in the name of Anglin's father Greg, who runs a Christian-inspired counseling service in Worthington.<ref name=splc/>
=== Finances === ''The Daily Stormer'' is primarily funded through donations which Anglin solicits regularly from site visitors.<ref name=splc>{{cite news|last1=Beirich|first1=Heidi|title=Blog Wars: ''The Daily Stormer'' and its Racist Frenemies|url=http://www.splcenter.org/blog/2015/03/11/blog-wars-the-daily-stormer-and-its-racist-frenemies/|accessdate=April 21, 2015|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|date=March 11, 2015}}</ref> His father was protested against by [[Anti-Racist Action]] for receiving donations from the site's readers to pass on to his son.<ref name=alive/> In February 2017, the website announced a corporate sponsor—Smerff Electrical, owned by Simon Hickey of [[Brisbane]], Australia,<ref name=alive/> whose website contains images of alt-right meme [[Pepe the Frog]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Notorious Neo-Nazis Claim They Have A ‘Corporate Sponsor’|url=http://www.vocativ.com/399501/neo-nazis-corporate-sponsor/|accessdate=February 23, 2017|publisher=Vocativ|date=February 8, 2017}}</ref> Anglin told [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']] that he received donations from [[Silicon Valley]], and that [[Santa Clara County, California]] was the largest source of traffic to his website.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Harkinson|first1=Josh|title=Meet Silicon Valley's Secretive Alt-Right Followers|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/03/silicon-valley-tech-alt-right-racism-misogyny|accessdate=March 26, 2017|work=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=March 10, 2017}}</ref>
The site is believed to have received over $200,000 in [[Bitcoin]] contributions since it began accepting the cryptocurrency in 2014.<ref name=Memoria>{{cite web|url=https://www.cryptocoinsnews.com/114574-2/|title=This Twitter Bot Monitors Neo-Nazi Bitcoin Donations|author=Francisco Memoria|date=August 30, 2017|publisher=Cryptocoins News}}</ref> A current [[cryptocurrency wallet]] has consistently kept approximately $80,000 in Bitcoin on hand.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cointelegraph.com/news/neo-nazi-bitcoin-transactions-made-public-by-twitter-bot|publisher=The Coin Telegraph|author= Jon Buck|title=Neo-Nazi Bitcoin Transactions Made Public by Twitter Bot}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://blockchain.info/address/16JAUnuvxQ6BdfX4DwsEVTWgd3a8oitu8h?sort=0|title=Bitcoin address}} (Crytocoins News and Coin Telegraph link to this Bitcoin wallet)</ref> Money entering and being spent by the accounts is publicly tracked by a Twitter bot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/paax7z/this-twitter-bot-tracks-neo-nazi-bitcoin-transactions|title=This Twitter Bot Tracks Neo-Nazi Bitcoin Transactions|publisher=Motherboard|date=August 29, 2017}}</ref> A Twitter account for the ''Stormer'' announced that [[Coinbase]] was deleting accounts of persons attempting to send Bitcoin to them;<ref name=Memoria /> Coinbase stated in general terms that it "prohibits use of an account which would abuse, harass, threaten, or promote violence against others".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/vbbb5y/can-the-bitcoin-community-stop-neo-nazis-from-using-the-digital-currency|title=Can the Bitcoin Community Stop Neo-Nazis From Using the Digital Currency?|date=August 18, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=November 2, 2017}}</ref> On August 20, 2017, for example, Anglin received a donation of 14.88 bitcoin (a reference to [[Fourteen Words]]). At the time, it was worth $60,000, but had Anglin kept the entire amount it would have been worth about $235,000 by the end of the year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/bitcoins-boom-is-a-boon-for-extremist-groups/2017/12/26/9ca9c124-e59b-11e7-833f-155031558ff4_story.html |title=Bitcoin’s boom is a boon for extremist groups |first=Craig |last=Timberg |date=December 26, 2017 |newspaper=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref>
''The Daily Stormer'' is run through a company called Moonbase Holdings, with Anglin saying that he chose the name so that donors could avoid scrutiny from their credit card companies. The company made $3,400 per month on the alt-right crowdfunding website [[Hatreon]], which ceased operations in February 2017. In his defamation lawsuit against Anglin, Muslim American radio personality [[Dean Obeidallah]] requested that Moonbase Holdings be scrutinized to find any other individuals related with the company.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barrouquere|first1=Brett|title=Show me the money: Lawyers in libel lawsuit seek to examine finances of Andrew Anglin’s company and Daily Stormer|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2018/03/29/show-me-money-lawyers-libel-lawsuit-seek-examine-finances-andrew-anglin%E2%80%99s-company-and-daily|accessdate=April 2, 2018|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
==Content and reception== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 133-075, Worms, Antisemitische Presse, "Stürmerkasten".jpg|thumb|''The Daily Stormer'' is named for the Nazi tabloid ''[[Der Stürmer]]'', known for its antisemitic caricatures. This 1934 billboard for ''Der Stürmer'' reads "With ''Der Stürmer'' against Judea. The Jews are our misfortune".|alt=Black and white historical photograph of several men, some with Nazi armbands, reading a newspaper billboard.]] ''The Daily Stormer'' takes its name from the [[Nazi Party]]'s tabloid newspaper ''[[Der Stürmer]]'',<ref name=mill/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gerhardt|first1=Christina|title=Google Image, The Daily Stormer And Anti-Semitism|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/google-image-the-daily-stormer-and-anti-semitism_us_5844815ce4b0b93e10f8e352|accessdate=December 24, 2016|work=The Huffington Post|date=December 4, 2016}}</ref> known for its virulently [[antisemitic]] caricatures of Jews.<ref name=iceland/> Its publisher, [[Julius Streicher]], was executed after the Second World War for [[crimes against humanity]].<ref name=iceland/>
The SPLC described the site as "the newest up and comer in the heated competition to rule the hate web", which "has in the last six months [up to March 2015] often topped the oldest and largest hate site on the web, [[Stormfront (website)|Stormfront]], in terms of [[Reach (advertising)|reach]] and [[page view]]s, based on [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] data".<ref name="splc" /> Anglin claimed in May 2016 that the website's traffic had doubled over the last six months, peaking at 120,000 daily visitors.<ref name=secret/> The website is part of the [[alt-right]] movement, and it calls itself "The World’s Most Visited Alt-Right Website". As the movement made headlines in mid-2016, "bolstered in part by the unexpected rise of [[Donald Trump]] and [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|Britain's decision to leave the European Union]]", Anglin declared: "We won the meme war; now we've taken over the [[Republican Party (United States)|GOP]], and we did this very, very quickly."<ref name=voice/> Unlike other figures such as [[Milo Yiannopoulos]], Anglin does not play down the extremist elements in the alt-right, stating that: "The goal is to ethnically cleanse White nations of non-Whites and establish an authoritarian government. Many people also believe that the Jews should be exterminated".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hankes|first1=Keegan|title=Whose Alt-Right Is It Anyway?|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2016/08/25/whose-alt-right-it-anyway|accessdate=September 18, 2016|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=August 25, 2016}}</ref>
===Content and style=== Anglin asserts that the purpose of ''The Daily Stormer'' is to provide "a means to propagandize people … to get them to look at the world in a certain way".<ref name="vocativ" /> Headlines include "All Intelligent People in History Disliked Jews", and "Adolf Hitler: The Most Lied About Man of All Time".<ref name=splc/> The site bills itself as "America's #1 Most-Trusted Republican News Source".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/commentary/2016/11/22/scale-one-goebbels-scared-richard-spencer-white-nationalists | title = On a scale of one to Goebbels, how scared should we be of Richard Spencer? | work = Dallas News | author = Robert Wilonsky | date = November 22, 2016 | accessdate = December 12, 2016 }}</ref> According to ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'', ''The Daily Stormer'' "posts hundreds of racist articles targeting black people, Arabs and Jews".<ref name="thejc">{{cite news|last1=Dysch|first1=Marcus|title=Neo-Nazi gave out internet abuse tips in campaign against Luciana Berger|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/124917/neo-nazi-gave-out-internet-abuse-tips-campaign-against-luciana-berger|accessdate=March 4, 2015|work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]]|date=October 30, 2014}}</ref> The website offers pro-[[Novorossiya (confederation)|separatist]] coverage of the [[War in Donbass|conflict in Eastern Ukraine]], which Anglin considers "the correct moral position".<ref name="vocativ" />
The SPLC stated that ''The Daily Stormer'' owed its success to the online [[imageboard]] [[4chan]] becoming popular among racists, as both websites use similar [[Internet meme|memes]] and rhetorical styles.<ref name="splc" /> One meme the website has used is to overlay photographs of [[Taylor Swift]] with anti-Semitic quotations, including those by Hitler.<ref name="hankes">{{cite news|last1=Hankes|first1=Keegan|title=How the extremist right hijacked ‘Star Wars,’ Taylor Swift and the Mizzou student protests to promote racism|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2016/01/05/how-extremist-right-hijacked-%E2%80%98star-wars%E2%80%99-taylor-swift-and-mizzou-student-protests-promote|accessdate=January 16, 2016|publisher=Southern Poverty Law center|date=January 5, 2016}}</ref> The website puts [[triple parentheses]] around the names of Jews, a far-right meme created by fellow website [[The Right Stuff (blog)|The Right Stuff]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Menegus|first1=Bryan|title=What Happened With That Anti-Semitic Chrome Extension? [Updated]|url=https://gizmodo.com/what-happened-with-that-anti-semitic-chrome-extension-1780420435|accessdate=June 6, 2016|publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|date=June 3, 2016}}</ref> Jacob Siegel of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' wrote that the website was growing in popularity amongst a younger audience due to its use of humor, and was attracting activists of other anti-[[political correctness]] ideologies—such as [[Gamergate controversy|Gamergaters]], [[Men's rights movement|men's rights activists]] and opponents of [[Social Justice Warrior]]s—who would not usually identify with fascism.<ref name="beast">{{cite news|last1=Siegel|first1=Jacob|title=Dylann Roof, 4chan, and the New Online Racism|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/06/29/dylann-roof-4chan-and-the-new-online-racism.html|accessdate=June 30, 2015|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=June 22, 2015}}</ref> The SPLC has also documented Anglin's involvement in and encouragement of [[culture jamming]] by making hyperbolic statements in fake online accounts as women and minorities.<ref name=hankes/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rashid|first1=Neha|title=The Emergence Of The White Troll Behind A Black Face|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2017/03/21/520522240/the-emergence-of-the-white-troll-behind-a-black-face|accessdate=March 26, 2017|publisher=NPR|date=March 21, 2017}}</ref> He has also said that "ridiculous" statements such as "gas the [[kike]]s", if repeated in media coverage, can work to desensitize the public to the Holocaust.<ref name="hankes" /> He also believes that his extreme right-wing rhetoric can [[Normalization (sociology)|normalize]] less extreme right-wingers such as Trump.<ref name=ncrm/> In December 2017, ''The Huffington Post'' leaked Anglin's 17-page style guide for the website, which included the guideline that articles must be so extremely hyperbolic that readers would be unsure whether the content is parody.<ref name=yorker>{{cite news|last1=Marantz|first1=Andrew|title=Inside The Daily Stormer's style guide|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/01/15/inside-the-daily-stormers-style-guide|accessdate=April 2, 2018|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Weevilicious.jpg|thumb|Hacker [[weev]] announced his conversion to Neo-Nazism on ''The Daily Stormer''.|alt=Portrait of a young man with long dark hair, stubble, spectacles and a white baseball cap]]
The [[hacker]] and [[Internet troll]] known as "[[weev]]" (Andrew Alan Escher Auernheimer), wrote an article on the website after his release from prison in October 2014, espousing his recent conversion to Neo-Nazism and his opposition to Jews who had built "an empire of wickedness the likes the world has never seen".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Howell O'Neill |first1=Patrick |title=The fall of hacker-troll Andrew ‘weev’ Auernheimer |url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/weev-hates-jewish-people/ |accessdate=November 8, 2018 |work=The Daily Dot |date=October 2, 2014}}</ref> [[Fredrick Brennan]], founder of the online community [[8chan]], wrote an article on ''The Daily Stormer'' encouraging [[eugenics]], based on his own experiences of having [[brittle bone disease]].<ref name="Courier">{{cite news|url=http://www.diplomaticourier.com/news/topics/security/2499-when-the-internet-breeds-hate|title=When the Internet Breeds Hate|last=Herzog|first=Chrizella|date=March 8, 2015|work=[[The Diplomatic Courier]]|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> Florida-based Jewish troll [[Joshua Ryne Goldberg]], who encouraged a 2015 [[Curtis Culwell Center attack|attack on a free speech exhibition]] in [[Garland, Texas]], under the alias of a Muslim extremist, wrote white supremacist articles for ''The Daily Stormer'' under the pseudonym Michael Slay.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Potaka|first1=Elise|title=Unmasking a troll: Aussie 'jihadist' Australi Witness a 20-year-old American nerd|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/unmasking-a-troll-aussie-jihadist-australi-witness-a-20yearold-american-nerd-20150909-gjil47.html|accessdate=September 28, 2015|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=September 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Zavadski|first1=Katie|title=‘Terrorist’ Troll Pretended to Be ISIS, White Supremacist, and Jewish Lawyer|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/09/11/terrorist-troll-pretended-to-be-isis-white-supremacist-and-jewish-lawyer.html|accessdate=June 4, 2016|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=September 11, 2015}}</ref> ''The Daily Stormer'' accepts freelance work and pays $14.88 per article.<ref name=yorker/> The second most prolific writer on the website goes by the pseudonym "Zeiger" and was unmasked in 2018 by the ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' as Gabriel Sohier Chaput, an IT consultant from [[Rosemont–La Petite-Patrie]], Quebec.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Curtis|first1=Christopher|title=Exclusive: Major neo-Nazi figure recruiting in Montreal|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/major-neo-nazi-figure-recruiting-in-montreal|accessdate=May 17, 2018|work=Montreal Gazette|date=May 4, 2018}}</ref>
''The Daily Stormer'' attracted media coverage when the SPLC stated that white supremacist spree killer [[Dylann Roof]]—who on June 17, 2015, shot nine [[African Americans]] to death in the [[Charleston church shooting]]—may have made several comments on the site. The SPLC found similarities between one user's comments and Roof's manifesto.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Kurtis|title=Dylann Roof's manifesto resembles comments on neo-Nazi website, analysis finds|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-dylann-roof-web-20150622-story.html|accessdate=June 30, 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 22, 2015}}</ref> ''The Daily Beast'' stated that Anglin "repudiated Roof's crime and publicly disavowed violence, while endorsing many of Roof's views".<ref name=beast/> In October of that year, Anglin gave a positive reaction to an attempted assassination on [[Henriette Reker]], a [[Immigration to Germany|pro-immigration]] candidate to be mayor of the German city of [[Cologne]], decrying her as a "feminist hag".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Beirich|first1=Heidi|title=Thomas Mair, BREXIT, and the US-UK neo-Nazi Connection|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2016/06/21/thomas-mair-brexit-and-us-uk-neo-nazi-connection|accessdate=June 24, 2016|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|date=June 21, 2016}}</ref>
In May 2017, weev set up the first non-English version of ''The Daily Stormer'', ''El Daily Stormer'' in Spanish. It is focused on news related to white nationalism in [[Spain]] and [[Latin America]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kunzelman|first1=Michael|title=Leading neo-Nazi website courts new readers… in Spanish|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/leading-neo-nazi-website-courts-new-readers-in-spanish/|accessdate=August 23, 2017|work=The Times of Israel|publisher=Associated Press|date=May 16, 2017}}</ref>
===Support for Donald Trump=== [[File:Donald Trump Laconia Rally, Laconia, NH 4 by Michael Vadon July 16 2015 19.jpg|thumb|alt=Trump speaking behind a brown wooden podium, wearing a dark blue suit and a red tie. The podium sports a blue "TRUMP" sign.|''The Daily Stormer'' endorsed Donald Trump's [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]] in 2016.]] Anglin officially endorsed Donald Trump for president in 2015. Anglin encouraged the website's readers to "vote for the first time in our lives for the one man who actually represents our interests".<ref name=crystal/> The website also received national and international coverage for its endorsement of Trump's proposal of a temporary moratorium on admitting foreign Muslims into the country; it proclaimed "Heil Donald Trump – ''The Ultimate Savior''".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kaplan|first1=Rebecca|title=Donald Trump's endorsers still with him after proposed Muslim entry ban|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/donald-trump-endorsers-still-with-him-after-proposed-muslim-ban/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=December 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Troup Buchanan|first1=Rose|title=Donald Trump gets support from neo-Nazi group after call to ban Muslims entering US|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/donald-trump-backed-by-neo-nazi-group-after-calls-to-ban-muslims-entering-us-a6764426.html|accessdate=December 24, 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=December 8, 2015}}</ref> According to the SPLC, white supremacist endorsement of Trump is unprecedented, as the movement is generally skeptical of all politicians.<ref name=tribune/> In July 2016, Andrew Anglin and ''The Daily Stormer'' were mentioned by [[Lacy Clay]], Democratic Representative from Missouri, as he asked in a congressional hearing whether FBI director [[James Comey]] was aware of Trump sharing Twitter posts by white supremacists.<ref>{{cite news|title=Democratic congressman hijacks hearing to ask FBI director about Trump retweeting white supremacists|url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/james-comey-donald-trump-white-genocide-2016-7|accessdate=July 8, 2016|publisher=Business Insider|date=July 7, 2016}}</ref> <!--This was the first website mentioned specifically in congress since the [[Silk Road (marketplace)|Silk Road]].--> Anglin wrote in July 2016 that he believed that Trump was a pragmatic anti-Semite who praised Israel to win votes from evangelical Christians, while dropping subtle hints about purported Jewish domination of rival [[Hillary Clinton]]'s campaign.<ref name=tribune>{{cite news|last1=Weigel|first1=David|title=Trump draws rebuke for his tweet with an image of Clinton and a Star of David|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-clinton-star-of-david-20160703-story.html|accessdate=July 4, 2016|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=July 3, 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' journalist Jessica Schulberg compared how white nationalists like Anglin and former Ku Klux Klan leader [[David Duke]] believed Trump to be representative of their ethnic interests, while at the same time several Jews believed him to be representative of theirs.<ref name=secret>{{cite news|last1=Schulberg|first1=Jessica|title=Trump’s Neo-Nazi And Jewish Backers Are Both Convinced He’s Secretly On Their Side|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-neo-nazis-jews_us_5747397be4b0dacf7ad4480e|accessdate=June 24, 2016|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref>
In ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', Trump supporter Crystal Wright wrote that the candidate needed to separate himself from white nationalists such as ''The Daily Stormer'', who were endorsing him ahead of other politicians they deemed "[[cuckservative]]s" for holding more liberal positions.<ref name=crystal>{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Crystal|title=The white supremacists flocking to Donald Trump|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/donald-trump/11890531/The-white-supremacists-and-racists-flocking-to-Donald-Trump.html|accessdate=September 28, 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=September 25, 2015}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Atlantic]]'', Conor Friedersdorf theorized that modern academia's focus on race rather than "[[Color blindness (race) in the United States|color-blind]]" individualism was causing divisions and allowing white nationalist sites such as ''The Daily Stormer'' to gain an audience, and therefore become a "tiny but nevertheless alarming portion" of Trump's support.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Friesendorf|first1=Conor|title=The Left's Attack on Color-Blindness Goes Too Far|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/09/the-lefts-attack-on-color-blindness-goes-too-far/403477/|accessdate=September 28, 2015|work=[[The Atlantic (magazine)|The Atlantic]]|date=September 4, 2015}}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] writer Malcolm Harris analyzed the endorsement and predicted that a Trump presidency would strengthen organized racist groups and lead to civil war.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump’s immigration plan is a recipe for civil war|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2015/9/trumps-immigration-plan-is-a-recipe-for-civil-war.html|accessdate=September 30, 2015|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=September 8, 2015}}</ref>
After Trump won the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]], Anglin called on the site's readers to use non-violent intimidation to make "brown people" feel unwelcome in America,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dickerson|first1=Caitlin|title=Reports of Bias-Based Attacks Tick Upward After Election|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/12/us/reports-of-bias-based-attacks-tick-upward-after-election.html?_r=0|accessdate=November 13, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref> and to goad disappointed supporters of Clinton into committing suicide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hawkins|first1=Derek|title=‘Get some of them to kill themselves’: Popular neo-Nazi site urges readers to troll liberals into suicide|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/11/11/get-some-of-them-to-kill-themselves-popular-neo-nazi-site-urges-readers-to-troll-liberals-into-suicide/|accessdate=November 13, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
In response to the bombing of the Syrian government's [[2017 Shayrat missile strike|Shayrat Airbase in 2017]], ''The Daily Stormer'' was one of several alt-right outlets that criticized Trump. While Anglin alleged the president could be under control of a purportedly Jewish [[deep state]], weev said in a video on the website that he retained faith in Trump from his past actions.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kestenbaum|first1=Sam|title=The ‘Alt-Right’ Is Blaming The Jews For Trump’s Syria Airstrike|url=http://forward.com/news/368605/the-alt-right-is-blaming-the-jews-for-trumps-syria-airstrike/|accessdate=May 1, 2017|work=[[The Forward]]|date=April 7, 2017}}</ref>
===Reaction from white nationalists=== [[File:2008 Jared Taylor.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Jared Taylor criticized the tone of ''The Daily Stormer''.|alt=Photographic portrait of a smiling man outside]] White nationalist websites such as Stormfront and Counter-Currents have taken issue with what they see as [[low culture|lowbrow]] coverage on ''The Daily Stormer'', as well as Anglin's defense of Christianity and denunciation of the white supremacist group [[Christian Identity]].<ref name=splc/> Kyle Rogers of the [[Council of Conservative Citizens]] has also criticized the website for reprinting its material.<ref name=splc/> Anglin has also been criticized for his relationships with non-white women in the Philippines, and for his insults towards white women on his website.<ref name=alive/>
Colin Liddell of [[AlternativeRight.com]] has criticized Anglin's beliefs and tone. Liddell, who believes that stopping migration and encouraging higher birthrates is more important for preserving the [[white race]], condemned Anglin for writing that it was impossible for the race to survive without adopting his views on Jews, Hitler and the Holocaust.<ref name="salon" /> Liddell considered that Anglin was attracting [[poor white]]s with his provocative online persona in the same manner as [[monster trucks]] and [[professional wrestling]], writing that "it is hard not to conclude that Anglin is a paid [[shill]] and [[agent provocateur]], whose purpose is simply to infest and discredit White nationalism".<ref name=lat>{{cite news|last1=Pearce|first1=Matt|title=What happens when a millennial goes fascist? He starts up a neo-Nazi site|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-daily-stormer-interview-20150624-story.html|accessdate=August 22, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 24, 2015}}</ref> [[Jared Taylor]] of [[American Renaissance (magazine)|''American Renaissance'']] criticized ''The Daily Stormer''{{'s}} "extremely harsh, dismissive and insulting tone toward blacks", which he called unhelpful.<ref name=lat/>
Others, such as the [[Traditionalist Youth Network]], have praised ''The Daily Stormer'' for its reach and influence.<ref name=splc/> Anglin's extreme tone has led some white nationalists to suspect that he is an undercover Jew, an accusation he finds analogous to believing that Jewish [[LGBT]] activist [[Allen Ginsberg]] was an undercover Nazi.<ref name=ncrm/>
==Activities==
==="Troll Army"=== [[File:Luciana Berger by Emma Baum.jpg|thumb|upright|''The Daily Stormer'' targeted Luciana Berger, a British politician, through a trolling campaign.|alt=Photographic portrait of a young woman with long dark hair]] ''The Daily Stormer'' orchestrates what it calls a "Troll Army", involved in [[Internet trolling]].<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|last1=Whiteman|first1=Hilary|title=I will not be silenced: Australian Muslim fights Twitter 'troll army'|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/27/asia/australia-muslim-twitter-campaign/|accessdate=March 4, 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=February 28, 2015}}</ref> It came to attention in October 2014 in a campaign against British [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] politician [[Luciana Berger]], a Jewish Member of Parliament. A member of neo-Nazi group [[National Action (UK)|National Action]] had been sent to prison for sending her abusive messages over Twitter and ''The Daily Stormer'' encouraged its readers to send her antisemitic messages, as long as they did not promote violence.<ref name=thejc/> It also gave out guidelines on how to limit traceability and create anonymous e-mail and Twitter accounts.<ref name=thejc/> Berger said she received 400 abusive messages in one week.<ref name=thejc/> The abuse was brought up in the British Parliament, where Speaker [[John Bercow]] deemed it "beneath contempt".<ref>{{cite news|title=MP wants action over 'vitriolic' Twitter abuse of colleague|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-29821693|accessdate=March 4, 2015|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=October 29, 2014}}</ref> The Troll Army launched a campaign in February 2015 against [[Mariam Veiszadeh]], an [[Afghan Australian]] Muslim activist who demanded that a T-shirt bearing the [[Australian flag]] reading "If you don't love it, leave" be withdrawn from sale at [[F. W. Woolworth Company|Woolworths]]. A woman was arrested for sending her abusive messages, and Anglin interpreted Veiszadeh's actions as curbing [[freedom of speech]], which he believed "should be responded to with the most ridiculous conceivable hateful speech".<ref name=cnn/>
The "Troll Army" has also attacked right-wing conspiracy theorist [[Alex Jones]] for having a Jewish wife and not being anti-Semitic.<ref name=eye/> In November 2015, they took part in "Operation: Kikebart", targeting conservative news website [[Breitbart News]] for opening an office in Israel. The aim was to post so much anti-Semitic content in the comments section that it would be unfeasible to moderate. [[Disqus]], the comment platform used by websites including Breitbart, ended its service to ''The Daily Stormer'' as a result.<ref name=eye/> In 2016, ''The Daily Stormer'' took part in a Gamergate-related attempt to have [[Nintendo]] marketing officer Alison Rapp fired; Nintendo dismissed her and stated that it was unrelated to the controversy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stuart|first1=Keith|title=Nintendo denies Alison Rapp firing is linked to harassment campaign|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/31/nintendo-denies-alison-rapp-firing-is-linked-to-harassment-campaign|accessdate=April 26, 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=March 31, 2016}}</ref> Later that year, the site encouraged racially abusing [[Julia Ioffe]], a Russian-Jewish journalist who had written a piece on Trump's wife, [[Melania Trump]], in ''[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]'' magazine. Melania Trump and ''The Daily Stormer'' both found the piece too critical. Ioffe said that the abuse was unparalleled in her lifetime since leaving Russia to escape such prejudices 26 years earlier.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gambino|first1=Lauren|title=Journalist who profiled Melania Trump hit with barrage of antisemitic abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/28/julia-ioffe-journalist-melania-trump-antisemitic-abuse|accessdate=May 1, 2016|work=The Guardian|date=April 29, 2016}}</ref> In June, users of the website [[doxing|revealed the personal details]] of Erin Schrode, a Jewish woman running for Congress in California, and sent her Holocaust-related messages.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘Fire up the oven’: Neo-Nazis target Jewish candidate in California|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/fire-up-the-oven-neo-nazis-target-jewish-candidate-in-california/|accessdate=June 6, 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=June 5, 2016}}</ref>
The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] has opened a lawsuit against ''The Daily Stormer'' alleging it had invaded the privacy and caused "intentional infliction of emotional distress" upon Montana Jewish resident Tanya Gersh. The website initiated a "troll storm" in response to Gersh's alleged extortion of property belonging to the mother of white nationalist [[Richard B. Spencer]]. Gersh denies the allegations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ohlheiser |first1=Abby|title=The man behind the neo-Nazi Daily Stormer website is being sued by one of his ‘troll storm’ targets|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2017/04/18/the-man-behind-the-neo-nazi-daily-stormer-website-is-being-sued-by-one-of-his-troll-storm-targets/|accessdate=May 1, 2017|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]|date=April 18, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| last = Spencer| first = Sherry| title = Does Love Really Live Here?| url = https://medium.com/@recnepss/does-love-really-live-here-fff159563ba3| access-date = May 1, 2017}}</ref> The site crowdfunded $152,000 in legal fees from around 2,000 contributors and hired First Amendment lawyer [[Marc Randazza]], whose previous clients include 8chan and right-wing author [[Mike Cernovich]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kunzelman|first1=Michael|title=First Amendment lawyer defends neo-Nazi website publisher|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/first-amendment-lawyer-defending-neo-nazi-website-publisher/|accessdate=August 17, 2017|work=The Times of Israel|agency=Associated Press|date=June 10, 2017}}</ref> The suit ran into difficulties because of Anglin's secrecy over his location.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bowles|first1=Nellie|title=To Sue Founder of Daily Stormer, a Neo-Nazi Site, First He Must Be Found|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/20/technology/theyre-trying-to-sue-a-white-supremacist-first-he-must-be-found.html|accessdate=August 28, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=August 20, 2017}}</ref> In November, a federal judge rules that Gersh was not a public figure, that Anglin had intentionally incited his readers to [[Harassment|harass]] Gersh, and that such harassment was not protected as free speech.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zraick |first1=Karen |title=Neo-Nazis Have No First Amendment Right to Harassment, Judge Rules |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/15/us/daily-stormer-anti-semitic-lawsuit.html |accessdate=November 17, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=November 15, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
In August 2017, Muslim American radio presenter [[Dean Obeidallah]] sued ''The Daily Stormer'' in an Ohio federal court. Anglin had published fake images which purported to show Obeidallah celebrating the [[2017 Manchester Arena bombing]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burns|first1=Janet|title=Dean Obeidallah Is Suing The Daily Stormer Over Claim He Planned Manchester Bombing|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/janetwburns/2017/08/16/comedian-dean-obeidallah-is-suing-the-daily-stormer-over-claim-he-planned-manchester-attack/#34ed27cd28c2|accessdate=August 30, 2017|work=Forbes|date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> The lawsuits cleared a longstanding hurdle in March 2018, when U.S. Magistrate Judge Jeremiah Lynch declared that there was sufficient evidence of Anglin being domiciled in Ohio despite living abroad.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kunzelman|first1=Michael|title=Lawsuit against Neo-Nazi site's founder clears legal hurdle|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2018/03/22/lawsuit-against-neo-nazi-sites-founder-clears-legal-hurdle/448342002/|accessdate=April 2, 2018|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Cincinnati.com|date=March 22, 2018}}</ref> In July, the court found in Obeidallah's favor, with neither Anglin nor his representatives present in court.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Adely |first1=Hannan |title=Court sides with Paramus-born comedian in lawsuit against neo-Nazi website |url=https://eu.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/paramus/2018/07/03/court-sides-pacourt-sides-paramus-native-lawsuiramus-native-lawsuit-against-neo-nazi-website/756288002/ |accessdate=July 4, 2018 |publisher=North Jersey |date=July 3, 2018}}</ref>
Taylor Dumpson, the first black student body president at [[American University]], sued Anglin in May 2018 for organizing a racist and sexist trolling campaign against her.<ref>{{cite news|title=School’s First Black Student President was the Target of a Racist Attack. Now she’s Suing Over the ‘Troll Storm’ That Followed|url=http://fox40.com/2018/05/05/schools-first-black-student-president-was-the-target-of-a-racist-attack-now-shes-suing-over-the-troll-storm-that-followed/|accessdate=May 17, 2018|agency=CNN|publisher=Fox 40|date=May 5, 2018}}</ref>
=== Distribution of propaganda === In 2016, ''The Daily Stormer'' and the hacker weev jointly took credit for sending copies of a racist, anti-Semitic flier to thousands of publicly accessible, Internet-connected printers throughout the country, many of them at universities. The flier urged the reader to visit the website and accompany it "in the struggle for global white supremacy".<ref name="hacking">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2016/03/26/breaking-after-hack-neo-nazi-group-anti-semitic-fliers-appear-campus-printers|title=After Hack by Neo-Nazi Group, Anti-Semitic Fliers Appear on Campus Printers|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|date=March 26, 2016|accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref><ref name="weevfly">{{cite web|url=http://dailyprincetonian.com/news/2016/03/breaking-hacker-claims-responsibility-for-anti-semitic-messages-around-u-alleges-presence-of-white-supremacist-group-on-campus/|title=Hacker, white supremacist website claim responsibility for anti-Semitic messages around U|work=[[Daily Princetonian]]|date=March 25, 2016|accessdate=May 23, 2016|first=Amber|last=Park}}</ref> Anglin credited weev for the printer exploit, while one of ''The Daily Stormer'' crew composed the flier's text.<ref name="brief">{{cite web|url=https://storify.com/weev/a-small-experiment-in|title=A brief experiment in printing.|publisher=storify.com|accessdate=August 28, 2016}}</ref> On April 20 that year, Hitler's birthday, university printers in Germany were hacked to publish Nazi propaganda tracts including the website's name.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smale|first1=Alison|title=Printers at German Universities Mysteriously Churn Out Anti-Semitic Fliers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/23/world/europe/germany-anti-semitic-leaflets.html?_r=0|accessdate=April 26, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=April 22, 2016}}</ref> That same year, ''The Daily Stormer'' expanded its activities to establish 31 "clubs".<ref>Mark Potok, [https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2017/year-hate-and-extremism The Year in Hate and Extremism: 2017 Spring Issue], ''Intelligence Report'', Southern Poverty Law Center (February 15, 2017): "The Daily Stormer, the website whose chief came up with the term 'Our Glorious Leader' for Trump, expanded into real-world activism by starting 31 'clubs'."</ref>
''The Daily Stormer'' capitalized on the popularity of the [[augmented reality]] video game ''[[Pokémon Go]]'' in mid-2016 to distribute racist flyers to children congregating in public to play the game, with Anglin explaining that "I have long thought that we needed to get pre-teens involved in the movement. At that age, you can really brainwash someone easily. Anyone who accepts Nazism at the age of 10 or 11 is going to be a Nazi for life."<ref name=ncrm>{{cite news|last1=Medwed|first1=Robbie|title=Now the Alt-Right is Targeting Young Boys with Pokémon Nazi Challenge|url=http://www.thenewcivilrightsmovement.com/rjmedwed/alt_right_targets_young_boys_with_pok_mon_nazi_challenge|accessdate=September 18, 2016|publisher=The New Civil Rights Movement|date=September 12, 2016}}</ref> On May 3, 2017, one day after a deadly [[2017 University of Texas stabbing attack|stabbing attack]] at the [[University of Texas]], racist flyers were posted across campus with the website address for ''The Daily Stormer'', a caricature of a black person, and the line "... around blacks ... never relax!".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/updated-racist-flyers-found-say-around-blacks-never-relax/J0sDeYiBgauXj7oS3pWyUP/|title=UPDATED: Racist flyers found at UT say 'Around blacks ... never relax'|publisher=}}</ref>
== Site hosting issues after the 2017 Unite the Right rally == [[File:Memorial for Heather Heyer, H. Jay Cullen, and Berke M.M. Bates (36421689132).jpg|thumb|Memorial for Heather Heyer at the site of her death during the [[Unite the Right rally]]. Anglin's mocking of her death led to ''The Daily Stormer'' being removed by several [[domain registrar]]s.|alt=Floral tributes on an empty street]] ''The Daily Stormer'' helped organize the [[Unite the Right rally]], a far-right rally in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] on August 11 and 12, 2017, in which a counter-protester, Heather Heyer, was killed in [[Charlottesville car attack|a vehicular ramming]].<ref name=funeral>{{cite news|last1=Worley|first1=Will|title=Neo-Nazi website asks readers to target funeral of Heather Heyer who died in Charlottesville violence|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/america-top-neo-nazi-website-daily-stormer-orders-followers-harass-funeral-heather-heyer-victim-a7895496.html|accessdate=August 17, 2017|work=The Independent|date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> Weev also called for readers of ''The Daily Stormer'' to locate and attend Heyer's funeral, calling her a "fat skank".<ref name=funeral/> Both Anglin and weev deny that Heyer died from vehicular impact, claiming instead that she was killed by a weight-related heart attack.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kaplan|first1=Alex|title=Fringe media are furiously trying to absolve the white nationalist who allegedly killed Heather Heyer|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/blog/2017/09/08/Fringe-media-are-furiously-trying-to-absolve-the-white-nationalist-who-allegedly-killed-He/217886|accessdate=October 7, 2017|publisher=Media Matters for America|date=September 8, 2017}}</ref>
On August 13, the website was informed by its [[domain registrar]] [[GoDaddy]] that it had violated the terms of service by mocking Heyer, and Anglin was given 24 hours to locate a new registrar for the site.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/daily-stormer-being-dumped-by-godaddy-apparently-seized-by-anonymous/|title=Daily Stormer being dumped by GoDaddy|date=August 14, 2017|accessdate=August 14, 2017|publisher=[[CBS News]]}}</ref> The next day it moved to [[Google]] which almost immediately cancelled its registration for violation of terms,<ref>{{cite news|title=Google cancels Neo-Nazi site registration soon after it was dumped by GoDaddy|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/14/godaddy-boots-the-daily-stormer-because-of-what-it-wrote-about-charlottesville-victim.html|accessdate=August 14, 2017|agency=Reuters|publisher=CNBC|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> also terminating the website's [[YouTube]] account.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/08/15/neo-nazi-site-daily-stormer-deleted-google-godaddy/|title=Neo-Nazi site Daily Stormer deleted by Google and GoDaddy|work=The Telegraph|date=August 15, 2017|access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> The following day, the website registered with [[Tucows]], who canceled it hours later for regularly inciting violence.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ling|first1=Justin|title=Neo-nazi site The Daily Stormer moves to the darkweb, but promises a comeback|url=https://news.vice.com/story/neo-nazi-site-the-daily-stormer-moves-to-the-darkweb-but-promises-a-comeback|publisher=[[Vice News]]|date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> On August 15, it was announced by weev that the site had moved to the [[dark web]], and that it was now only accessible via [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]], while [[Facebook]] banned links to the site and [[Discord (software)|Discord]] banned its channel.<ref name="StormerVerge">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/8/15/16150668/daily-stormer-alt-right-dark-web-site-godaddy-google-ban |title=Neo-Nazi site moves to dark web after GoDaddy and Google bans |last=Robertson |first=Adi |date=August 15, 2017 |publisher = [[The Verge]] |access-date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> On August 16, [[Cloudflare]], the [[DNS]] provider and proxy service used to protect ''The Daily Stormer'' also terminated their service. Cloudflare had traditionally refused to terminate sites based on their content, but CEO Matthew Prince made an exception, posting a public announcement and explanation on the company blog.<ref>{{cite web |last=Conger |first=Kate |url=https://gizmodo.com/cloudflare-ceo-on-terminating-service-to-neo-nazi-site-1797915295 |title=Cloudflare CEO on Terminating Service to Neo-Nazi Site: 'The Daily Stormer Are Assholes' |publisher=Gizmodo |date=August 16, 2017 |accessdate=August 17, 2017}}</ref> ''The Daily Stormer'' now receives DDoS protection from a [[content distribution network]] set up in March 2017, BitMitigate. The company's founder, Nick Lim, said that he found ''The Daily Stormer'' to be "stupid" but believed in freedom of expression.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schweincke|first1=Ken|title=After bouncing around the Web, Daily Stormer lands a new CDN provider|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/08/spurned-by-major-firms-daily-stormer-returns-with-help-from-a-startup/|accessdate=August 30, 2017|publisher=Ars Technica|date=August 19, 2017}}</ref> Several [[Twitter]] accounts connected with ''The Daily Stormer'' were also suspended.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/daily-stormer-charlottesville-twitter-accounts-deleted-heather-heyer-funeral-a7897411.html |title=Twitter deletes Daily Stormer's accounts amid outrage at neo-Nazi site's response to Charlottesville |date=August 16, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |first=Andrew |last=Buncombe}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/zmygwj/twitter-just-suspended-accounts-linked-to-the-neo-nazi-website-daily-stormer |title=Twitter just suspended accounts linked to the neo-Nazi website Daily Stormer |first=Carter |last=Sherman |date=August 16, 2017 |newspaper=[[Vice News]]}}</ref>
On August 17, after a relocation to dailystormer[[.ru]], the Russian media watchdog [[Roskomnadzor]] requested a shutdown of the domain.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-40960053|title=Daily Stormer: Cloudflare drops neo-Nazi site|publisher=BBC News|date=August 17, 2017|access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref> ''The Daily Stormer'' briefly returned to the [[Clearnet (networking)|clearnet]] with a [[.lol]] [[gTLD]], dailystormer.lol, administered by [[Namecheap]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/spurned-by-major-companies-the-daily-stormer-returns-to-the-web|title=Spurned by Major Companies, The Daily Stormer Returns to the Web With Help From a Startup|first=Ken|last=Schwencke|date=August 18, 2017|website=[[ProPublica]]|archivedate=August 18, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170818220510/https://www.propublica.org/article/spurned-by-major-companies-the-daily-stormer-returns-to-the-web|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Far-right-groups-find-new-homes-on-the-Web-with-11943930.php|title=Far-right groups find new homes on the Web, with difficulty|first=Marissa|last=Lang|date=August 18, 2017|website=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> but after two days, Namecheap canceled the domain.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/08/20/the-daily-stormer-was-back-online-for-a-quick-second/|title=The Daily Stormer was back online for a quick second|last=Dillet|first=Romain|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date=August 20, 2017}}</ref> The company's CEO Richard Kirkendall stated that "the quality and context of the material, paired with the support for violent groups and causes passes from protected free speech into incitement", specifically quoting one published statement from ''The Daily Stormer'': "It doesn't take a Ph.D. in mathematics to understand that White men + pride + organization = Jews being stuffed into ovens."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.namecheap.com/inciting-violence-vs-freedom-speech/|title=Inciting Violence vs Freedom of Speech|first=Richard|last=Kirkendall|date=August 20, 2017|website=[[Namecheap]]|archivedate=August 20, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170820141838/https://blog.namecheap.com/inciting-violence-vs-freedom-speech/|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/08/unable-to-get-a-domain-racist-daily-stormer-retreats-to-the-dark-web/|title=Unable to get a domain, racist Daily Stormer retreats to the Dark Web|first=Timothy B.|last=Lee|date=August 22, 2017|publisher=[[Ars Technica]]}}</ref>
The site returned to the web as punishedstormer.com on August 24, hosted by [[DreamHost]], whose other far-right clients include [[National Vanguard (American organization)|National Vanguard]] and the [[Harold Covington|Northwest Front]]. [[Denial-of-service attack]]s from [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] caused intermittent outages for all of DreamHost's sites, including those unconnected to white supremacist ideology.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brandom|first1=Russell|title=The Daily Stormer switched addresses and got pushed off the web a second time|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/8/24/16200002/daily-stormer-dreamhost-anonymous-ddos-attack|accessdate=August 25, 2017|publisher=The Verge|date=August 24, 2017}}</ref> Within hours of the attack, DreamHost canceled the site's accounts for violating its terms of service, saying the host had already been kicked off the site years previously and was exploiting an automated sign-up process.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Timothy B.|title=DreamHost takes a beating after hosting racist Daily Stormer|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/08/dreamhost-takes-a-beating-after-hosting-racist-daily-stormer/|accessdate=December 9, 2017|work=Ars Technica|issue=24, August 2017|language=en-us}}</ref> Days later, ''The Daily Stormer'' was available under an Albanian [[.al]] [[ccTLD]], dailystormer.al.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Byrne|first1=Brian Patrick|title=Daily Stormer Whack-A-Mole Begins Again: Neo-Nazi Site Resurfaces Then Moves Back to GoDaddy [Now in Albania]|url=https://gizmodo.com/daily-stormer-whack-a-mole-begins-again-neo-nazi-site-1798396343|accessdate=August 30, 2017|publisher=Gizmodo|date=August 24, 2017}}</ref> Within four days, it was removed by registrar Host.al for breaking their content rules.<ref>{{cite news |last=Whittaker|first=Zack |date=August 30, 2017 |title=Albanian domain registrar kicks Neo-Nazi site Daily Stormer offline |publisher=ZDNet|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/another-domain-host-drops-neo-nazi-site-daily-stormer/ |access-date=August 31, 2017}}</ref> In September, ''The Daily Stormer'' was briefly registered with a [[.at]] address from Austria, but this was removed by registrar [[nic.at]] when local politicians complained.<ref>{{cite news|title=Austria domain name rejects neo-Nazi website Daily Stormer|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/austria-domain-name-rejects-neo-nazi-website-daily-stormer/|accessdate=September 15, 2017|work=The Times of Israel|date=September 12, 2017}}</ref> Later that month, it reappeared on a [[.is]] domain from Iceland, a country known for its freedom of speech; Anglin said that the recent collapse of the Nordic island's government meant that politicians would be distracted from affairs related to his website.<ref name=iceland>{{cite news|title=Neo-Nazi site finds home in Iceland|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-41323726|accessdate=September 20, 2017|publisher=BBC News|date=September 20, 2017}}</ref> Before the end of September, ISNIC pulled ''The Daily Stormer'' because Anglin refused its standard condition of disclosing his address, fearing that the information would be passed to law agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Andrew|title=The Daily Stormer, neo-Nazi website, loses Icelandic web address in latest domain spat|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/sep/29/daily-stormer-neo-nazi-website-loses-icelandic-web/?|accessdate=October 1, 2017|work=The Washington Times|date=September 29, 2017}}</ref> From September 21 to October 6, ''The Daily Stormer'' was hosted on a [[.cat]] domain, exclusively reserved for websites promoting Catalan language and culture. It exploited weakened filters after the Spanish government raided the offices of registrar Fundació puntCAT amidst a political crisis, and published several pieces in support of Catalan independence.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Redondo|first1=Mónica|title=‘The Daily Stormer’ consiguió hacerse con el dominio .cat|url=https://hipertextual.com/2017/10/the-daily-stormer-consiguio-hacerse-con-dominio-cat|accessdate=October 7, 2017|publisher=Hipertextual|date=October 6, 2017|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Jeffries|first1=Adrianne|title=The Daily Stormer just lost its new .cat domain|url=https://theoutline.com/post/2376/the-daily-stormer-just-lost-its-new-cat-domain|accessdate=October 7, 2017|publisher=The Outline|date=October 6, 2017}}</ref> In November 2017, ''The Daily Stormer'' was registered with a [[.hk]] domain from Hong Kong,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/infamous-neo-nazi-website-finds-safe-space-hong-kong-721963|title=American Neo-Nazi Website Linked to Praise of Terrorism Finds Safe Space in Hong Kong|work=Newsweek|date=November 24, 2017|accessdate=November 27, 2017}}</ref> which was revoked before the end of the month.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/11/27/embattled-us-neo-nazi-site-daily-stormer-finds-home-hong-kong-domain-registry-promises-review/|title=Embattled US neo-Nazi site The Daily Stormer finds a home in Hong Kong, as domain registry promises review|work=Hong Kong Free Press|date=November 27, 2017|accessdate=December 9, 2017}}</ref>
On November 29, 2017, the site returned to the clear web yet again with a new [[.red]] domain name, registered through GKG.net.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://geomovements.com/daily-stormer-returns-with-red-domain-b1b420dd3096|title=The Daily Stormer Returns With .RED Domain – GeoMovements|date=November 29, 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181117210931/https://www.whois.com/whois/dailystormer.red|title=Whois dailystormer.red|date=November 17, 2018|access-date=November 17, 2018}}</ref> The domain kept the website online until it was seized by the registrar. Hours after the domain was seized, the site was registered on a new .top website, through the same registrar they has previously used for .red.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/americanodyssey/the-daily-stormer-quickly-returns-to-the-clearnet-3dda7c2e9dd8|title=‘The Daily Stormer’ Quickly Returns to the Clearnet|last=X|first=Subcomandante|date=January 30, 2018|website=Medium|access-date=November 17, 2018}}</ref> The [[.top]] domain lasted just until February 2, 2018, when it was taken offline by the registrar. In February 2018, ''The Daily Stormer'' registered a new domain under the [[.name]] TLD with the Chinese-based internet company Eranet International Limited.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/americanodyssey/were-back-the-daily-stormer-returns-from-the-dark-web-9d1b933fd418|title=‘We’re back!’: The Daily Stormer Returns from the Dark Web|last=X|first=Subcomandante|date=February 3, 2018|website=Medium|access-date=November 17, 2018}}</ref>
===Reaction=== The domain blocking by Internet providers has raised questions regarding the implications of domain registrants policing the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2017/08/the_one_big_problem_with_godaddy_dropping_the_daily_stormer.html|title=GoDaddy Joins the Resistance|first=Will|last=Oremus|date=August 16, 2017|website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|archivedate=August 18, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170818193342/http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2017/08/the_one_big_problem_with_godaddy_dropping_the_daily_stormer.html|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/haroldfurchtgottroth/2017/08/16/daily-stormer-shows-up-hypocrisy-of-network-neutrality/|title=Daily Stormer Shows Us Hypocrisy Of Network Neutrality|first=Harold|last=Furchtgott-Roth|date=August 16, 2017|website=[[Forbes]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/08/fighting-neo-nazis-future-free-expression|title=Fighting Neo-Nazis and the Future of Free Expression|date=August 17, 2017|website=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]|archivedate=August 18, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20170818215148/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/08/fighting-neo-nazis-future-free-expression|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="verge-aug21">{{cite web|first=Adi|last=Robertson|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/8/21/16180614/charlottesville-daily-stormer-alt-right-internet-domain|title=Why the alt-right can’t build an alt-internet|date=August 21, 2017|website=[[The Verge]]}}</ref> The August 21 cancellation of [[The Rebel Media]]'s registration on 24 hours notice was compared to that of ''The Daily Stormer'', as both had provided coverage sympathetic to Charlottesville protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/canada/the-rebel-disrupted-as-it-loses-its-domain-provider/wcm/a35f68b6-b18e-4e66-b2bd-143412d56195|title=The Rebel disrupted as it loses its domain provider|publisher=National Post|date=August 21, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] acknowledged that the companies were within their legal rights to terminate their contracts with ''The Daily Stormer'', but that the move set a dangerous precedent in which other political views including left-wing ones could be denied legal protection.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/08/fighting-neo-nazis-future-free-expression|title=Fighting Neo-Nazis and the Future of Free Expression|date=August 17, 2017|website=Electronic Frontier Foundation|archivedate=August 18, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170818215148/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/08/fighting-neo-nazis-future-free-expression|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2017/08/18/blocking-neo-nazi-site-dangerous-warns-digital-rights-group-eff/580463001/|title=Blocking neo-Nazi site is 'dangerous,' warns digital rights group EFF|website=USA Today}}</ref> Several news outlets also published editorials discussing the free speech implications of the move.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2017/08/the_one_big_problem_with_godaddy_dropping_the_daily_stormer.html|title=GoDaddy Joins the Resistance - Activists got domain registries to pull the plug on the Daily Stormer. Could that come back to haunt them?|website=Slate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-hiltzik-daily-stormer-hate-20170817-story.html|title=Hate on the Web: Does banning neo-Nazi websites raise free-speech issues for the rest of us?|website=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/450669/white-supremacist-free-speech-ban-sets-dangerous-precedent|title=Journalists Overreach in Their Quest to Purge ‘Hate’ from the Web |website=National Review}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/08/23/545320833/unlikely-allies-join-fight-to-protect-free-speech-on-the-internet|title=Unlikely Allies Join Fight To Protect Free Speech On The Internet|website=National Review}}</ref>
As of August 17, ''The Daily Stormer'' had returned to the dark web on the Tor network. This prompted an announcement from the Tor project team that they were "disgusted" by the website—but that they were powerless to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/why-tor-project-refuses-censor-neo-nazi-websites-child-porn-drug-dealing-1635605|title=Why the Tor Project refuses to censor neo-Nazi websites, child porn and drug dealing|first=Jason|last=Murdock|date=August 18, 2017|website=[[International Business Times]]|archivedate=August 18, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170818195310/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/why-tor-project-refuses-censor-neo-nazi-websites-child-porn-drug-dealing-1635605|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-tor-project-is-disgusted-by-the-daily-stormer-but-cant-censor-it-2017-8|title=The Tor Project is 'disgusted' by the Daily Stormer – but can't censor it|first=Shona|last=Ghosh|date=August 18, 2017|website=[[Business Insider]]|archivedate=August 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170819015015/http://nordic.businessinsider.com/the-tor-project-is-disgusted-by-the-daily-stormer-but-cant-censor-it-2017-8?r=US&IR=T|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''[[Vice News]]'' noted that [[Stormfront (website)|Stormfront]] remained a client of Cloudflare; also (as echoed in commentary from a new blog by Andrew Anglin<ref>{{cite web|url=https://andrewanglinblog.wordpress.com/2017/08/25/on-the-current-status-of-the-daily-stormer-and-the-weird-events-surrounding-it/|title=On the current status of the Daily Stormer and the weird events surrounding it|date=August 25, 2017|author=Andrew Anglin|publisher=Wordpress}}</ref>) that GoDaddy remains a registrar for [[Celeb Jihad]], which features leaked or hacked sexual videos of celebrities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/gyywax/hacked-celebrity-nudes-show-freedom-of-speech-is-arbitrarily-defined-by-internet-corporations|title=Hacked celebrity nudes show freedom of speech is arbitrarily defined by internet corporations|publisher=Vice|date=August 25, 2017}}</ref> The next day Stormfront's domain name was seized by [[Network Solutions]], enforcing terms of service against "bigotry, discrimination or hatred". Prompted by correspondence from the [[Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law]], the action prevented the site, which had operated for 20 years, from reemerging under a different registrar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/story/news/2017/08/26/white-supremacist-forum-site-stormfront-seized-domain-hosts/604902001/|title=White supremacist forum site Stormfront seized by domain hosts|author=Brittany Crocker|publisher=Knoxville News-Sentinel|date=August 27, 2017}}</ref>
